    There is created the office of director of engineering. The director of engineering shall be appointed by the mayor with the consent of a majority of the members elected to the council. The director of engineering may be removed from office by the mayor with the consent of a majority of all the members elected to the council. The director of engineering may be removed from office by a two-thirds vote of all members elected to the council, independent of the mayor's approval or recommendation. 
(Ord. No. 99-59, § I, 7-13-99) 
Sec. 2-222. - Duties. 
(a)  The director of engineering shall have the responsibility to plan, organize, direct, coordinate, maintain and evaluate the operations of the engineering office of the city including but not limited to program effectiveness and demands for expanded or new program offerings as well as recommendations and implementation of appropriate changes. 
(b)  The director of engineering shall have the responsibility to evaluate the need for and feasibility of new programs; conducting short and long-range program planning; identifying sources of grant funding and supervise the preparing of grant applications. 
(c)  The director of engineering shall supervise the recruitment, selection, and training of regular and temporary employees of the department, prepare and administer the department budget; supervise the maintenance of required records; prepare or supervise the preparation of regular and special reports; confer with civic and special interest groups regarding the parks and recreation program; participate in and supervise a variety of informational and public relation activities to make the public aware of program offerings and facilities available; and any other reasonably duties as assigned. 
(d)  The director of engineering shall obey all orders addressed to him by the council or the mayor. He shall report monthly to the city council on activities affecting his department. 
(Ord. No. 99-59, § I, 7-13-99) 
Secs. 2-223-2-300. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - DEPARTMENTS[12] 
Footnotes: 
--- (12) --- 
Cross reference- Civil defense and disaster planning, Ch. 8. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 2-301-2-315. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - BOARD OF PUBLIC WORKS[13] 

Footnotes: 
--- (13) --- 
Cross reference- Fire departments, § 10-21 et seq.; water, sewers and sewage disposal, Ch. 24. 
State Law reference- Board of public works, RSMo 91.450 et seq. 

Sec. 2-316. - Created. 
    There is created for the city an executive department to be known as the board of public works. 
    Said board shall consist of six (6) voting members appointed by the mayor with the approval of the council. No more than two (2) members of said board serving at any one (1) time shall be nonresidents of the City of Carthage. All such members must be residential, business customers or representatives of commercial or industrial customers of Carthage Water & Electric Plant (CW&EP). No more than one (1) member of the board can be employed by the same employer. In all cases, such members of this board shall live within five (5) miles of the Carthage, city limits. 
(Code 1978, § 133.010; Ord. No. 6580, § 1, 3-8-94; Ord. No. 6621, § 1, 6-28-94) 
State Law reference- Authority to create board of public works, RSMo 91.450. 
Sec. 2-317. - Membership. 
(a)  Each member of the board of public works, before entering upon the duties of his office, shall take and subscribe the same oath or affirmation as is required by law to be taken and subscribed by the elective officers of the city, which oath or affirmation shall be filed with the city clerk. Each member of the board of public works shall furnish to the city and shall at all times hereinafter maintain a bond given to the city in the penal sum of two thousand dollars ($2,000.00). The bond shall be paid for by the water and electric department. The bond shall be approved by the mayor and conditioned on the faithful performance of duties as members of the board and upon paying over all monies belonging to the city coming into their hands as provided by law. The bond shall be filed in the office of the city clerk. 
(b)  Each member of the board of public works shall receive from the city, as full compensation of his services, a salary of one hundred dollars ($100.00) per annum, payable monthly, from the revenues derived from the operation of the water and electric plant. 
(c)  In addition to the six (6) voting members appointed by the mayor with the approval of the council, the mayor may appoint a city council member who shall be a nonvoting member of the board, with the approval of the council, and will receive no compensation for such service. 
(Code 1978, §§ 133.030, 133.040; Ord. No. 14-13, § I, 5-27-2014) 
State Law reference- Membership of board of public works, RSMo 91.450-91.470. 
Sec. 2-318. - Official name for conducting business. 
    The business of the board of public works with the exception of the purchase of investments as prescribed in section 2-327 shall be transacted under the name or title of "Carthage Water and Electric Plant." 
(Code 1978, § 133.150) 
Sec. 2-319. - Attorney. 
    The board of public works may employ the services of the city attorney or an assistant designated by him, to handle the legal affairs of the board and the water and electric plant. The board may pay the attorney a retainer fee in the amount of one hundred dollars ($100.00) per month. The fee shall be paid from the operating revenues of the water and electric plant. 
(Code 1978, § 133.120) 
Sec. 2-320. - Employment of personnel. 
(a)  The board of public works may appoint and employ for the purpose of operating the water, electric and sewage disposal departments such officers and employees as may be necessary, at such salaries or wages as may be just and fair for the type and amount of work done and compatible with, but not in excess of, compensation paid for similar work in similar communities in the area. 
(b)  All appointees shall be under the supervision and control of the board of public works, and shall be appointed to hold their respective positions at the pleasure of the board, and shall perform such services as may be prescribed by the board. 
(Code 1978, § 133.110; Ord. No. 6274, § 5, 9-25-90) 
Sec. 2-321. - Employee benefits authorized. 
    The board of public works may contribute toward the purchase of group life insurance, health, accident, hospital and surgical insurance for and on behalf of the employees and their dependents in such amounts and on such terms as the board deems fair and reasonable and for the best interests of the department. 
(Code 1978, § 133.130) 
Sec. 2-322. - Rules and regulations. 
    The board of public works shall make such rules and regulations as it may deem proper, and shall prescribe the duties to be performed by each of its appointees. The board may require any of its appointees to give bond in such sum as the board may prescribe. Such bond shall be conditioned on the faithful performance of duties. 
(Code 1978, § 133.160) 
State Law reference- Rules and regulations authorized, RSMo 91.490. 
Sec. 2-323. - Council approval of rates and budget. 
(a)  A complete schedule of all rates charged by the board of public works for water, electricity and sewer services shall be furnished by the board of public works to the city clerk and shall be kept in the office of the city clerk for public inspection. 
(b)  The annual budget of the board of public works shall be submitted to the council prior to the second council meeting in May of each year for approval. No appropriation shall be made from the budget until the budget has been approved by the council. 
(c)  No change in the rate charged for electricity, water or sewer shall take effect until approved by the council. 
(d)  The collection of rates for water service, electric light and power service or for any other product of service of the water and light plant shall be under the control and supervision of the board of public works, subject to the ordinances of the city council. 
(Code 1978, §§ 133.100, 133.200) 
State Law reference- Council approval of rates authorized, RSMo 91.540. 
Sec. 2-324. - Sewage disposal plant. 
    The board of public works shall supervise and have charge of the operation and maintenance of the sewage disposal plant and sewer flush tanks. It shall let all contract work thereon and the purchase of supplies therefor, in the same manner as provided in section 2-330 and shall employ all necessary labor for the operation and maintenance of the same. 
(Code 1978, § 133.170) 
State Law reference- Board of public works to have charge of municipal public utilities, RSMo 91.450. 
Sec. 2-325. - Reserved. 
Sec. 2-326. - Revenues from sale of water and electric service. 
(a)  All revenues derived from the sale of water and electric service, the sale of appliances and the sundry sources connected with the operation under the jurisdiction of the board of public works shall be deposited in the depository of city funds and charged to a fund known as the "water and electric fund." No monies shall be paid out of the fund except for the payment of expenses of operation, maintenance, repairs, extensions, replacement, depreciation, and any and all liability claims of the water and electric plant and the creation and maintenance of such reserves as the board of public works shall from time to time determine to be necessary and in keeping with sound business management. 
(b)  No check shall be drawn upon the water and electric fund except upon a special warrant signed by the mayor and attested by the city clerk and approved by the president or secretary of the board of public works. The city council shall, monthly, and more often if necessary, appropriate out of the water and electric fund a sum of money sufficient to cover the expenses of operation, maintenance, repairs, extensions, replacements, depreciation, and any and all liabilities of the water and electric plant and in addition thereto, a sum of money equal to the amount which the board of public works has deposited in the bank selected by the city as the depository of city funds and designated "the water and electric operating fund." 
(Code 1978, § 133.050) 
Sec. 2-327. - Investment funds; indebtedness not to exceed surplus. 
(a)  The board of public works may invest and reinvest amounts set aside as reserves and also any surplus remaining in the hands of the city treasurer in obligations issued or guaranteed by the United States or any other state, or any municipal or political subdivision, or any school district therein. Any investments so made shall be purchased and registered in the name of the board of public works. The sale, transfer, or exchange of any security or securities so registered shall be effected by the signature of the president of the board of public works, attested by the secretary, pursuant to authority granted by action of the board of public works. All income derived from such investments and the proceeds from the sale or payment of any investment shall be deposited with the city treasurer in the same manner as other revenues. 
(b)  By vote of two-thirds of the qualified electors voting thereon, the board of public works may become indebted for or contribute toward the purchase, construction, extension or improvement of plants within the city limits to be leased or otherwise disposed of according to law to private persons or corporations, or manufacturing and industrial development purposes, including the real estate, buildings, fixtures and machinery, provided indebtedness or contribution does not exceed that sum carried on the books of account of the board of public works as surplus. 
(Code 1978, § 133.060) 
Sec. 2-328. - Financial reports. 
    At least once each month the board of public works shall furnish to the city clerk a report directed to the city council, showing the balance of the water and electric operating fund, expenditures from the fund itemized as to payroll, bills for materials, supplies, etc., refunds of consumers' deposits and amounts set aside in reserve and a statement of amounts deposited in the city, showing the source of such revenue from the sale of water, electricity, consumers' deposits, income from investments and proceeds of sale of investments. In addition thereto, the report shall show the balance in reserve accounts together with a statement of all approved contract work let and all contracts completed under the supervision of the board during the month next preceding such report. The report shall be submitted in the following form: 
CARTHAGE WATER AND ELECTRIC PLANT

Sec. 2-329. - Maintaining books; annual audit. 
    It shall be the duty of the board of public works to keep books of account, showing with entire accuracy current entries of the receipts and expenditures of the board in such manner as to enable the same to be understood and investigated, and also to preserve on file in its office, duplicate vouchers for all its expenditures, which books and duplicates shall at all times be open to the examination of any councilmember or any committee appointed by the mayor and approved by the city council. The board of public works shall annually cause the books, accounts and records to be audited by a certified public accountant who is experienced in public utility accounting. A copy of the audit shall be filed in the office of the city clerk and approved by the city council. The contract for the making of the audit shall be first approved by the city council. 
(Code 1978, § 133.080) 
State Law reference- Keeping of accounts required, RSMo 91.520. 
Sec. 2-330. - Supervision over work and supplies for water and electric plant; contracts for major plant expansion subject to council approval. 
    The performance of all work and the furnishing of all supplies for the water and electric plants shall be under the supervision and control of the board of public works and contracts for the performance of work and the furnishing of supplies shall be let out in the same manner as other public works and contracts are let out, except in cases where it is not practicable to do so. All contracts pertaining to any major plant expansion, extension or repair shall be submitted to the council, and the council shall, by ordinance, approve same. No such contract shall be binding upon the board of public works until approved by the city council. 
(Code 1978, § 133.090) 
State Law reference- Contracts, RSMo 91.530. 
Sec. 2-331. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. 6698, adopted January 24, 1995, repealed § 2-331, which pertained to city departments to pay utilities and derived from Code 1978, § 133.210. 
Sec. 2-332. - Interference with orders. 
    No person shall willfully interfere with or obstruct the enforcement of any order issued by the board of public works. 
(Code 1978, § 133.190) 
Secs. 2-333-2-400. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - FINANCIAL AFFAIRS[14] 

Footnotes: 
--- (14) --- 
Cross reference- Committee on audit and claims, § 2-59; committee on budget, § 2-62. 
State Law reference- Municipal finances, RSMo 95.010 et seq. 

Sec. 2-401. - Appropriation ordinances. 
    The council may, by ordinance, appropriate funds in the treasury, or which may hereafter come into the treasury through any source of revenue for the current year, for such specified purposes as may therein be made, but such general appropriation shall not authorize the issuance of warrants upon the treasury for any portion of the amounts therein named, and warrants on the treasury in payment of such general appropriations, or such portions thereof as the council may desire to have paid, shall be issued by the mayor and clerk only when authorized by ordinance. 
(Code 1978, § 153.120) 
Sec. 2-402. - Claims generally. 
    All miscellaneous claims against the city shall be filed with the city clerk in proper form not later than Wednesday before the second Monday in each month, and unless so filed, the audit and claims committee shall not be obliged to consider them, unless ordered to do so by the council. If any claim filed against the city is not in sufficient form or substance to enable the committee to consider the same intelligently, such committee shall refer the same back to be made more definite and certain, and if referred back, such committee shall note its objections conveniently thereon. Claims against the city that are fixed by ordinance, such as salaries and similar fixed charges do not have to be referred to the committee. 
(Code 1978, § 101.270) 
Sec. 2-403. - Payment of bills. 
    Whenever the city is indebted to any person, and the amount thereof shall have been audited and allowed by the council, a warrant shall be drawn therefor, in favor of such person for such amount. No bill against the city for supplies or services rendered to or for the city or any of its departments, or for money for or on account of the city for salaries and wages of city officers and employees, shall be certified as correct and approved by the committee on audit claims or allowed by the council, unless it was filed in the office of the city clerk on or before the Friday next preceding the meeting of the council at which the bill is to be allowed. 
(Code 1978, § 153.130) 
Sec. 2-404. - Warrants assignable. 
    All warrants of the city shall be assignable by endorsement thereon, signed by the payee and giving the name of the assigns and date of the assignment. 
(Code 1978, § 153.140) 
Sec. 2-405. - Expenditures generally. 
    All warrants drawn for salaries, expenses or liabilities of the city government, or grading or repairing streets, or other public work, shall be drawn upon and payable out of the general revenue fund, except as otherwise provided. All warrants drawn on account of salaries or expenses incident to the board of public works shall be drawn upon and payable only out of the funds belonging to such board. 
(Code 1978, § 153.160) 
Sec. 2-406. - Payment of fees, taxes and license charges under protest. 
(a)  If no other procedure is established by law for protesting a fee, tax or license charge, then a person who has paid any fee, tax or license charge shall protest at the time of paying such fee, tax or license charge, or within thirty (30) days thereafter, by filing with the city clerk of the city a written statement setting forth the grounds on which the protest is based, the true value of the money in dispute, the date when the fee, tax or license charge was paid and proof that the person making the claim paid the fee, tax or license charge. 
(b)  If no other procedure is established by law for protesting a fee, tax or license charge, and a person has paid a fee, tax or license charge prior to the passage of this article, such person shall have the right to protest the payment of the fee, tax or license charge provided the statute of limitations has not expired on the claim, and the claim is filed within thirty (30) days of the passage of his ordinance with the city clerk of the city setting forth therein a statement of the grounds on which the protest is based, the true value of the money in dispute, the date when the fee, tax or license charge was paid and proof that the person making the claim paid the fee, tax or license charge. 
(c)  The city clerk shall set aside, in a separate account, all or part of such fee, tax or license charge which is in dispute under subsection (a). Within sixty (60) days after the filing of the protest under subsection (a) or (b), an administrative hearing officer appointed by the city administrator shall hold a hearing on the protest. Notice of the hearing and presentation of evidence shall be as described in subsection (d). A record of the hearing shall be made and upon hearing the evidence, the administrative hearing officer shall rule on the validity of the protest within ten days after the conclusion of the hearing. Any person aggrieved by this decision, including the city, shall, within thirty (30) days after notice of the ruling as required by RSMo ch. 536, file his or her administrative appeal pursuant to the rules established in RSMo ch. 536, for review of a contested case in the circuit court of Jasper County. If no action is taken to appeal the decision of the administrative hearing officer as required by RSMo ch. 536, the decision shall be final. 
(1)  If the protest is invalid the city clerk shall, when such decision is final, disburse to the proper official the fee, tax or license charge impounded as authorized by the laws of the city. 
(2)  If the protest is valid, then the city clerk shall, when the decision is final, refund to the person who protested the fee, tax or license charge the amount found to be invalid, plus interest computed at a rate equal to that received on the city's average daily collected bank balance on the sum from the time it was paid to the city. 
(d)  The city administrator shall hold a public hearing within ten business days after notice of appeal is filed. Notice of hearing shall contain a time and date for the hearing and be directed to the appealing party at the address given on his appeal by certified mail. The appellant, his or her attorney, and any other persons whose interest may be affected on the matter shall be given the opportunity to be heard, present evidence, and examine adverse witnesses. 
(e)  Nothing in the section shall preclude the city from exercising its rights to determine the enforceability and applicability of this section when a person challenges such authority wherever and however such rights may be asserted under applicable law. 
(Ord. No. 08-44, § I, 9-23-08) 
Secs. 2-407-2-450. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 06-21, adopted Mar. 28, 2006, repealed § 2-406, which pertained to city clerk's revolving fund and derived from Ord. No. 6046, § I, adopted Aug. 26, 1986; Ord. No. 6298, § 1, adopted Jan. 22, 1991; Ord. No. 6653, § 1, adopted Sept. 27, 1994; Ord. No. 00-15, § I, adopted Mar. 28, 2000; Ord. No. 05-87, § I, adopted Dec. 27, 2005. 
ARTICLE VI. - BOARDS, COMMISSIONS, ETC.[15] 
Footnotes: 
--- (15) --- 
Cross reference- Board of public works, § 2-316 et seq.; plumbing examining board, § 6-209 et seq.; library board, § 16-31; planning, zoning and historic preservation commission, § 17-16 et seq.; board of adjustment, § 17-36 et seq.; police personnel administration board, § 18-511 et seq.; solid waste commission, § 20-2. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-451. - Notice of meetings; minutes of meetings. 
(a)  The president or chairman of any board now or hereafter created by ordinance shall furnish to the city clerk the date, hour and place of meeting of all regularly-called meetings at least twenty-four (24) hours prior to such regularly called meeting. The president or chairman of each such board shall furnish to the city clerk the date, hour and place of meeting of any specially-called meeting as far in advance of such meeting as possible, but at least twenty-four (24) hours in advance of the meeting. 
(b)  The city clerk shall post notices of all meetings of each city board upon receipt of same. The notice shall include the date, time and place of meeting and the name of the board which is meeting. 
(c)  The president or chairman of each board shall furnish to the city clerk the full and complete minutes of all meetings, within seventy-two (72) hours after the meeting. 
(Code 1978, § 127.010) 
State Law reference- Notice of meetings, RSMo 610.020 
Sec. 2-452. - Travel expenses. 
    No member of any board created by ordinance shall travel outside the corporate limits of the city at the expense of the city, unless such travel is first approved by the council. No voucher for expenses incurred by travel outside the corporate limits of the city shall be paid unless such travel received prior council approval. 
(Code 1978, § 127.020) 
Sec. 2-453. - Service on more than one board. 
    No person, including a member of the council, shall be a member of more than one (1) board of the city. 
(Code 1978, § 127.030) 
Secs. 2-454-2-465. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - HOSPITAL BOARD 

Sec. 2-466. - Created. 
(a)  There is created a hospital board of trustees pursuant to RSMo 96.150 to 96.180 and 96.195, to the extent not inconsistent with the Code of Carthage. 
(b)  The board of trustees shall consist of five (5) members appointed by the mayor with the approval of the city council, who shall be citizens of the city, and who shall serve for four (4) year terms. In addition to the removal procedures of RSMo 96.175, any member of the board of trustees may be removed from the board, with or without cause, by majority vote of the members of city council. 
(Ord. No. 6473, § 1, 1-12-93; Ord. No. 03-64, § I, 10-28-2003; Ord. No. 08-54, § I, 11-25-08; Ord. No. 16-50, §§ I, II, 12-13-16) 
State Law reference- Board membership, etc., RSMo 96.160-96.180. 
Sec. 2-467. - Records. 
    The secretary of the hospital board of trustees shall keep accurate minutes of all board meetings, which minutes shall be signed by said secretary and by the president. All books, records, and accounts of the board of trustees shall be open to inspection by the mayor or by any committee of the council authorized for that purpose. 
(Code 1978, § 137.060) 
Sec. 2-468. - Funds generally. 
    All funds accruing to the city for hospital purposes shall be paid over to the city and receipts therefor shall be filed with the city clerk. No hospital funds in the hands of the city shall be expended except upon warrants duly executed by the mayor and city clerk, and all warrants shall be drawn upon vouchers of the president and secretary of the hospital board of trustees. No warrant shall be drawn unless first authorized by the city council. The funds in the hands of the city shall be kept in deposit with a depository designated by the city council. Notwithstanding anything to the contrary in this Division 2 or otherwise, funds received by the city in connection with the sale of the hospital facility and/or the defeasance of bonds related to the hospital facility shall be deposited in such city accounts as are designated by the city council. 
(Code 1978, § 137.080; Ord. No. 16-33, § I, 7-26-16) 
Sec. 2-469. - Revolving fund. 
    The hospital board of trustees shall make a requisition upon the city for hospital funds, not to exceed the sum of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00), for the purpose of paying cash to employees, petty accounts, and for various necessities, the need for which may arise from time to time. In drawing on such fund, the board shall direct its treasurer to execute a receipt for such funds as are drawn, and the bookkeeper of the board shall keep an accurate account of the payment of such bills and minor accounts as may be paid from such fund until the fund is exhausted, at which time vouchers shall be turned over to the city clerk, showing the date, the amount, and the purpose for which the fund has been used. When such payments amount to the sum so drawn, the city clerk shall surrender the receipt given him and take the vouchers covering the expenditures in lieu thereof. 
(Code 1978, § 137.090) 
Sec. 2-470. - Special funds. 
    The city shall open and carry on the city books not less than three (3) separate accounts covering the city hospital funds. One (1) fund shall be known as the building fund, one (1) shall be known as the operating fund and one (1) shall be known as the endowment fund. The city shall open and carry on the city books, such other accounts as may be necessary to keep distinct account of the several funds belonging to the hospital. The board of trustees shall pay over to the city, as rapidly as collected, interest and other funds, designating the particular fund to which such funds so paid are to be credited, and for which the city shall issue receipt to the board of trustees, designating the fund to which the payments belong. 
(Code 1978, § 137.100) 
Sec. 2-471. - Ambulance service. 
    The board of trustees of the hospital may establish, operate and maintain an ambulance service in order to provide for the general health, welfare and convenience of the residents of the city and the surrounding area. 
(Code 1978, § 137.130) 
Sec. 2-472. - Power to bind city for indebtedness. 
    All obligations incurred in connection with the construction, leasing, equipping, operating and maintaining of the facility and grounds and other property, real and personal, under control of the hospital board of trustees shall be payable only from the fund established for such facility and the assets under control of the board. The city shall not be liable for any such claims or indebtedness except to the extent of the fund established for such facility and the assets under control of the board or as elsewhere provided. 
(Code 1978, § 137.140) 
Sec. 2-473. - Council approval of contracts. 
    Whenever the hospital board of trustees enters into any contract for the construction of any building or other improvement, for the McCune Brooks Hospital which requires state and/or federal approval, the contract shall thereupon be submitted to the city council for its approval. If such contract is found to be satisfactory, the council shall, by ordinance, approve the same. No such contracts shall be binding either upon the board of trustees or the city until the same shall have been approved by the council as herein provided. 
(Code 1978, § 137.150) 
Sec. 2-474. - Restrictions on hospital activities. 
    No part of the net earnings of the city's hospital shall inure to the benefit of, or be distributed to, members of the board of trustees, officers, or other private persons, except that the board of trustees shall be authorized to pay reasonable compensation for services rendered. No substantial part of the activities of the hospital shall be the carrying on of propaganda or otherwise attempting to influence legislation, and the hospital shall not participate in any political campaign on behalf of any candidate for public office or carry on any other activity not permitted by an organization exempt from federal income tax under the Internal Revenue Code of 1954. 
(Code 1978, § 137.160)

(Ord. No. 6276, § 1(142.010), 12-25-90)

    Powers Museum Inc., is hereby established as the Administrative Board of the Powers Museum. The city shall transfer all property both monetary and real to Powers Museum Inc. Board for the administration, maintenance and operation of the Powers Museum.

DIVISION 5. - CIVIL WAR MUSEUM ADVISORY BOARD 

Sec. 2-494. - Created. 
    There is hereby authorized, established and created for the city an advisory board for the Carthage Civil War Museum. 
(Ord. No. 6532, § 1, 10-26-93) 
Sec. 2-495. - Composition; appointment. 
    The board shall consist of seven (7) members appointed by the mayor with the approval of the council. No more than two (2) of said members may be nonresidents of the City of Carthage. The members shall serve a term of three (3) years with terms expiring on December 1 of each year. The terms of no more three (3) of said members shall expire in any given year. 
(Ord. No. 6532, § 2, 10-26-93) 
Sec. 2-496. - Duties and responsibilities. 
    The Civil War Museum Board shall be an advisory board to advise the city on the establishment of the overall mission of the museum including operational goals and objectives. These will include but not be limited to the appropriateness of exhibits to be displayed in said museum, hours of operations, staffing, and procedures. The board shall not be responsible for the day to day management of the museum nor shall the board have any power over expenditure of funds or receipt of funds for said museum. For reporting and organizational purposes, the Civil War Museum Board will report through the public service committee which will function as the board's oversight committee. 
(Ord. No. 6532, § 3, 10-26-93; Ord. No. 98-58, § I, 9-8-98) 
DIVISION 6. - TAX INCREMENT FINANCE COMMISSION 

Sec. 2-497. - Created. 
    There is hereby created a tax increment finance commission in accordance with RSMo. 99.820. 
(Ord. No. 96-13, § 1, 2-27-96) 
Sec. 2-498. - Composition; appointment. 
    The commission shall consist of six (6) members appointed by the mayor with the approval of the council, two (2) members appointed by the Carthage R-9 School District, and one (1) member appointed to represent all other districts levying ad valorem taxes. Of the members first appointed by the municipality, two (2) shall be designated to serve for term of two (2) years, two (2) shall be designated to serve for term of three (3) years and two (2) shall be designated to serve for term of four (4) years from the date of said initial appointment. Thereafter, the members appointed by the municipality shall serve for a term of four (4) years. 
(Ord. No. 96-13, § 1, 2-27-96) 
Sec. 2-499. - Duties and responsibilities. 
    The tax increment finance commission shall be an advisory board to the city council. Said commission shall review all requests for the establishment or amendment of tax increment finance districts. Said commission shall not have the authority to approve the establishment or amendment of a tax increment finance district or to enter into any contracts or agreements. In its deliberations concerning the establishment of a tax increment finance district, the city council shall consider the recommendations made by the tax increment finance commission. Said commission shall not have power over expenditures of funds or receipts of funds. 
(Ord. No. 96-13, § 1, 2-27-96) 
Secs. 2-500-2-520. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - CODE OF ETHICS[18] 

Footnotes: 
--- (18) --- 
Cross reference- City council, § 2-21 et seq.; mayor and mayor pro tem, § 2-131 et seq. 

Sec. 2-521. - Declaration of policy. 
    The public judges its government by the way the members of the city council, the mayor and its appointed officials conduct themselves in the post to which they are elected. The public has a right to expect that each such officer's conduct will tend to preserve public confidence in and respect for the government of the City of Carthage. To obtain these goals, it is important that the mayor, each member of the city council and the appointed officials of the City of Carthage will uniformly: 
(1)  Treat all citizens with courtesy, impartiality, fairness and equality under the law; and 
(2)  Avoid both actual and potential conflict between their private self-interest and the public interest. 
(Ord. No. 97-75, § I, 12-23-97) 
Sec. 2-522. - Definitions. 
    [The following words, terms and phrases, as used in this article, shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them in this section, unless the context clearly indicates otherwise:] 
    Appointed official means any person appointed to the position of department head of any department of the government of the City of Carthage and any person appointed to any of the governing boards of the City of Carthage. 
    Financial interest means any interest which shall yield, directly or indirectly, a monetary or other material benefit to the public official. 
    Person means any person, firm, association, group, partnership or corporation, or any combination thereof. 
    Personal interest means any interest arising from blood or marriage relationships or from close business or political association whether or not any financial interest is involved. 
    Public body means any board, agency, body, commission, committee, department or office of the City of the Carthage, Missouri. 
(Ord. No. 97-75, § I, 12-23-97) 
Sec. 2-523. - Fair and equal treatment. 
(a)  Impartiality: Neither the mayor nor any member of the council nor any appointed official of the city shall grant or make available to any person any consideration, treatment, advantage or favor beyond that which it is the policy of the City of Carthage to grant or make available to the public at large. 
(b)  Use of public property: Neither the mayor nor any member of the council nor any appointed official of the city shall request, use or permit the use of, any publicly owned or publicly supported property, vehicle, equipment, labor or service for the personal convenience or the personal advantage of that person or any other person. This rule shall not be deemed to prohibit the mayor or any member of the council or any appointed official of the city from requesting, using or permitting the use of such publicly owned or publicly supplied property, vehicle, equipment, material, labor or service, which are provided as a matter of public policy for the use of officials and employees in the conduct of official business. 
(Ord. No. 97-75, § I, 12-23-97) 
Sec. 2-524. - Conflict of interest. 
    Neither the mayor nor any member of the council nor any appointed official of the city shall have a financial interest, direct or indirect, in any contract with the city, or be financially interested, directly or indirectly, in the sale to the city of any land, materials, supplies or services, except on behalf of the city as an officer or employee. Any violation of the provision renders the contract or sale void, and any person violating this section shall thereby forfeit their office. Provided, however, that nothing contained herein shall be construed to apply to any contract, sale or lease not initiated, proposed, instituted, introduced by the public officer who may be involved or interested in such undertaking. 
    Neither the mayor nor any member of the council shall hold any other office or employment with the City of Carthage during their term of office. 
    The mayor, the members of the council and the appointed officials of the city are prohibited from either directly or indirectly bidding on or purchasing property owned by the city or under the direction and control of the city unless the property is being sold at a public sale or auction or by sealed bids. 
(Ord. No. 97-75, § I, 12-23-97) 
Sec. 2-525. - Disclosure of interest in legislation. 
    The mayor or any member of the council who has a financial or other personal interest in any legislation shall disclose on the records of the city council the nature and extent of such interest and may vote on such legislation provided that said official is not prohibited from voting by some other provision of the City of Carthage or the State of Missouri. This provision shall not apply if the person so effected abstains from voting. 
(Ord. No. 97-75, § I, 12-23-97) 
Sec. 2-526. - Gifts and favors. 
    Neither the mayor nor any member of the council nor any appointed official of the city shall accept any valuable item or promise, from any person, firm or corporation which to the official's knowledge is interested directly or indirectly in any manner whatsoever in business dealings with the city. The prohibition against gifts or favors shall not apply to any occasional nonpecuniary gift, insignificant in value, or an award publicly presented in recognition of public service or any gift which would have been offered or given if he were not a member of the council, the mayor of the City of Carthage or an appointed official of the City of Carthage. 
(Ord. No. 97-75, § I, 12-23-97) 
Sec. 2-527. - Confidential information. 
    Neither the mayor nor any member of the council nor any appointed official of the city shall, without prior formal authorization of the council, disclose any confidential information concerning any other official or employee, or any other person, or any property or governmental affairs of the City of Carthage. Said person shall also be prohibited from the use of any confidential information to advance the financial or personal interest of said person or any other person. 
(Ord. No. 97-75, § I, 12-23-97) 
Sec. 2-528. - Prohibition of interference. 
    No member of the council of the City of Carthage shall direct or request the employment or removal of persons from employment by the city administrator or the mayor or by any department head of the city, or in any way interfere with the appointment or removal of officers and employees of the various departments of the city. Except for the purpose of inquiry, all members of the council shall deal with the administrative officers and services of the city solely through the mayor and the city administrator of the City of Carthage, and no member of the council shall give orders to any employee of the City of Carthage either publicly or privately. 
(Ord. No. 97-75, § I, 12-23-97) 
Sec. 2-529. - Political activity. 
    Neither the mayor nor any member of the council nor any appointed official of the city shall use the prestige of their office on behalf any political party or candidate for elected office and to this end shall refrain from using their official title in support of or in opposition to candidates for political office or a political party. Nor shall the mayor or any member of the council or any appointed official of the city use their official title in support of or opposition to legislation or other matters pending before governmental bodies other than the City of Carthage, Missouri unless the council of the city has officially taken a position with respect to said legislation. 
    No candidate for mayor or candidate for the city council of the city shall ask or direct any employee or salaried officer of the city to perform any act or service for said candidate which relates to the candidate's election campaign other than as a part of the employee's or officer's official duties. 
(Ord. No. 97-75, § I, 12-23-97) 
Sec. 2-530. - Immoral conduct. 
    If the mayor or any member of the council or appointed official of the city is convicted of a crime involving moral turpitude, said office shall immediately become vacant. The mayor and members of the council and appointed officials of the city shall refrain from engaging in conduct which is improper and from using their position to obtain a favor or advantage not available to the public at large. 
(Ord. No. 97-75, § I, 12-23-97) 
Sec. 2-531. - Sanctions. 
    Violations of any provisions of this code of ethics should raise significant questions for the mayor or council person or appointed official concerned as to whether their voluntary resignation or other course of action is indicated to promote the best interest of the City of Carthage. Violations may constitute cause for censure, suspension, or removal from office. 
(Ord. No. 97-75, § I, 12-23-97) 
Chapter 3 - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Intoxicating liquor in fire department buildings, § 10-29; licenses, taxation and miscellaneous business regulations, Ch. 12. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 3-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Church or place of worship shall mean and include a building used for worship services by an organization having the following characteristics: 
(1)  Recognized by the state as a not-for-profit charitable entity, organized for religious purposes; 
(2)  Meets on a regular basis, at least weekly; and 
(3)  Utilizes clergy duly licensed by a religion recognized by the state. 
    Intoxicating liquor means and include alcohol for beverage purposes, alcoholic, spirituous, fermented, malt, or other liquors, or combination of liquors, a part of which is spirituous, vinous, or fermented, and all preparations or mixtures for beverage purposes, containing in excess of one-half of one (1) percent by volume except for nonintoxicating beer as defined in RSMo section 312.010. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 311.020. 
    Malt liquor means any intoxicating liquor containing not in excess of five (5) percent alcohol by weight that is manufactured from pure hops and pure extract of hops, or pure barley malt or wholesome grains or cereals and wholesome yeast and pure water. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 311.200. 
    Nonintoxicating beer means any beer manufactured from pure hops and pure extract of hops, and pure barley malt, or other wholesome grains or cereals, and wholesome yeast and pure water, and free from all harmful substances, preservatives and adulterants, and having an alcoholic content of more than one-half of one (1) percent by volume, and not more than three and two-tenths (3.2) percent by weight. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 312.010. 
    Original package means: 
(1)  One (1) sealed container of not less than fifty (50) milliliters of any intoxicating liquor; or 
(2)  Any package containing three (3) or more beer containers and any package containing three (3) or more containers containing nonintoxicating beer. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 311.100, 312.010. 
    Wholesale liquor dealer or wholesale liquor dealing agent means any person who solicits, receives, or takes orders for, the purchase and delivery of any intoxicating liquor to any person within the city. 
(Code 1978, §§ 600.010, 600.020, 600.150, 605.010, 610.020; Ord. No. 01-21, § I, 3-13-2001; Ord. No. 02-14, § I, 3-12-2002) 
Sec. 3-2. - Exemptions. 
    This chapter does not: 
(1)  Apply to beverages having an alcoholic content of less than one-half of one (1) percent by volume. 
(2)  Prevent the natural fermentation of fruit juices in the home for the exclusive use of the occupants of the home and their guests. 
(Code 1978, §§ 600.010, 600.090, 605.010) 
Sec. 3-3. - Public possession. 
(a)  In this section "alcoholic beverage" includes intoxicating liquor and nonintoxicating beer. 
(b)  No person shall possess any alcoholic beverage on any street, alley or sidewalk within the city except in the original package with the seal unbroken. 
(c)  Subsection (b) does not prohibit the possession of an alcoholic beverage in an establishment licensed to sell same for on-premises consumption. 
(Ord. No. 6142, § 7(3), 9-13-88; Ord. No. 6754, § 1, 8-22-95) 
Cross reference- Drinking of intoxicating liquor in public places, §§ 3-21, 3-59; driving while intoxicated, § 23-155; driving with excessive blood alcohol content, § 23-156. 
Sec. 3-4. - Identification for the purpose of determining age. 
    Identification, for the purpose of determining the age, shall be presented upon request of any law enforcement officer by any person on the premises of an establishment licensed to sell intoxicating liquor or nonintoxicating beer, or by any person found in the possession of any intoxicating liquor or nonintoxicating beer. 
(Code 1978, § 600.180) 
Sec. 3-5. - Possession of intoxicants by minors. 
    Any person under the age of twenty-one (21) years, who purchases or attempts to purchase, or has in his possession, any intoxicating liquor as defined in RSMo 311.020 or who is visibly in an intoxicated condition as defined in RSMo 577.001, or has a detectable blood alcohol content of more than two-hundredths of one (1) percent or more by weight of alcohol in such person's blood is guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1978, § 600.170; Ord. No. 06-75, § 1, 11-14-06; Ord. No. 17-20, § 1, 6-13-2017) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 311.325, 312.407. 
Sec. 3-6. - Minors misrepresenting age. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person under the age of twenty-one (21) years to represent themselves to have attained the age of twenty-one (21) years for the purpose of purchasing, asking for, or in any way receiving any intoxicating liquor or nonintoxicating beer. 
(Code 1978, § 600.180) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 311.320, 312.405. 
Sec. 3-7. - Sale to and by certain persons. 
(a)  Certain persons may not purchase intoxicating liquors. No person, or his employee, shall sell or supply intoxicating liquor, or permit the same to be sold or supplied, to a habitual drunkard or to any person who is under or apparently under the influence of intoxicating liquor. Intoxicating liquor shall not be given, sold or otherwise supplied to any person under the age of twenty-one (21) years, but this shall not apply to the supplying of intoxicating liquor to a person under said age for medicinal purposes only. No person under the age of twenty-one (21) years shall sell, or assist in the sale or dispensing of, intoxicating liquor. 
(b)  Persons under the age of twenty-one restricted from entering premises selling intoxicating liquors, etc. It shall be unlawful for any licensee holding a sales-by-drink license for intoxicating liquor, beer or nonintoxicating beer, or his employee, agent or servant, to either directly or indirectly suffer or allow a person under the age of twenty-one (21) years to enter the premises of said licensee, except that a person age sixteen (16) through twenty (20) years may be on said premises if accompanied by a legal guardian, parent or spouse over the age of twenty-one (21) years. These provisions shall not apply to premises where substantial quantity of foods are served, premises used primarily as a bowling alley, or premises with licenses prescribed in Section 311.480 of the Revised Statutes of the State of Missouri. For the purpose of this paragraph, "substantial quantities of food" shall mean the amount of prepared meals and food wherefrom at least fifty (50) percent of the gross income of any establishment has been derived during the three (3) most recent months preceding. Any person found guilty violating the provisions of this paragraph shall be subject to a fine of not more than two hundred dollars ($200.00). 
(Code 1978, §§ 600.100, 600.190) 
State Law reference- When persons eighteen years of age or older may sell or handle liquor or beer, RSMo 311.300; sale to minors, certain other persons, RSMo 311.310. 
Sec. 3-8. - Conduct in taverns. 
    It shall be unlawful for any licensee holding a sales-by-drink license for intoxicating liquor, beer or nonintoxicating beer or his employees, agents or service [servants] to allow any of the following, to wit: 
(1)  Any employee of said establishment on the premises in a condition where either of the breasts, pelvic area, or buttocks are not covered with opaque clothing. 
(2)  Any person to perform a dance of any kind upon the bar or any other place used for the serving of food or beverages or any place within the licensed premises opened to public view from the sidewalk or street. 
(3)  Exotic dance or strip tease to be performed, except: 
a.  Such dance may be performed on a raised dais or platform containing not less than one hundred (100) square feet of service and at least eighteen (18) inches from the floor level where patrons may be seated or standing. 
b.  Such dance must [be performed] at every point no less than six (6) feet from the nearest patron. 
c.  Such dance shall not be performed in any place within the license premises which is opened to public view from the sidewalk or street. 
d.  Such dance shall only be permitted in an establishment which is properly zoned in an adult entertainment district as provided for in sections 25-800 through 25-805 of the Carthage Code. 
(Ord. No. 6481, § 1, 2-9-93; Ord. No. 6667, § 1, 11-22-94) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 6481 did not specifically amend this Code; hence, inclusion of § 1 as § 3-8 was at the discretion of the editor. 
Sec. 3-9. - Possession of alcoholic beverages in glass containers on city-owned property; exception. 
    It shall be unlawful to possess intoxicating liquor, malt liquor or nonintoxicating beer in glass bottles or glass containers on all real estate owned by the city including, but not limited to, all city-owned parks, except that this section shall not apply to the Carthage Memorial Hall property located at 407 S. Garrison, which is owned and operated by the city. 
(Ord. No. 01-16, § I, 3-13-2001) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 01-16, § I, adopted Mar. 13, 2001, did not specify manner of codification, hence; inclusion of this provision as § 3-9 was at the discretion of the editor. 
Sec. 3-10. - Proximity to churches, schools and certain other public places. 
(a)  Except as provided in subsection (b), no license shall be granted for the sale of intoxicating liquor within three hundred (300) feet of any school, hospital, church or other building regularly used as a place of religious worship, except that when a school, hospital, church or place of worship shall hereafter be established within three hundred (300) feet of any place of business licensed to sell intoxicating liquor, the license shall not be denied. The three hundred (300) feet distance provided for in this section shall be measured from the center threshold of the main public entrances of such premises by the most direct walking route. No license shall be denied under this section if there has been a valid license to sell intoxicating beverages in existence at the same location or address within one (1) year immediately preceding the application for such a license. 
(b)  Any business may serve intoxicating liquor so long as they are operating with in an area of the city that is zoned District E General Business or greater. There shall be no restrictions prohibiting a business that possesses the proper licenses from the city and the State of Missouri to sell intoxicating liquor, as approved by their license, within a general business zoned area of the city with the following exceptions and distinctions (these distinctions apply only to this section of the code): 
(1)  Type 1 Business : A business that is operating within District E General Business or greater zoned district with more than fifty (50) percent of its annual revenue solely from the sale of intoxicating liquor shall be permitted to operate without restrictions limiting their proximity to a residential property, church, school or hospital with so long as they are not located within one hundred fifty (150) feet from any property zoned District A or B. The measurement of the one hundred fifty (150) from District A or B shall be from property line of the business property to the nearest property line zoned District A or B. 
(2)  Type 2 Business : A business which receives less than fifty (50) percent of its annual revenue from the sale of intoxicating liquor, is permitted to operate freely and without restrictions limiting their proximity to a residential property, church, school or hospital throughout any District E General Business district or greater zoned district. 
(c)  Any exception may be given to any restriction of section 3-10 by a simple majorly vote of the city council upon motion by any council member. 
(d)  Nothing in this section shall be interpreted to extend or expand the type of licenses allowed for the sale of intoxicating liquor. 
(Ord. No. 01-18, § I, 3-13-2001; Ord. No. 01-55, § I, 6-26-2001; Ord. No. 02-36, § I, 6-11-2002; Ord. No. 15-15, § I, 5-12-2015) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 01-18, § I, adopted Mar. 13, 2001, did not designate § I, hence; inclusion of § I as § 3-10 was at the discretion of the editor. 
Sec. 3-11. - Prohibiting the use of alcoholic beverages and drugs by any minor at open house parties. 
(a)  No person who is the owner in possession, a tenant or sub-tenant, or has temporary charge of any residence or premises, shall allow an open house party to take place at the residence or premises if any alcoholic beverage or drug is possessed or consumed at the residence or premises by any minor where the person knew or reasonably should have known that any alcoholic beverage or drug was in the possession or being consumed by a minor at the residence or premises and where the person failed to take reasonable steps to prevent the possession or consumption of the alcoholic beverage or drug at the residence or premises. 
    The provisions of this section shall not apply to: 
(1)  The consumption, use or possession of a drug by a minor pursuant to a lawful prescription for each drug. 
(2)  Religious observance or prescribed medical treatments. 
(3)  The possession by a minor of alcoholic beverages or lawfully prescribed drugs incidental to the lawful employment of such minor. 
(b)  Any person violating any provision of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by fine of two hundred and fifty dollars ($250.00) for the first violation of this section and a fine of five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each subsequent violation. 
(c)  The following definitions shall be used for the provisions of this section: 
(1)  Adult. Person seventeen (17) years of age or older. 
(2)  Alcoholic beverage. Any alcoholic liquor as defined now and hereafter by the revises Statutes of Missouri (RSMo). Currently, "alcoholic liquor" is define by RSMo 311.020. 
(3)  Control. Any form of authority, regulation, responsibility or dominion, including a possessory right. 
(4)  Drug. A controlled substance as defined and described now or hereafter by the Revised Statutes of Missouri. Currently "controlled substances" are defined and described by RSMo. 195.005 - 195.425. 
(5)  Minor. A person not legally permitted by reason of age to possess, consume or purchase alcoholic liquor as described now or hereafter by the Revised Statutes of Missouri. 
(6)  Open house party. A social gathering at a residence or premises of persons in addition to the owner or those with rights of possession or their immediate family members. 
(7)  Residence or premises. A motel room, hotel room, home, apartment, condominium, or other dwelling unit, including the curtilage of a dwelling unit, or a hall, meeting room, or other place of assembly, whether occupied as a dwelling or specifically for social functions, and whether owned, leased, rented, or used with or without compensation. 
(Ord. No. 07-44, § 1, 9-13-07) 
Secs. 3-12-3-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - NONINTOXICATING BEER 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 3-21. - Unlawful possession. 
    No person shall possess nonintoxicating beer within the city, unless the same has been acquired from some person holding a duly authorized license to sell the same. 
(Code 1978, § 605.100) 
State Law reference- Possession of nonintoxicating beer not acquired from dealer, RSMo 312.160. 
Sec. 3-22. - Sale in original package. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, or offer for sale, in this city, any nonintoxicating beer, except the same shall be sold or offered for sale in the original bottle, or in the original package containing bottles, bearing the original label and full name of the brewer or manufacturer thereof, both upon the label on the bottle and upon the cap or cork of such bottle, or in the case of the sale of nonintoxicating beer or draught, except the same be drawn from the original keg or barrel, having stamped on the ends thereof the full name of the manufacturer or brewer of the nonintoxicating beer therein contained. 
(Code 1978, § 605.060) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 312.300. 
Sec. 3-23. - Sale or keeping of intoxicating liquor. 
(a)  No person holding a license issued under the terms of this article for the sale of nonintoxicating beer at retail, shall be granted or permitted to hold a license to sell intoxicating liquor, nor shall any person be granted or permitted to hold a license to sell nonintoxicating beer in, or about the premises of any person who is the holder of a license to sell intoxicating liquor. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 312.050. 
(b)  No person holding a license under the terms of this article shall have or keep or secrete in or about the premises described in, and covered by, his license, any intoxicating liquor of any kind or character, nor shall any manufacturer, wholesaler, or distributor sell intoxicating liquor to any retail distributor holding a license for the sale of nonintoxicating beer only. 
(Code 1978, §§ 605.050, 605.110) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 312.430. 
Sec. 3-24. - Licensee's duty to prevent increasing alcoholic content. 
    It shall be the duty of every holder of a license to sell nonintoxicating beer to use every precaution to prevent any person on the premises described in such license from pouring into, mixing with, or adding to such beer, any alcohol, or other liquor, or any alcohol cube or cubes, or other ingredient or ingredients, that will increase, or tend to increase, the alcoholic content of such beer. Any such license holder who shall, or who shall knowingly permit any person in or about the premises described in such license, to pour into, mix with, or add to such beer, any such ingredient or ingredients that will increase, or tend to increase, the alcoholic content of any such beer, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and in addition thereto, shall forfeit such license and shall not thereafter, for a period of one (1) year, be entitled to the renewal of such license. 
(Code 1978, § 605.070) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 312.440, 312.450. 
Sec. 3-25. - Breaking original package or drinking on premises. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person holding a license authorizing the sale of nonintoxicating beer in the original package to allow a package to be broken, or to allow any of such beer to be consumed on the premises described in the license. 
(b)  No person shall open any original package of nonintoxicating beer in any premises licensed for the sale of same only in the original package. 
(c)  No person shall consume any nonintoxicating beer in any premises licensed for the sale of same only in the original package. 
(Code 1978, § 605.080, 605.090) 
Cross reference- Public possession of alcoholic beverages, § 3-3. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 312.390. 
Sec. 3-26. - Hours of sale. 
    No person holding a license under the provisions of this article, shall sell, give away, or otherwise dispose of, or suffer the same to be done, upon or about his premises, any nonintoxicating beer between 1:30 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. 
(Code 1978, § 605.120) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 312.410. 
Secs. 3-27-3-35. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Local licenses and license fees authorized, RSMo 312.140. 

Sec. 3-36. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to manufacture, brew, sell, or offer for sale in the city any nonintoxicating beer, without a license for such manufacture or sale issued by the city. 
(Code 1978, § 605.020) 
Sec. 3-37. - What license authorizes. 
(a)  A license to brew or manufacture and sell nonintoxicating beer in this city shall be construed to authorize the sale, by the holder of such license, of such beer to distributors or wholesalers for resale to retailers only, and of the sale of such beer, by the holder of such license, direct to retailers. A license authorizing any distributor or wholesaler to sell nonintoxicating beer in this city shall be construed to authorize the sale of such beer only to holders of licenses authorizing the sale of such beer to consumers, nor for resale, but shall not be construed to authorize the sale by any such distributor or wholesaler of such beer direct to consumers. 
(b)  Every license issued under the terms of this division and authorizing the sale of nonintoxicating beer for consumption on the premises described in such license, shall be construed to authorize the sale of such beer by the bottle, by the glass, on draught, and in the original package. 
(c)  No person holding a license for the sale of nonintoxicating beer shall sell beer at any place other than the place described in the license and the application therefor. 
(Code 1978, § 605.040) 
Sec. 3-38. - Applicant's oath. 
(a)  Before any license required by this division is issued the applicant for same shall take and subscribe to an oath that he will not allow any intoxicating liquor to be kept, stored, or secreted in or upon the premises described in such license, and that such applicant will not otherwise violate any law of this state or any ordinance of this city, or knowingly allow any other person to violate any law of this state or ordinance of this city while in or upon such premises. 
(b)  Subsection (a) does not apply to manufacturer's license. 
(Code 1978, § 605.030) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 312.070. 
Sec. 3-39. - Fees. 
(a)  The appropriate annual fee indicated below shall be paid to the city before the issuance or renewal of a license under this division. 
(1)  For the manufacture, and sale by the manufacturer, of nonintoxicating beer brewed or manufactured within the city, three hundred seventy-five dollars ($375.00). 
(2)  For the sale in this city of any nonintoxicating beer by any distributor or wholesaler, other than the manufacturer or brewer thereof, seventy-five dollars ($75.00). 
(3)  For the sale of nonintoxicating beer for consumption on the premises where sold, thirty-seven dollars and fifty cents ($37.50). 
(4)  For the sale of nonintoxicating beer by grocers and other merchants and dealers, for sale in the original package direct to consumers, but not for resale, twenty-two dollars and fifty cents ($22.50). 
(b)  All license fees shall become due and payable on January 1 of each year, and shall be paid in full not later than January 15. 
(Code 1978, § 605.020) 
Sec. 3-40. - Term. 
    Licenses required by this division expire at the end of the calendar year for which they were issued. No license herein shall be issued for a period of less than six (6) months. 
(Code 1978, § 605.020) 
Sec. 3-41. - Transfer. 
    No license issued under the terms of this division shall be transferable or assignable. 
(Code 1978, § 605.020) 
Secs. 3-42-3-55. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - INTOXICATING LIQUOR 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 3-56. - Entry powers of city officials. 
    Any inspector or police officer of the city shall be permitted to enter upon or into any premises licensed under this article in order to ascertain whether there is compliance with the ordinances of the city. 
(Code 1978, § 600.200) 
Sec. 3-57. - Licensing of manufacturers and wholesalers. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to manufacture or sell or offer for sale at wholesale any intoxicating liquor without a license therefor issued by the city. 
(b)  No such license shall be issued until the appropriate fee indicated below has been paid to the city: 
(1)  For a license to manufacture, distill, or blend intoxicating liquor, two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00). 
(2)  For a license for the sale of intoxicating liquor by a wholesale liquor dealer, or a wholesale liquor dealing agent, if the intoxicating liquor contains not in excess of five (5) percent alcohol by weight, seventy-five dollars ($75.00). 
(3)  For a license to handle intoxicating liquor containing not in excess of twenty-two (22) percent alcohol by weight, two hundred dollars ($200.00). 
(4)  For a license to handle intoxicating liquors of all kinds, five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(c)  Licenses issued pursuant to this section expire at the end of the calendar year for which they are issued. 
(Code 1978, §§ 610.010, 610.020) 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to license manufacture, etc., of intoxicating liquor, RSMo 311.220. 
Sec. 3-58. - Possession of illegal liquor. 
    No person shall possess intoxicating liquor within the city unless the same has been acquired from some person holding a duly authorized license to sell the same under this article. 
(Code 1978, § 600.090) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 311.580. 
Sec. 3-59. - Drinking in public. 
    No person shall drink intoxicating liquors, in any quantity, upon any street, alley or sidewalk within the city. 
(Code 1978, § 240.340; Ord. No. 6142, § 7(2), 9-13-88) 
Cross reference- Public possession of alcoholic beverages, § 3-3. 
Sec. 3-60. - Mixing liquor with drugs. 
    No person shall mix or permit or cause to be mixed with any intoxicating liquor kept for sale, sold or supplied by him as a beverage any drug or form of methyl alcohol or impure form of alcohol. 
(Code 1978, § 600.070) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 311.340. 
Sec. 3-61. - Hours of sale. 
(a)  No person licensed under this article, nor any employee of such person, shall sell, give away, or otherwise dispose of, or suffer the same to be done upon or about his premises, any intoxicating liquor in any quantity between the hours of 1:30 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. on weekdays and between the hours of 1:30 a.m. Sunday and 6:00 a.m. Monday. If the person has a license to sell intoxicating liquor by the drink, his premises shall be and remain a closed place as defined in this section between the hours of 1:30 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. on weekdays and between the hours of 1:30 a.m. Sunday and 6:00 a.m. Monday. Where licenses authorizing the sale of intoxicating liquor by the drink are held by clubs or hotels, this section shall apply only to the room or rooms in which intoxicating liquor is dispensed; and where such licenses are held by restaurants whose business is conducted in one (1) room only and substantial quantities of food and merchandise other than intoxicating liquors are dispensed, then the licensee shall keep securely locked during the hours and on the days specified in this section all refrigerators, cabinets, cases, boxes, and taps from which intoxicating liquor is dispensed. 
(b)  In this section, "closed place" means a place where all doors are locked and where no patrons are in the place or about the premises. 
(c)  Nothing in this section shall be construed to prohibit the sale or delivery of any intoxicating liquor during any of the hours or on any of the days specified in this section by a licensed wholesaler to a person licensed to sell the intoxicating liquor at retail. 
(d)  When January first, March seventeenth, July fourth, or December thirty-first falls on Sunday, and on the Sundays prior to Memorial Day and Labor Day and on the Sunday on which the national championship game of the national football league is played, commonly known as "Super Bowl Sunday", any person having a license to sell intoxicating liquor by the drink under this chapter may be open for business and sell intoxicating liquor by the drink under the provisions of his license on that day after 6:00 a.m. until 1:30 a.m. the following day. 
(e)  Nothing stated above shall prevent any person holding a valid license for the sale of intoxicating liquor in the original package or for retail sale of liquor by the drink on Sunday from selling said products on Sundays between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 12:00 midnight. 
(Code 1978, § 600.110, 600.120; Ord. No. 6126, § I, 4-12-88; Ord. No. 6220, § 1, 12-12-89; Ord. No. 6504, § 2, 7-13-93; Ord. No. 01-20, § I, 3-13-2001; Ord. No. 10-37, §§ I, II, 10-26-10) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 311.290, RSMo 311.298 
Sec. 3-62. - Window displays. 
    It shall be unlawful to display in any street window or show window within the city any intoxicating liquor, or any package, bottle, or container bearing the label or brand of any intoxicating liquor. 
(Code 1978, § 600.130) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 311.350. 
Sec. 3-63. - Sale to minors. 
(a)  Any licensee under this article or his employee, who shall sell, vend, give away or otherwise supply any intoxicating liquor in any quantity whatsoever to any person under the age of twenty-one (21) years, or to any person intoxicated or appearing to be in a state of intoxication, or to a habitual drunkard, and any person whomsoever except his parent or guardian who shall procure for, sell, give away or otherwise supply intoxicating liquor to any person under the age of twenty-one (21) years, or to any intoxicated person or any person appearing to be in a state of intoxication, or to a habitual drunkard, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(b)  Subsection (a) does not apply to the supplying of intoxicating liquor to a person under the age of twenty-one (21) years for medical purposes only, or to the administering of intoxicating liquor to any person by a duly licensed physician. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 311.310. 
Sec. 3-64. - Sale by the drink. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to sell intoxicating liquor except as specifically authorized by this chapter or in the "Liquor Control Law" of the State of Missouri set forth in RSMo chapter 311. 
(Code 1978, § 600.150; Ord. No. 01-17, § I, 3-13-2001) 
State Law reference- Sale by the drink, RSMo 311.090 et seq. 
Sec. 3-65. - Opening packages on licensed premises. 
    An original package of intoxicating liquor shall not be opened by any person on the premises of an establishment holding a retail license to sell intoxicating liquor unless the license authorizes the consumption of intoxicating liquor in the licensed premises. 
(Code 1978, § 600.020) 
Sec. 3-66. - Prohibited interests in certain retailers. 
    No person or corporation holding a retail intoxicating liquor license nor any employee, officer, agent, subsidiary or affiliate thereof, shall, directly or indirectly, be interested in any business of any other person or corporation, or of any employee, officer, agent, subsidiary, or affiliate thereof, who is licensed to sell malt liquor at retail. 
(Code 1978, § 600.140) 
State Law reference- Restrictions on number of licenses, etc., RSMo 311.260. 
Sec. 3-67. - Notice to police by retail licensee of certain conditions. 
    Each retail license under this article or an employee of the licensee shall notify the police department of all conditions which would make the licensed premises not be an orderly place or house that they are unable to immediately cause to cease, and shall also notify immediately the police department of the occurrence of any assault or any other act of violence upon their premises. 
(Code 1978, § 600.080) 
Sec. 3-68. - Temporary permit for sale by drink may be issued to certain organizations. 
(a)  Notwithstanding any other provision of this chapter, a permit for the sale of all kinds of intoxicating liquor, including intoxicating liquor in the original package, at retail by the drink for consumption on the premises of the licensee may be issued to any church, school, civic, service, fraternal, veteran, political, or charitable club or organization for the sale of such intoxicating liquor at a picnic, bazaar, fair, or similar gathering. The permit shall be issued only for the day or days named therein and it shall not authorize the sale of intoxicating liquor for more than seven (7) days by any such club or organization. 
(b)  The applicant shall pay a fee of thirty-seven dollars and fifty cents ($37.50) for such permit. 
(c)  If the event will be held on a Sunday, the permit shall authorize the sale of intoxicating liquor on that day beginning at 11:00 a.m. 
(d)  No provision of law or rule or regulation of the city shall be interpreted as preventing any wholesaler or distributor from providing customary storage, cooling or dispensing equipment for use by the permit holder at such picnic, bazaar, fair or similar gathering. 
(e)  A distiller, wholesaler, winemaker, or brewer may give a gift not to exceed a value of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per year to a holder of a temporary permit as defined in section. 
(Ord. No. 18-15, § I, 5-8-2018) 
State Law reference- RSMo 311.482 and RSMo 311.070.4 
Secs. 3-69-3-79. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - RETAIL LICENSE[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to require license, RSMo 311.260. 

Sec. 3-80. - Required. 
    No person shall sell intoxicating liquor at retail in the city without a license issued by the city. A separate license is required for each place of business. 
(Code 1978, § 600.060) 
Sec. 3-81. - Application and issuance. 
(a)  All persons desiring to obtain licenses required by this division shall make verified written application for the same, which application shall be submitted to the city. Upon receipt of such written application, the same shall be referred to the mayor for approval. If the mayor is satisfied that the facts contained in the application are true and correct, and that the license should properly be issued, he shall approve the application, and the city shall issue the license upon the conditions herein provided, Should the mayor, for good cause, believe that the license should not be issued to the applicant, he shall refuse to give his approval to the application. If the applicant shall feel himself grieved by the action of the mayor, he may make application to the city council, at its next regular meeting, for the granting of such license. Upon such appeal to the council the mayor shall give to the council, in writing, his reasons for refusing to approve the application. The council shall then set a certain day to hear the matter, at which time all interested parties may appear and be heard, and if a majority of all the members of the council shall vote, after hearing all of the evidence and arguments, to issue the license, then the license shall be issued. In all cases of this nature, the proceedings of the council shall be spread upon its journal. 
(b)  Upon the approval of the application, the payment of the license fee, and the compliance with the requirements hereof, the city shall grant to the applicant a license to conduct an intoxicating liquor business in this city. 
(Code 1978, §§ 600.030, 600.060) 
Sec. 3-82. - Fee. 
    Prior to the issuance or renewal of a license under this division the appropriate annual fee listed below shall be paid to the city: 
(1)  For a retail license to sell intoxicating liquor in the original package, seventy-five dollars ($75.00). 
(2)  For a retail license to sell malt liquor by the drink for consumption on the premises, fifty-two dollars and fifty cents ($52.50). 
(3)  For a retail license to sell malt liquor in the original package, twenty-two dollars and fifty cents ($22.50). 
(4)  For a retail license to sell intoxicating liquors in the original package on Sundays, three hundred dollars ($300.00). 
(5)  For a retail license to sell intoxicating liquor by the drink Monday through Saturday for a "restaurant bar" as defined by RSMo. section 311.097 or for a "resort" as defined by RSMo. section 311.095, seventy-five dollars ($75.00); 
(6)  For a retail license to sell intoxicating liquor by the drink on Sundays for a "restaurant bar" as defined by RSMo. section 311.097 or for a "resort" as defined by RSMo. section 311.095, three hundred dollars ($300.00). 
(Code 1978, §§ 600.020, 600.050; Ord. No. 6504, § 1, 7-13-93; Ord. No. 01-19, § I, 3-13-2001) 
Sec. 3-83. - Persons and premises eligible. 
(a)  No person shall be granted a license to sell intoxicating liquor unless such person is of good moral character nor shall any corporation be granted a license unless the managing officer of such corporation is of good moral character. No person shall be granted a license hereunder if a license has previously been revoked, or if the person has been convicted since the ratification of the twenty-first amendment to the Constitution of the United States, of a violation of the provisions of any law applicable to the manufacture or sale of intoxicating liquor.
