Beginning at the center of Oak Street where it meets the west city limits; thence east down the center of Oak Street to the center of Florence Street; Thence South down the center of Florence Street to the center of Walnut Street; Thence East down the center of Walnut Street to the center of Center Street; Thence South down the center of Center Street to the center of Chestnut Street; Thence East down the center of Chestnut Street to the center of Case Street; Thence South down the center of Case Street to the center of Cedar Street; Thence East down the center of Cedar Street to the center of Garrison Street; Thence North down the center of Garrison Street to the center of Chestnut Street; Thence East down the center of Chestnut Street to the center of Main Street; Thence North down the center of Main Street to the center of Central Avenue; Thence East down the center of Central Ave to the center of Clinton Street; Thence South down the center of Clinton Street to the center of 2nd Street; Thence East down the center of 2nd Street to the center of Fulton Street; Thence South down the center of Fulton Street to the center of 3rd Street; Thence East down the center of 3rd Street to the center of Orchard Street; Thence North down the center of Orchard Street to the center of 2nd Street; Thence East down the center of 2nd Street to the center of Bois D Arc Street; Thence South down the center of Bois D Arc Street; to the center of 3rd Street; Thence East down the center of 3rd Street to the center of River Street; Thence North down the center of River Street to the center of the Rail Road Crossing River Street North of Central Ave; Thence East down the center of the rail road tracks to the East City limit line. The western, northern and eastern boundaries of the second ward shall be the city limits. 
(3)  Third Ward. Beginning in the center of Baker Boulevard where it intersects the west city limit line north of 16th Street South of Fred Hatfield Circle; Thence North down the center of Baker Boulevard to the center of Centennial Avenue; Thence East down the center of Centennial Avenue to the center of the Rail Road Tracks intersecting Centennial Avenue East of Sophia Street West of Case Street; Thence Northeast down the center of the Rail Road Tracks to the center of Macon Street; Thence East down the center of Macon Street to the center of Grand Avenue; Thence North down the center of Grand Avenue to the center of 11th Street; Thence West down the center of 11th Street to the center of Main Street; Thence North down the center of Main Street to the center of Chestnut Street; Thence West down the center of Chestnut Street to the center of Garrison Avenue; Thence South down the center of Garrison Avenue to the center of Cedar Street; Thence West down the center of Cedar Street to the center of Case Street; Thence North down the center of Case Street to the center of Chestnut Street; Thence West down the center of Chestnut Street to the center of Center Street; Thence North down the center of Center Street to the center of Walnut Street; Thence West down the center of Walnut Street to the center of Florence Street; Thence North down the center of Florence Street to the center of Oak Street; Thence West down the center of Oak Street to the west city limit line. Thence south following the West City limit line back to the point of beginning. 
(4)  Fourth Ward. The Northern boundary of the Fourth Ward beginning at the south west corner of the first ward at the center of the intersection of Grand Avenue and Centennial Avenue; Thence East down the center of Centennial Ave. to the center of Clinton Street; Thence North down the center of Clinton Street to the center of 15th Street; Thence East down the center of 15th Street to the center of Fulton Street; Thence North down the center of Fulton Street to the center of 13th Street; Thence East down the center of 13th Street to the center of Glenwood Place; Thence south down the center of Glenwood Place to the center of Centennial Avenue; Thence East down the center of Centennial Ave to Buena Vista Ave and continuing due East to the Eastern city limit line. The Western Boundary beginning at the center of the intersection of Grand Avenue and Centennial Avenue; Thence South down the center of Grand Avenue to the south city limit line intersecting Grand Avenue. The southern and eastern boundary of the fourth ward shall be the city limit line. 
(5)  Fifth Ward. All of the land within the city limits that lays south and west of this line Beginning in the center of Baker Boulevard where Baker Boulevard intersects the west city limit line north of 16th Street South of Fred Hatfield Circle; Thence North down the center of Baker Boulevard to the center of Centennial Avenue; Thence East down the center of Centennial Avenue to the center of the Rail Road Tracks intersecting Centennial Avenue East of Sophia Street West of Case Street; Thence Northeast down the center of the Rail Road Tracks to the center of Macon Street; Thence East down the center of Macon Street to the center of Grand Avenue; Thence south down the center of Grand Avenue to the intersection of the southern city limit line. The west and south boundary of the fifth ward shall be the western and southern city limit line. 
(Code 1978, § 151.010; Ord. No. 6364, § 1, 10-22-91; Ord. No. 01-99, § I, 11-27-01; Ord. No. 03-22, § I, 4-8-03; Ord. No. 03-26, § I, 5-13-03; Ord. No. 11-42, § I, 10-25-11) 
State Law reference- Wards required, RSMo 77.030. 
Sec. 9-3. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 11-42, § II, adopted Oct. 25, 2011, repealed § 9-3 which pertained to precincts and derived from § 151.020 of the 1978 Code; and Ord. No. 01-100, § I, adopted Nov. 27, 2001. 
Sec. 9-4. - Number of councilmen per ward. 
    Each ward shall be entitled to two (2) representatives on the city council elected in the manner provided by law and the ordinances of the city. 
(Code 1978, § 151.030) 
State Law reference- Establishment of precincts, RSMo 115.113. 
Sec. 9-5. - Candidates for office; filing. 
(a)  All elections held for offices of the city shall be held without designation of party affiliation. 
(b)  Those persons wishing to be candidate for office in the city, in the general municipal election held on the first Tuesday of April of each year shall file their declaration of candidacy with the city clerk, on forms to be supplied by the city clerk, no sooner than the thirteenth Tuesday prior to the city general election nor later than the ninth Tuesday prior to the city general election. 
(c)  Each declaration of candidacy filed with the city clerk shall be accompanied by the payment of the fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) to the city or by submitting to the city clerk the signatures of twenty-five (25) registered voters nominating the candidate who are residents of the district in which the candidate is running. 
(d)  The closing filing date for any office in the city shall be 5:00 p.m., the eleventh Tuesday prior to the election. The city shall, before the sixteenth Tuesday prior to any election at which offices are to be filled, notify the general public of the opening filing date, the office or offices to be filled, the proper place for filing and the closing filing date of the election. Such notification may be accomplished by legal notice published in at least one newspaper of general circulation in the political subdivision or special district. 
(Ord. No. 6329, § 1, 5-28-91; Ord. No. 6416, § 2, 5-12-92; Ord. No. 03-70, § I, 12-9-03) 
Sec. 9-6. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. 6416, adopted May 12, 1992, repealed former § 9-6, which pertained to the establishment of primary elections and derived from Ord. No. 6329, adopted May 28, 1991. 
Sec. 9-7. - General election date; officers to be elected. 
(a)  On the first Tuesday in April of each year there shall be a general election by the qualified voters of the city for the election of one (1) councilman from each ward of the city, who shall hold his office for a term of two (2) years. 
(b)  At the general election held on the first Tuesday in April, every four (4) years, there shall be elected by the qualified voters of the city, a mayor, who shall hold his office for a term of four (4) years. 
(Code 1978, §§ 151.040, 151.050; Ord. No. 6011, § I, 12-10-85; Ord. No. 6012, § I, 12-10-85; Ord. No. 01-48, § I, 5-8-01) 
Editor's note- Section 3 of Ord. No. 6329, adopted May 28, 1991, renumbered § 9-5 as § 9-7 to allow for the inclusion of §§ 9-5 and 9-6. 
Cross reference- Qualifications, appointments and compensation, § 2-143; selection of judge, § 14-2. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 77.030, 77.370. 
Chapter 10 - FIRE PREVENTION AND PROTECTION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Fires in streets, § 21-8; gasoline trucks on public square, § 23-174; following fire apparatus prohibited, § 23-175; crossing fire hose, § 23-176; parking of gasoline trucks, § 23-426. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 10-1. - Fire prevention code adopted. 
(a)  The provisions, except as modified in this article, of the 2006 International Fire Code including Appendices A-D, three (3) copies of which are on file in the office of the city clerk, are hereby incorporated in this chapter and made a part hereof as though set forth fully herein and are hereby adopted as the official fire code of the city. 
(b)  Wherever the word "municipality" is used in the code adopted by this article, it shall be construed to mean this city. 
(c)  The fire prevention code adopted by this article shall be administered and enforced by the fire chief. 
(d)  General penalty. 
(1)  Whenever in the code adopted in this section, or in any rule, regulation, notice or order promulgated by any officer or agency of the city under authority duly vested in him/her or it by said code, any act is prohibited or is declared to be unlawful or an offense or misdemeanor or the doing of any act is required or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful or an offense or a misdemeanor, upon conviction of a violation of any such provision of the code adopted herein or of any such ordinance, rule, regulation, notice or order, the violator shall be punished by a fine not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00) or by imprisonment in the city or county jail not exceeding ninety (90) days or by both such fine and imprisonment; provided, that in any case wherein the penalty for an offense is fixed by a statute of the state, the statutory penalty, and no other, shall be imposed for such offense, except that imprisonments may be in the city prison or workhouse instead of the county jail. 
(2)  Every day any violation of the code adopted herein or any other ordinance or any such rule, regulation, notice or order shall continue shall constitute a separate offense. 
(3)  Whenever any act is prohibited by the code adopted herein, by an amendment thereof, or by any rule or regulation adopted thereunder, such prohibition shall extend to and include the causing, securing, aiding, or abetting of another person to do said act. Whenever any act is prohibited by this code, an attempt to do the act is likewise prohibited. 
(e)  Section 307.1-307.5 of the Fire Prevention Code are stricken. 
(Code 1978, § 510.010; Ord. No. 6120, § I, 3-8-88; Ord. No. 98-16, §§ I-III, 3-10-98; Ord. No. 12-33, § II, 8-14-2012; Ord. No. 14-05, § I, 2-11-2014) 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, Ch. 6. 
State Law reference- Adoption by reference, RSMo 67.280. 
Sec. 10-2. - Open burning. 
(a)  Regulations . 
(1)  Open burning of yard waste is allowed provided it originates and is burned on the same premises and unless a permit by the Missouri Department of Natural Resources is issued which supersedes these regulations. 
(2)  Yard waste must consist of tree limbs, leaves, brush, or untreated and unpainted wood wastes. 
(3)  Open burning is permitted from 7:00 a.m. to 10:00 p.m. 
(4)  The fire department must be notified prior to any burning. 
(5)  Fires in approved containers may be no less than fifteen (15) feet from any structure. 
(6)  Fires not in containers must be no less than twenty-five (25) feet from any structure. 
(7)  Fire materials to be burned, not in containers, must be no larger than three (3) feet in diameter and two (2) feet high. 
(8)  Fires not in containers larger than the designated size must be no less than fifty (50) feet from any structure and require approval from the fire department. 
(9)  Fires must be constantly attended until the fire is extinguished. 
(10)  A fire extinguisher with a minimum 4-S rating, charged water hose, or other approve extinguishing equipment must be available for immediate utilization. 
(11)  Fires may not be burned on any improved street, sidewalk, or alley. 
(12)  Fires may not cause a hazardous condition of any kind. 
(13)  Fires may not be burned during the time that a burn ban is issued. 
(b)  Fire department personnel have the authority to order the extinguishment of any fire not within regulations. 
(Code 1978, § 240.120; Ord. No. 14-05, § II, 2-11-2014) 
Sec. 10-3. - Fireworks. 
(a)  No person, shall shoot, set off, explode or discharge any blank cartridge, torpedo, cane torpedo, firecracker, or any substance containing chlorate of potash and sulphur, or device for exploding or discharging such substances, or any other fireworks. Provided, however, that fireworks displays, to be conducted by persons who make a profession of holding fireworks displays, may be held after having first obtained written permission from the fire chief. Blank cartridges may be discharged within the city limits at any time when used in conjunction with organized athletic events. 
(b)  Persons may sell fireworks in the city limits during the time as authorized by state statute. So long as they comply with all federal, state and local law concerning the sale of fireworks. 
(Code 1978, § 240.250; Ord. No. 02-50, § I, 7-9-2002; Ord. No. 08-56, § I, 11-25-2008) 
State Law reference- Fireworks, RSMo 320.121. 
Sec. 10-4. - Exceptions. 
    The following shall be exceptions to section 10-3: 
(1)  December 31st from 5:00 p.m. to January 1st at 1:00 a.m. 
(2)  June 30th to July 3rd from 9:00 a.m. until 11:00 p.m. each evening. 
(3)  July 4th until July 5th from 9:00 a.m. until 1:00 a.m. 
(4)  July 5th from 9:00 a.m. until 11:00 p.m. 
(5)  Nothing in this section shall allow the discharge of any firework in the municipal park at any time. 
(6)  The fire chief shall have sole discretion of suspending section 10-4 of the City Code in times of high fire risk or drought. 
(Ord. No. 10-14, § I, 6-8-2010) 
Secs. 10-5-10-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - FIRE DEPARTMENT[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Officers and employees generally, § 2-101 et seq.; offenses against government and administration of justice, § 13-201 et seq.; authority of fire department officials to direct traffic, § 23-26. 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to provide for fire department, RSMo 77.190. 

Sec. 10-21. - Created. 
    There is created a fire department. 
(Code 1978, § 205.010) 
Sec. 10-22. - Office of fire chief created. 
    There is created the office of fire chief. The fire chief shall be appointed by the mayor with the consent of the majority of the members elected to the city council. The fire chief may be removed from office by the mayor with the consent of a majority of all the members elected to the city council. The fire chief may be removed from office by a two-thirds vote of all members elected to the council, independent of the mayor's approval or recommendation. 
(Ord. No. 6692, § 1, 1-10-95) 
Sec. 10-23. - Supervision and control. 
    The supervision, custody, maintenance and control of the fire department shall be under the direct control of the mayor and council of the city. The fire chief and the council of the city shall adopt and promulgate rules and regulations for the conduct of the fire department, including the hours of duty of firemen. The salary or wages of any fireman shall cease upon the date of his removal, suspension or discharge. 
(Code 1978, §§ 205.010, 205.020, 205.080; Ord. No. 6274, § 1, 9-25-90; Ord. No. 6692, § 2, 1-10-95) 
Secs. 10-24, 10-25. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Former §§ 10-24 and 10-25 were repealed by §§ 3 and 4 of Ord. No. 6274, adopted Sept. 25, 1990. The repealed provisions pertained to pension plan, insurance, etc. for the fire department employees and to records of all members of the fire department, and derived from Code 1978, §§ 205.040, and 205.130-205.150. 
Sec. 10-26. - Qualifications of employees. 
(a)  No member of the city fire department shall serve as a firefighter (full-time or part-time) until he or she has reached their twenty-first (21st) birthday and is a citizen of the United States. No person shall continue to serve as a firefighter after his sixty-fifth (65th) birthday. No person shall serve as a firefighter with the city fire department unless he/she possess and maintains a telephone (landline or cell) and resides within a fifteen (15) mile radius of the Fire Station located at 401 W. Chestnut in the City of Carthage. Any employee assigned a city owned emergency response type vehicle shall reside within the city limits or the designated boundaries of the city fire protection district. 
(b)  The term "resides/residence" as used in this section, shall be defined as the true, fixed and permanent home and principal establishment, and to which whenever he/she is absent he/she has the intention of returning. 
(c)  Applicants/current employees. Applicants or current employees who do not conform to the residency requirements established by this section, shall establish residence within the boundaries specified in this section within nine (9) months after the date of appointment for new hires or effective date of the ordinance from which this section is derived for current employees. In the discretion of the city administrator, person who, at the time the nine (9) months expires, have entered into a contract to purchase a residence for their use and who are prepared to move in within a reasonable time not to exceed six (6) months may be deemed to have met this requirement. 
(Code 1978, § 205.060; Ord. No. 10-39, § I, 11-9-2010; Ord. No. 11-07, § I, 2-8-2011; Ord. No. 18-08, § I, 2-27-2018) 
Sec. 10-27. - Effect of promotion upon compensation. 
    In no event shall a promotion in rank in the fire department result in a decrease in pay. If the beginning pay scale of the higher rank is less than the present pay scale of the person who is promoted, then that person who is promoted shall continue to draw the same rate of pay until such time as his time in grade in the rank in which he is promoted equals or is greater than the pay he is drawing. 
Sec. 10-28. - Fire chief. 
(a)  The fire chief shall be responsible for the discipline, good order and conduct of the fire department, the enforcement of all laws, ordinances and regulations pertaining thereto, and for the care and condition of fire department property. He shall command and control all members of the department and all departmental property and other houses used for that purpose, and of all engines and fire apparatus belonging to the city. He shall have control of all persons present at fires. 
(b)  The fire chief shall wear a proper badge of office. When a fire breaks out, he shall take immediate and proper measures for its extinguishment. He shall have the right to remove personal property from any building on fire or in danger thereof, and to guard the same. Any person refusing to obey the commands of the chief while present at a fire shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(c)  The chief shall have power to order the cutting down and removing of any building, erection, fence or other thing, if he shall deem it necessary for the purpose of checking a fire in its progress. In case of absence of the chief from any fire, the assistant chief shall, for the time, have all the powers of the chief and perform the duties of that office. The chief may prescribe limits in the vicinity of a fire, within which no person, excepting those who reside therein, members of the fire or police departments, and those admitted by order of the chief or his assistant shall be permitted to come. 
(Code 1978, § 205.070) 
Sec. 10-29. - Intoxicating liquor, etc. 
    No spirituous, fermented or malt liquors shall be permitted in any building used by the fire department. Any member of the fire department found to be in violation of this section shall be subject to being discharged. 
(Code 1978, § 205.100; Ord. No. 6571, § 1, 2-22-94) 
Sec. 10-30. - Employees required to pay debts; no political or religious discrimination; participation in elections. 
    Any officer or member of the fire department neglecting or refusing to pay a just debt shall be discharged from the service of the city. No officer or member of the department shall be employed or discharged on account of his religious or political views. Except to exercise the right to vote, no member of the fire department shall participate in an election. 
(Code 1978, §§ 205.090, 205.110) 
Sec. 10-31. - Loitering. 
    Persons who are not members of the fire or police department shall not meet or loiter around the buildings used by the fire department. Members of the fire department on duty who permit violations of this section are subject to dismissal. 
(Code 1978, § 205.120) 
Chapter 11 - HUMAN RIGHTS[1] 
Footnotes:

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL

ARTICLE II. - FAIR HOUSING[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Discriminatory housing practices, RSMo 213.100 et seq. 

Sec. 11-16. - Policy. 
    It is the policy of the city to provide, within constitutional limitations, for fair housing throughout the city. 
(Code 1976, § 290.010) 
Sec. 11-17. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meaning ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Discriminatory housing practice means an act that is unlawful under sections 11-21, 11-22, and 11-23. 
    Dwelling means any building, structure, or portion thereof which is occupied as, or designed or intended for occupancy as, a residence by one (1) or more families, and any vacant land which is offered for sale or lease for the construction or location thereon of any such building, structure or portion thereof. 
    Family includes a single individual. 
    Handicap means a physical or mental impairment resulting in a disability unrelated to a person's ability to acquire, rent or maintain property. 
    To rent includes to lease, to sublease, to let and otherwise to grant for a consideration the right to occupy premises not owned by the occupant. 
(Code 1976, § 290.020) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 213.100. 
Sec. 11-18. - Enforcement by private persons. 
    The rights granted by sections 11-21, 11-22 and 11-23 may be enforced by civil actions to enjoin the violation in the circuit court of the county. Any such civil action shall be commenced within one hundred and eighty (180) days after the alleged discriminatory housing practice occurred. The city attorney, on behalf of the city, may intervene as a part plaintiff. 
(Code 1978, § 290.100) 
Sec. 11-19. - Enforcement by city attorney. 
(a)  Whenever the city attorney has reasonable cause to believe that any person is engaged in a pattern or practice of resistance to the full enjoyment of any of the rights granted by this article, or that any group of persons has been denied any of the rights granted by this article and such denial raises an issue of general public importance, he may bring a civil action in the circuit court of the county, by filing with it a complaint setting forth the facts and requesting such preventive relief, including an application for a permanent or temporary injunction, restraining order, or other order against the person or persons responsible for such pattern or practice or denial of rights, as he deems necessary to ensure the full enjoyment of the rights granted by this article. 
(b)  If it appears that a complainant is in danger of suffering irreparable injury, or if it appears that some action is about to be taken which will jeopardize the complainant's interest in the subject property, the city attorney shall file an injunction in the circuit court of the county to prevent the continued violation of this article or to prevent the parties from acting in such a manner as to frustrate the intent and purpose of this article upon a showing that the complainant would suffer irreparable harm without such action. 
(c)  Upon a conviction in the municipal court for a violation of sections 11-21, 11-22 or 11-23, in addition to any other penalties which may have been imposed, the license of such person to engage in the real estate business in this city may be suspended for a period not to exceed thirty (30) days, for the first conviction, and may be suspended for a period not to exceed six (6) months or revoked upon the second conviction. 
(Code 1978, § 290.110(C)-(E)) 
Sec. 11-20. - Interference, coercion or intimidation. 
    It shall be unlawful to coerce, intimidate, threaten or interfere with any person in the exercise or enjoyment of, or on account of his having exercised or enjoyed, or on account of his having aided or encouraged any other person in the exercise or enjoyment of any right granted or protected by the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1978, § 290.130) 
Sec. 11-21. - Discrimination in sale or rental of housing. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person: 
(1)  To refuse to sell or rent after the making of a bona fide offer, or to refuse to negotiate for the sale or rental of, or otherwise make unavailable or deny, a dwelling to any person because of race, color, religion, national origin, sex, or handicap. If other bona fide offers to rent or buy have been made, the owner, lessor or his agent may accept such offers without violating this paragraph. 
(2)  To discriminate against any person in the terms, conditions or privileges of sale or rental of a dwelling, or in the provision of services or facilities in connection therewith, because of race, color, religion, national origin, sex or handicap. 
(3)  To make, print, or publish, or cause to be made, printed or published, any notice, statement or advertisement with respect to the sale or rental of a dwelling that indicates any preference, limitation or discrimination based on race, color, religion, sex, national origin or handicap, or an intention to make any such preference, limitation or discrimination. 
(4)  To represent to any person, because of race, creed, color, religion, national origin, sex, handicap or ancestry that any dwelling is in fact so available. 
(5)  For profit, to induce or attempt to induce any person to sell or rent any dwelling by representations regarding the entry or prospective entry into the neighborhood of a person or persons of a particular race, color, religion, national origin, sex or handicap. 
(Code 1976, § 290.040) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 213.105. 
Sec. 11-22. - Discrimination in financing of housing. 
    It shall be unlawful for any bank, savings and loan association, insurance company or other corporation, association, firm or enterprise whose business consists in whole or in part in the making of commercial real estate loans, to deny a loan or other financial assistance to a person applying therefor for the purpose of purchasing, constructing, improving, repairing or maintaining a dwelling, or to discriminate against him in the fixing of the amount, interest rate, duration or other terms or conditions of such loan or other financial assistance because of the race, creed, sex, color, religion, national origin, ancestry or handicap of such person or of any person associated with him in connection with such loan or other financial assistance, or of the present or prospective owners, lessees, tenants or occupants of the dwellings, in relation to which such loan or other financial assistance is to be made or given. 
(Code 1978, § 290.050) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 213.110. 
Sec. 11-23. - Discrimination in brokerage services. 
    It shall be unlawful to deny any person access to or membership or participation in any multiple-listing service, real estate broker's organization or other service, organization or facility relating to the business of selling or renting dwellings, or to discriminate against him in terms or conditions of such access membership or participation, on account of race, creed, color, religion, national origin, ancestry, sex or handicap. 
(Code 1978, § 290.060) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 213.115. 
Chapter 12 - LICENSES, TAXATION AND MISCELLANEOUS BUSINESS REGULATIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Alcoholic beverages, Ch. 3; licensing of dogs and kennels, § 4-6; cablevision, Ch. 7; sales from parked vehicles, § 23-415. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 12-1. - Fortunetelling prohibited. 
    No person shall engage in the business of being a fortuneteller or palmist within the city. 
(Ord. No. 6001, § I(615.090), 10-8-85) 
Sec. 12-2. - Auto salvage yards. 
(a)  In this section "auto salvage yard" means a place of business where: 
(1)  Motor vehicles are kept or stored for the purpose of dismantling them or selling them for scrap; 
(2)  Property made of metal is stored or kept for the purpose of recycling or selling it for scrap. 
(b)  "Auto salvage yard" does not include: 
(1)  A place of business where metal products that are the by-product of the business or industry located on such premises are kept or stored; or 
(2)  A recycling center in which all metals are stored in containers or kept within buildings. 
(c)  No person shall operate an auto salvage yard within the city. 
(Code 1978, §§ 635.010, 635.020) 
Sec. 12-3. - Going-out-of-business sales. 
    No person shall hold a "going-out-of-business sale" within the city for a period in excess of ninety (90) days. No person shall advertise a "going-out-of-business sale" unless in fact the business is to be terminated. 
(Code 1978, § 640.090) 
Secs. 12-4-12-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - LICENSES GENERALLY[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- General licensing authority, RSMo 94.110. 

Sec. 12-26. - License required; payment of taxes as prerequisite. 
(a)  The various objects, subjects, persons, trades, vocations, avocations and occupations hereinafter mentioned and carried on within the limits of the city shall be licensed, taxed and regulated as hereinafter provided. No city manufacturer's, merchant's, or occupation license shall be issued unless all city taxes on the property in question have been paid. No city occupation or business license shall be issued to any hotel, motel or bed and breakfast which is more than thirty (30) days in arrears in the payment of lodging taxes due to the city; additionally, the city clerk's office shall revoke the occupation or business license of any hotel, motel or bed and breakfast which is more than thirty (30) days in arrears in the payment of lodging taxes to the city. 
(b)  Any person who or which shall engage in, or carry on, any trade, business, occupation, calling, vocation or avocation in the city required by this article to be licensed, without first having obtained and paid for such license shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1978, §§ 615.010, 615.070; Ord. No. 6530, § 1, 10-12-93; Ord. No. 02-06, § I, 2-12-2002) 
Sec. 12-26.1. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section I of Ord. No. 98-69, adopted Oct. 13, 1998, repealed § 12-26.1 in its entirety. Formerly, § 12-26.1 pertained to evidence of workers' compensation insurance prior to license issuance and derived from § 1 of Ord. No. 6609, adopted May 24, 1994. 
Sec. 12-27. - License fee; term of license. 
    All licenses shall be payable in advance and shall be issued by the city for a period of six (6) months or one (1) year, unless otherwise provided herein, and shall expire on the last day of December of the year for which they are issued. The amount collected for any license for a shorter period of time than one (1) year shall be in the same proportion to the rate fixed for one (1) year as the length of time for which such license is issued bears to one (1) year, a major part of a month counting as a whole month for the purpose of this computation. Where any license fee is made payable in advance, no license shall be issued for less period than a year. And provided further, that all licenses issued under this article shall expire on the last day of December of the year for which they are issued, regardless of what month in that year they may be issued. 
(Code 1978, § 615.020) 
Sec. 12-28. - License fee due date; penalty for late payment. 
(a)  All licenses required by this article shall be due and payable on January 1 of each year, or where license has been issued for a term of six (6) months. A grace period of forty-five (45) days shall be allowed after the due date before any license shall become delinquent. 
(b)  To any license which is not issued before the delinquent date, a penalty of one (1) percent per month shall be added to the cost thereof with the maximum penalty being ten (10) percent. In addition, interest shall accrue on all late fees at a rate of one (1) percent. For the purpose of computing the amount of the penalty provided by this section, the delinquency shall be dated back to the date the license became due and payable, and the penalty shall be assessed for each full month of the delinquency, only full months being counted. Where a license is delinquent from the first of the year, the penalty shall be computed on the basis of the amount due for the full year. Where the delinquency occurs on licenses due during the last six (6) months of the year, the penalty shall be computed on the basis of the balance due thereon. 
(c)  Any business that receives a license pursuant to chapter 12 is required to only pay fifty dollars ($50.00) for a city occupation license and is in violation of subsection (a) of this section shall have a late fee of fifty cents ($.50) per month. 
(d)  Any business that operates without a business license shall be assessed the following fine: first offense, seventy-five dollars ($75.00) plus court cost; second offense, one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) plus court cost; third and subsequent offense as determined by the court. The fine associated under subsection (d) shall be in addition to any other penalties and/or late fees. 
(Code 1978, § 615.050; Ord. No. 12-02, § I, 2-14-2012; Ord. No. 13-02, § I, 2-26-2013) 
Sec. 12-29. - Use of fees. 
    All license fees imposed by this article are for general revenue purposes. 
(Code 1978, § 615.060) 
Sec. 12-30. - Transfer of license. 
    All licenses issued under the provisions of this article shall be issued to the person making application for same, and no such license shall be transferable to any other person. 
(Code 1978, § 615.040) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 94.120. 
Sec. 12-31. - Posting of license. 
    Every person to whom a license shall be issued under the terms of this article shall keep the same conspicuously posted in this place of business. 
(Code 1978, § 615.030) 
Sec. 12-32. - License fee schedule. 
    Effective January 1, 1998, there is hereby established a restructuring of the city's occupational license fee on all businesses operating within the City of Carthage, wherein said businesses shall pay to the City of Carthage the following licenses based upon their annual taxable gross sales, to-wit: 
0 to $100,000.00\$50.00 
$100,001.00 to $300,000.00\100.00 
$300,001.00 to $500,000.00\200.00 
$500,001.00 to $1,000,000.00\400.00 
For each additional $1,000,000.00 in taxable gross sales the license fee shall increase by $100.00. 
Exceptions to this fee schedule are listed below: 
Manufacturing, per employee\$1.00 
Minimum license fee for manufacturing\50.00 
Retail license to sell intoxicating liquors in the original package on Sundays\300.00 
Adult entertainment establishments\300.00 
Franchise agreements entered into with the City of Carthage shall be licenses under separate provisions of the City Charter and Code of the City of Carthage. 
The tax on cigarette sales shall not be affected by the provisions of this section. 
Hotels, rooming houses, and bed and breakfasts shall pay fifty dollars ($50.00), plus any applicable city lodging tax. 
(Code 1978, §§ 220.050, 615.080, 620.040; Ord. No. 6656, § 1, 10-11-94; Ord. No. 96-84, § I, 12-23-96) 
State Law reference- Restrictions on licensing of certain professions, RSMo 71.620; restrictions on licensing of agriculture, RSMo 71.630. 
Sec. 12-33. - Conditions precedent. 
    No license provided under this chapter shall hereafter be issued by the city clerk to any person or entity until the proposed licensee produces a copy of a retail sales license issued by the State of Missouri, a statement from the department of revenue that the licensee owes no tax due under RSMo 144.010 through 144.510 or RSMo 143.191 through 143.261 and proof that any and all tax, utility or other obligations of the proposed licensee to the city for all preceding years lawfully due shall have been paid. 
(Ord. No. 09-01, § I, 1-13-2009) 
Secs. 12-34-12-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - AMUSEMENT ARCADES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to license, tax and regulate amusements, RSMo 94.110. 

Sec. 12-51. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Amusement device means any amusement machine or device operated for the purpose of amusement or skill and for the playing of which a fee is charged to include but not limited to video games and pool tables. 
    Amusement parlor means any establishment whose primary business is the offering of amusement devices for use to the public. 
    Proprietor means any person who as owner, lessee or proprietor, has under his control any establishment, place or premises, in or at which such coin-operated amusement device is placed or kept for use or play. 
(Code 1978, § 240.710(A); Ord. No. 6480, §§ 1, 2, 2-9-93) 
Sec. 12-52. - Hours of operation. 
    No amusement parlor shall operate between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 9:00 a.m., except that the amusement parlor may stay open until 1:00 a.m. on Saturday and Sunday. Any proprietor found guilty of violating this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1978, § 240.710(B), (C))

ARTICLE IV. - CIGARETTE TAX[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to levy license tax on tobacco dealers, RSMo 94.110. 

Sec. 12-66. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Carrier means any railroad, express company, trucking company, bus company or other public or private carrier transporting cigarettes into the city. 
    Cigarette means any roll for smoking made wholly or in part of tobacco irrespective of size or shape and whether or not such tobacco is flavored, adulterated or mixed with any other ingredient, the wrapper, or cover of which is made of paper or any other material or substance except tobacco. 
    Enforcement officer means the person designated to enforce this article. The term, includes such person's authorized agents. 
    Jobber means any person who distributes, delivers, conveys or gives away cigarettes to retail dealers or other persons in the city for the purpose of retail sale only. 
    Meter machine means any mechanical device which is used for the purpose of impressing or printing such a mark as may be prescribed by the city on a package of cigarettes which when so impressed or printed thereon shall evidence payment of the occupation license tax imposed by this article. 
    Package means any quantity of cigarettes wrapped and sealed in paper, foil, cardboard, or otherwise by the manufacturer of cigarettes prior to being placed in cartons and shipment from the manufacturer. 
    Retail dealer means any person, other than a wholesale dealer, jobber or manufacturer, engaged in the business of selling cigarettes, by person handling or through any machine or device, to the ultimate consumer or agent. 
    Sale means any transfer of title or possession or both, exchange, trade or barter, conditional or otherwise, in any manner whatsoever or by whatever means for any consideration or agreement therefor. 
    Stamp means a small piece of paper with which printing thereon as may be prescribed by the city which when affixed to a package of cigarettes and canceled shall evidence payment of the occupation license tax thereon, imposed by this article, and shall also include the impression or printed marking of a meter machine when used in lieu of such stamp. 
    Vending machine means any mechanical device used for the sale or dispensing of cigarettes and automatically operated by the purchaser through the deposit of coins, slugs or tokens. 
    Vending machine operator means any person in the capacity of owner, lessee, tenant or in any other capacity who shall operate or cause to be operated a vending machine. 
    Wholesale dealer means any person who distributes, delivers, conveys, or gives away cigarettes to retail dealers or other persons in the city for the purpose of retail sale only. 
(Code 1978, § 600.020) 
Sec. 12-67. - Tax imposed; use. 
    There is hereby imposed a license tax upon the distribution and sale within the city of all cigarettes as hereinafter provided. All receipts from the cigarette license tax shall be deposited to the credit of the general fund of the City of Carthage. 
(Code 1978, § 660.010; Ord. No. 6194, §§ I-III, 6-13-89) 
Sec. 12-68. - License for place of business. 
    Every wholesale dealer, jobber, manufacturer or retail dealer, or any other person, engaged in selling cigarettes or offering, delivering or displaying the same for sale within the city shall pay to the city an occupation license tax at the rate of two (2) mills per cigarette on each and all cigarettes sold, offered, delivered or displayed for sale within the city. 
(Code 1978, § 660.030) 
Sec. 12-69. - Manner of payment. 
    The payment of said license occupation tax shall be made contemporaneously with delivery of the sales tax report pursuant to section 12-70 below. 
(Ord. No. 96-78, § II, 11-12-96) 
Editor's note- Section I of Ord. No. 96-78, adopted Nov. 12, 1996, repealed §§ 12-69-12-80 in their entirety. Formerly, said sections pertained to similar subject matter and derived from §§ 660.040-660.140 of the 1978 Code. Section II of Ord. No. 96-78 enacted new provisions as herein set out. 
Sec. 12-70. - Evidence of payment. 
    It shall be the duty of every wholesale dealer or jobber before delivering to any retail dealer or other person within the city for sale at retail within the city to provide to the city a report showing daily purchases and returns of each package of cigarettes by each retail dealer and vending machine operator within the city which reports shall net out the dollar amount due the city for the occupation license tax by the month. The reporting form shall be approved by the city and shall be due not later than the fifteenth day of each month for the proceeding month. Each wholesale dealer or jobber shall authorize the city to verify such reports with the information provided to the Missouri Department of Revenue. 
(Ord. No. 96-78, § II, 11-12-96) 
Note- See the editor's note following § 12-69. 
Sec. 12-71. - Sale restricted. 
    No person shall sell or offer for sale or display for sale at retail within the city any cigarette unless the occupation license tax has been paid thereon and evidence of payment has been made to the city as provided above. 
(Ord. No. 96-78, § II, 11-12-96) 
Note- See the editor's note following § 12-69. 
Secs. 12-72-12-80. - Reserved. 
Note- See the editor's note following § 12-69. 
Secs. 12-81-12-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - AUTOMOBILE DEALERS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 12-101. - Street entrances. 
    The entrance to any establishment licensed under this article from the adjoining street shall not be constructed or maintained until the licensee has reset the adjoining curbing and reconstructed the adjoining sidewalk in accordance with the rules and requirements of the street commission. The licensee shall forthwith replace the curbing and sidewalk in conformance with the requirements of the street commissioner. 
(Code 1978, § 625.030) 
Secs. 12-102-12-110. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to levy license tax on automobile dealers, RSMo 94.110. 

Sec. 12-111. - Required. 
    No person shall conduct or engage in the business or solicitation of selling or dealing in automobiles inside the city without first obtaining license for such purpose. 
(Code 1978, § 625.010) 
Sec. 12-112. - Application. 
(a)  Any person, firm or corporation hereafter desiring to engage in the business of the sale of automobiles shall make application in writing to the city, which application shall set forth: 
(1)  If the applicant is an individual trading in his own name then his name and the place of his residence. If the applicant is a person trading upon a trade name, then the name under which he does business. If the applicant is a partnership, then the name and address of the respective partners and trade name under which the partnership does business. If the applicant is a foreign corporation, then the name of the state in which incorporated and a statement as to whether or not the corporation is licensed to do business in the state, and the name of its attorney in fact or its registered agent and the names and places of residence of its officers. If the applicant is a domestic corporation, then the names and places of residence of its officers. 
(2)  If the business is to be conducted on an open lot, a description of the lot number to be used by the applicant of the business. 
(b)  The applicant shall present with the application, a plan showing at least one (1) entrance or approach to the place of business from the street adjoining the same. 
(Code 1978, §§ 625.020, 625.030) 
Sec. 12-113. - Fee. 
    "No license shall be issued or renewed under this division until the applicant pays an annual license fee to the city based upon gross receipts as follows: one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) plus ten cents ($0.10) per one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) of all gross receipts over two hundred thousand dollars ($200,000.00). The term "gross receipts," as used in this section, shall exclude the sale of shop parts and the amount allowed for a trade-in shall be deducted from the sales price of an automobile to determine the gross receipts on any particular sale. 
(Ord. No. 6170, § 1, 2-28-89) 
Sec. 12-114. - Term. 
    Licenses required by this division shall expire at the end of the calendar year for which they are issued. 
(Code 1978, § 625.040) 
Sec. 12-115. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Former § 12-115 was repealed by Ord. No. 6163, § I, adopted Feb. 14, 1989. The repealed provisions pertained to city council approval before issuance of automobile dealer's license and derived from Code 1978, § 625.090. 
Sec. 12-116. - Revocation. 
    The council may revoke any license issued under this division for the violation of any of the terms of this article, but such revocation shall not relieve the licensee from any penalty for violation of this article. 
(Code 1978, § 625.100) 
Secs. 12-117-12-130. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - CONTRACTORS[6] 
Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Cross reference- Electricians, § 6-68 et seq.; plumbers, § 6-216 et seq. 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to buy license taxes on certain contractors, RSMo 94.110. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 12-131. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    General contractor means every person engaged in the business of building, erecting, repairing, remodeling and otherwise constructing or reconstructing houses, buildings or other structures or any part thereof. 
    Specialty contractor means every person who contracts to construct or do roofing repairs or installation, painting or paper contracting, ditching, sewer construction, curb and gutter construction, tree trimming, tree and shrubbery removal, pavement construction, plastering, flooring, floor sanding or other construction work of a specialized nature, or work performed by contract under the contract of a general contractor. "Specialty contractor" includes a person who inspects for or controls termites or other pests. 
(Code 1978, §§ 630.010, 630.070) 
Sec. 12-132. - Exemptions. 
    Except as provided in section 12-147, this article does not apply to individuals who exclusively labor for daily wages. 
(Code 1978, § 630.010) 
Sec. 12-133. - Revocation of building permits and licenses. 
    Failure of any general contractor or specialty contractor to comply with any of the provisions of this article shall be cause for the revocation of his license or the building permit issued to him. The building inspector shall give five (5) days' notice to the general contractor or specialty contractor of the violations before revoking any building permit or license. 
(Code 1968, § 630.040) 
Sec. 12-134. - Signs on projects. 
    Every general contractor shall identify each project on which construction work is being performed by means of a suitable sign not less than twenty-four (24) inches by fifteen (15) inches in size with the following information in letters sufficient in size as to be visible from the street: name of permit holder, license number and classification. 
(Code 1978, § 630.060) 
Secs. 12-135-12-144. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 12-145. - Required. 
    No person shall engage in business as a general contractor or specialty contractor without a license issued by the city. 
(Code 1978, § 630.020) 
Sec. 12-146. - Persons eligible. 
    No person shall be granted a license as a specialty contractor to engage in the inspection for or control of termites or other pests unless such person is of good moral character, nor shall any corporation be granted a license for the same or similar activities unless the managing officer of such corporation is of good moral character. If, in the opinion of the mayor, the applicant for such license is of good moral character, the city clerk shall issue a license. However, should the mayor believe that the license should not be issued, he shall refuse to give his approval to the application. If the applicant shall feel himself aggrieved by the action of the mayor in refusing to approve said application, he shall appeal to the city council for relief. The council shall then set a certain day to hear the matter, at which time all interested parties may appear and be heard, and if a majority of all members of the council shall vote to issue the license, then the license shall be issued. 
(Code 1978, § 630.070) 
Sec. 12-147. - Fee. 
    Fee:

Sec. 12-148. - Term. 
    Licenses required by this division expire at the end of the calendar year for which they were issued. 
(Code 1978, § 630.020) 
Sec. 12-149. - Insurance. 
    Before any person is granted a license under this division, such person shall file a certificate of insurance with the city certifying public liability insurance in an amount as provided by the Missouri State Statutes; and such person shall also be required to file a certificate of insurance for workers' compensation coverage or an affidavit, the form of which shall be developed by the Division of Labor and Industrial Relations for the State of Missouri, signed by the applicant attesting that the contractor is exempt from such requirement and no business license shall be issued to any contractor applicant failing to provide such certificate of insurance or affidavit. 
(Ord. No. 09-01, § II, 1-13-09) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 09-01, § II, adopted Jan. 13, 2009, repealed the former § 12-149, and enacted a new § 12-149 as set out herein. The former § 12-149 pertained to similar subject matter. See the Code Comparative Table for complete derivation. 
Secs. 12-150-12-175. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - MERCHANTS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 12-176. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Enforcement officer means the person designated to enforce this article. 
    Merchant means any person who deals in the sale of any goods, wares or merchandise, at any store, stand or place occupied for that purpose within the city. 
(Code 1978, § 640.010) 
Sec. 12-177. - Violations. 
    Any merchant who fails, neglects, or refuses to deliver the statements herein required, and pay the tax and license levied by this article on or before the first Monday in January of each year shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor upon conviction, and in addition to any other penalty imposed, the enforcement officer shall assess the aggregate amount of sales of such merchant at double their aggregate value. The same shall be ascertained by the available best information, and the enforcement officer shall also report the delinquency to the city attorney. 
(Code 1978, § 640.100) 
Sec. 12-178. - False statements. 
    Whoever makes or files with the enforcement officer under the provisions of this article, a false statement under oath, shall, on conviction thereof, forfeit his license and be guilty of a misdemeanor. It shall be the duty of the enforcement officer to carefully examine all statements filed with him and to prosecute all violations of this article according to law. Before instituting any such prosecution, the enforcement officer shall give the merchant an opportunity of explaining the statement and correcting it, if inadvertently made and if it appears to the enforcement officer that such false statement was wilfully and corruptly made, the enforcement officer shall report same to the city attorney. 
(Code 1978, § 640.110) 
Sec. 12-179. - Records. 
    It shall be the duty of each merchant to keep a proper book, and enter in ink an account of all sales made by him or them, which account shall always be open to the inspection of the city under the requirements of this article, but shall not be made public or be subject to the inspection of others. 
(Code 1978, § 640.080) 
Sec. 12-180. - Display of merchandise on sidewalks. 
    Merchants located within the city are hereby authorized to display merchandise on the public sidewalks adjacent to their business within the city, provided that the sidewalk has a width of at least five (5) feet and that the merchandise is displayed on no more than one-half of the sidewalk, that being the one-half closest to the building housing the merchant's [business]. 
(Ord. No. 6167, § I, 2-14-89) 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 6167, adopted Feb. 14, 1989, did not specifically amend this Code; hence, inclusion of § I as § 12-180 was at the discretion of the editor. 
Cross reference- Sight distance triangles on corner lots to be free from obstructions to vision, § 17-1; streets and sidewalks, Ch. 21. 
Secs. 12-181-12-187. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
State Law reference- Merchants tax authorized, RSMo 94.080. 

Sec. 12-188. - Required. 
    Every merchant shall before doing or offering to do the business as such obtain a license from the city. 
(Code 1978, § 640.020) 
Sec. 12-189. - Fee. 
(a)  The enforcement officer shall after the first Monday in December and before the first Monday in January of each year call on each merchant, and notify the merchant to furnish and whether so notified or not furnish the enforcement officer with a statement of the aggregate amount of all sales made by him during the year next preceding the first Monday of December, which statement shall be made in writing and delivered to the enforcement officer, verified by the affidavit of the merchant or officer of the corporation making it, if residing in the city, if not, then by some credible person authorized to do so and the amount of the tax and license due thereon shall be paid to the enforcement officer on or before the first Monday of January of each year. 
(b)  When any merchant commences business in the city after the first Monday in January in any year, he shall pay a license fee to the city of twenty-five dollars ($25.00). 
(Code 1978, §§ 640.030, 640.040, 640.070; Ord. No. 96-79, § I, 11-26-96; Ord. No. 96-84, 12-23-96) 
Secs. 12-190-12-200. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - PAWNBROKERS AND SECONDHAND DEALERS 

Sec. 12-201. - Records. 
(a)  Every person buying for trade, resale or accepting as security for any secured personal loan, any tangible personal property, shall at the time of taking possession of such property record in a register the description of such property, purchased or received, together with the time, name, date of birth, and place of residence of the person selling or leaving the property, and also the amount paid or loaned for the property. 
(b)  Every entry shall be made in ink or typed and shall not in any manner be erased, obliterated, or defaced. 
(c)  Such register shall at all times be kept open to the inspection of any officer of the police department. 
(Code 1978, § 240.050) 
Sec. 12-202. - Receiving property from minors. 
    No pawnbroker shall receive any personal property from any minor, without the written consent of such minor's parents or guardians. 
(Code 1978, § 645.020) 
Sec. 12-203. - Clothing to be cleaned. 
    No person shall sell secondhand clothing without first cleaning or sterilizing such clothing. 
(Code 1978, § 645.030) 
Secs. 12-204-12-225. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - PEDDLERS, HAWKERS, ETC.[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to license and regulate peddlers, etc., RSMo 94.110. 

Sec. 12-226. - Peddling from parked vehicles. 
(a)  No person shall park any vehicle on any public way, city park or real property in this city for the purpose of selling, or offering for sale, any goods, produce, or merchandise or for the purpose of soliciting business without the approval of the council. 
(b)  This section shall not apply to those selling goods on Wednesdays and Saturdays from March through November on the north side of the square, for the Farmers Market. Any person participating in the farmers market shall provide a current sales tax certificate and pay a ten dollars ($10.00) season license fee. All other state health regulations shall apply. 
(Code 1978, § 240.460; Ord. No. 09-14, § I, 3-10-09) 
Sec. 12-227. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this article is to protect, maintain and enhance the public health, safety, and general welfare by regulating peddling, itinerant traders, traveling salesperson, and other door-to-door salesperson, generally known as peddlers. This article is not intended to interfere with legitimate business activities of peddlers as the same are herein defined, whether same be local or interstate. These provisions are intended only to, as nearly as possible, ferret out the illegitimate or confidence operators and to regulate and control all those who would use their unique presence on property within the city, either in person or by means of a telephone contact, or their unique proximity to its residents, for purposes of harassment, nuisance, theft, or other unlawful activities. To achieve this end, this article requires peddlers seek licenses, have background checks, and peddle under certain limitations. It is not the intent of this article to infringe free speech rights or require licensing for persons going door-to-door for political campaigns, religious proselytizing, or other free speech reasons. 
(Ord. No. 10-38, § I, 10-26-10) 
Sec. 12-228. - Definitions. 
    As used in this article, the following words have the meaning indicated except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    A canvasser is a person who attempts to make personal contact with a resident at his/her residence, without prior specific invitation or appointment from the resident, for the primary purpose of attempting to enlist support for or against a particular religion, philosophy, ideology, political party, issue or candidate, even if incidental to such purpose the canvasser accepts the donation of money for or against such cause. 
    A peddler , hawker , etc., is a person who attempts to make personal contact with a resident at his/her residence, without prior specific invitation or appointment from the resident, for the primary purpose of attempting to sell a good or service. The word "peddler" or "hawker" shall include "door-to-door salespersons", "itinerant traders, vendors or merchants", "traveling salespersons", "vendor", "huckster", "concessionaire", and shall include route salespersons selling randomly to customers, but not route salespersons supplying only prior customer orders. A "peddler" does not include a "solicitor." 
    A solicitor is a person who attempts to make personal contact with a resident at his/her residence, without prior specific invitation or appointment from the resident, for the primary purpose of (1) attempting to obtain a donation to a particular patriotic, philanthropic, social service, welfare, benevolent, educational, civic, fraternal, charitable, political or religious purpose, even if incidental to such purpose there is the sale of some good or service, or (2) distributing a handbill or flyer advertising a commercial event, activity, good or service that is offered to the resident for purchase at a location away from the residence or at a time different from the time of visit. 
(Ord. No. 10-38, § I, 10-26-10) 
Sec. 12-229. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any peddler, solicitor, itinerant merchant, and vendor as defined in section 12-228 of this article to engage in such business within the corporate limits of the City of Carthage, without first obtaining a license therefore. Each employee of a business or corporation engaging in peddling shall have a separate license. A license must be applied for at least fifteen (15) days prior to the date when the activity to be carried on is to commence. 
(Ord. No. 10-38, § I, 10-26-10) 
Sec. 12-230. - Exemptions. 
    The license requirement of section 12-229 shall not apply to: 
(1)  Sales by farmers and gardeners of the produce of their farms, gardens and greenhouses, including fruit, vegetables and flowers, or to the sale, distribution and delivery of milk, teas, coffees, spices, groceries, meats and bakery goods, to sales on approval, to conditional sales of merchandise, or to the taking of orders for merchandise for future delivery when full payment is not required at the time of solicitation; 
(2)  To individuals or groups who are duly authorized to act for and on behalf of, any recognized charitable, civic or religious organization; 
(3)  Peddlers selling to or soliciting orders from retail businesses only; 
(4)  Peddlers going to a house or place of business at the express invitation of the owner or occupant of such house or place of business; 
(5)  Persons engaged in a business or activity which the state or federal government has exclusive authority to regulate; 
(6)  Persons distributing newspapers, pamphlets, handbills or other written or printed matter distributed for the purpose of disseminating news, information or religious materials; 
(7)  Persons living in the city who hold garage sales, in accordance with Article XII of the Code of Carthage; and 
(8)  Governmental entities. 
(Ord. No. 10-38, § I, 10-26-10) 
Sec. 12-231. - Prohibitions. 
    No person, including those exempted in section 12-230 hereof, shall: 
(1)  Remain upon private property after having been asked to leave by the owner or occupant thereof. Any itinerant vendor, mobile street vendor or peddler who enters upon property owned, leased or controlled by another and willfully refuses to leave said property after having been notified by such owner or possessor of said property, or his agent, to leave such property shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(2)  Engage in any conduct in violation of any law of the State of Missouri or any ordinance of the City of Carthage. 
(3)  Sell or offer for sale any goods, wares, merchandise, food, produce or other items upon any public street, sidewalk, alley or other public right of way. 
(4)  Call on prospective customers between the hours of 7:30 p.m. and 10:00 a.m., unless by previous arrangement with such customer. 
(5)  Engage in any activity of solicitation, selling, requesting donations, distribution of literature of any type, or offering of any service upon any public street or at any street intersection. 
(Ord. No. 10-38, § I, 10-26-10) 
Sec. 12-232. - Required information. 
    Applicants for a license under this article shall make a sworn application to the city upon forms to be furnished by the city clerk's office. A criminal record check shall be completed by the Carthage Police Department. Each applicant shall provide the minimum following information: 
(1)  Full name and all information contained on the driver's license of the applicant and each agent or employee working under the license; 
(2)  Permanent home address and present local address of the applicant; 
(3)  Name and home office address of the applicant's employer; 
(4)  If the applicant owns or uses a motor vehicle in connection with his business, a description of such motor vehicle and the license number of same; 
(5)  A brief description of the merchandise or services to be sold; 
(6)  A statement as to whether or not the applicant has been convicted of any felony and the disposition of same; 
(7)  A site plan to be drawn by the applicant, not to scale, which need only show the location to be used by the itinerant vendor and to be made the basis of the license; 
(8)  Proposed duration of the temporary sales operation; 
(9)  Written permission of the owner of the land or building where the sales are to take place (itinerant vendor only); 
(10)  A copy of the applicant's State of Missouri Sales Tax Permit; and 
(11)  A copy of a certificate of insurance, for vehicular, property, casualty, or liability as may be reasonable and customary for the nature of the proposed operation consistent with the Revised Statutes of Missouri (RSMO). 
(Ord. No. 10-38, § I, 10-26-10) 
Sec. 12-233. - Investigation; issuance, and denial. 
(a)  The city clerk shall initiate the investigation of the truth and accuracy of the information contained in the application as soon as possible. 
(b)  The city clerk shall deny a license if a timely investigation reveals that: 
(1)  Failure of the applicant to truthfully provide any of the information requested by the city as a part of the application or the failure to sign the application, or the failure to pay the required fee at the time of application. 
(2)  The conviction of the applicant within the past five (5) years from the date of application for any violation or any federal or state statute or regulation, or of any local ordinance, which adversely reflects on the person's ability to conduct the business for which the license is being sought in an honest and legal manner. These violations shall include but not be limited to burglary, theft, larceny, swindling, fraud, unlawful business practices, and any form of actual or threatened physical harm against another person or violations involving a sex offense, trafficking in controlled substances, or any violent acts against persons or property; 
(3)  An investigation reveals that the applicant falsified information on the application; 
(4)  The location and time of the activities described in the application would endanger the safety and welfare of the applicant or its customers; 
(5)  The applicant is a person against whom a judgment based upon, or conviction for, fraud, deceit or misrepresentation has been entered within the five (5) years immediately preceding the date of application; 
(6)  There is no proof as to the authority of the applicant to serve as an agent to the principal; or 
(c)  The city clerk's disapproval and the reasons for disapproval shall be noted on the application, and the applicant shall be notified that his application is disapproved and that no license will be issued. Notice shall be mailed to the applicant at the address shown on the application form, or at the applicant's last known address. 
(Ord. No. 10-38, § I, 10-26-10) 
Sec. 12-234. - Violations, enforcement or revocation of license. 
(a)  The licenses issued pursuant to this article may be revoked immediately by the city clerk of the City of Carthage, for any of the following causes: 
(1)  Any fraud, misrepresentation or false statement contained in the application for license; 
(2)  Any fraud, misrepresentation or false statement made in connection with the selling of goods, wares or merchandise; 
(3)  Any violation of this article; 
(4)  Conviction of the licensee of any felony or of a misdemeanor involving moral turpitude; or 
(5)  Conducting the business licensed under this article in an unlawful manner or in such a manner as to constitute a breach of the peace or to constitute a menace to the health, safety or general welfare of the public; or any other conduct that is prohibited by local, state or federal laws or regulations. 
(b)  The license of an itinerant vendor shall be suspended until such time as may be heard publicly and reinstated by the city council. 
(c)  Notice of hearing for revocation of a license shall be given in writing, setting forth specifically the grounds of the complaint and the time and place of the hearing. Such notice shall be mailed, postage prepaid, to the licensee, at his last known address, at least five (5) days prior to the date set for the hearing. 
    Any person who violates or fails to comply with the provisions of any section of this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction shall be punishable by fine as provided in the Carthage Code. 
(Ord. No. 10-38, § I, 10-26-10) 
Sec. 12-235. - Appeals. 
    Any person aggrieved by the decision of the city clerk in regard to the denial of application for license as provided for in section 12-233 of this article or in connection with the revocation of a license as provided for in section 12-234 of this article, shall have the right to appeal to the city council of the City of Carthage, Missouri. Such appeal shall be taken by filing with the city clerk within fourteen (14) days after notice of the decision by the city clerk has been mailed to such person's last address, a written statement setting forth the grounds for the appeal. The city clerk shall set the time and place for a hearing on such appeal and notice of such hearing shall be given to such person in the same manner as provided in section 12-234 of this article for notice of hearing on revocation. The order of the city council on such appeal shall be final. Upon the denial or revocation of a license, the city clerk shall notify in writing the applicant or licensee of the reason for such denial or revocation. The applicant or licensee shall have a right of appeal to the city council upon the denial or revocation of the license. 
(Ord. No. 10-38, § I, 10-26-10) 
Sec. 12-236. - Fees. 
    Each and every person seeking a license under the provisions herein shall pay an application fee of fifty dollars ($50.00). The license fee shall be paid by the person desiring the license and payable at the time of application. This fee shall be charged to help defray the cost of investigation and administration incident to the license. This fee shall not be pro-rated or refunded to the applicant regardless of whether a license is issued or not. 
    The fee for the issuance of each license shall be: 
(1)  For a peddler acting on behalf of a merchant licensed or not otherwise licensed to do business within the city, a fee of ten dollars ($10.00) per day. 
(2)  For a solicitor (including a commercial solicitor advertising an event, activity, good or service for purchase at a location away from the residence) or canvasser requesting a license, no fee. 
(3)  For a canvasser (even if incidental to such purpose the canvasser accepts the donation of money for or against such cause), no fee. 
(Ord. No. 10-38, § I, 10-26-10) 
Sec. 12-237. - Duration. 
    Each itinerant vendor's or peddler's license issued under the authority of this article shall be valid for the period of anticipated use of the applicant, but not to exceed ninety (90) days for from the date it is issued, or until revoked under the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 10-38, § I, 10-26-10) 
Sec. 12-238. - Customers' rights; cancellation. 
    All peddlers or solicitors shall provide to the consumer, in writing, the right to cancel a solicitation transaction made in person or by telephone until midnight of the third business day after the day on which the customer signs an agreement or offer to purchase any goods, wares, merchandise, food, photographs, publications or services. For the purpose of telephone solicitation, the date of transaction means the day the consumer receives the goods, wares, merchandise, food, photographs, publications or services purchased in a solicitation transaction. If the consumer chooses to cancel the solicitation transaction, notification by mail shall be considered given at the time mailed, as evidenced by the postmark, notification by telegram shall be considered given at the time filed for transmission and notification by any other writing shall be considered given at the time delivered to the merchant's designated place of business. It shall be unlawful for any peddler, solicitor or company represented to refuse to allow the customer to cancel the solicitation transaction. 
(Ord. No. 10-38, § I, 10-26-10) 
Sec. 12-239. - License display. 
    Every peddler or itinerant vendor as defined in this article who has secured a license under the authority of this article shall keep a copy of any license upon his person at all times and shall display the same upon the request of any city official, customer, police officer or owner or occupant upon whose property the itinerant vendor or peddler has gone for business purposes. 
(Ord. No. 10-38, § I, 10-26-10) 
Sec. 12-240. - Transferability, assignability or use by another. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person other than the person to whom the license was issued to display or otherwise use any itinerant vendor's or peddler's license. The licenses issued under the authority of this article shall not be transferable or assignable. 
(Ord. No. 10-38, § I, 10-26-10) 
Sec. 12-241. - Surety. 
    Before any license, as provided by this article, shall be issued for engaging in the businesses as defined in section 12-229 of this article in the City of Carthage, such applicant shall file with the city clerk a bond running to the city, in the sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) executed by the applicant, as principal, and a surety bond upon which service of process may be made in the State of Missouri; said bond to be approved by the city attorney, conditioned that the said applicant shall comply with all of the provisions of the ordinance of the City of Carthage, Missouri, and the statutes of the State of Missouri, regulating and concerning the sale of goods, wares and merchandise, and will pay all judgments rendered against said applicant for any violation of said ordinances or statutes, or any of them, together with all judgments and costs that may be recovered against him by any person or persons for damage growing out of any misrepresentation or deception practiced on any person transacting such business with said applicant, whether said misrepresentations or deceptions were made or practiced by the owners or by their servants, agents, or employees, either at the time of making the sale or through any advertisement of any character whatsoever, printed or circulated with reference to the goods, wares and merchandise sold or any part thereof, and guaranteeing to any citizen of the City of Carthage, Missouri, that property purchased will be delivered according to the representations of the said applicant. Action on the bond may be brought in the name of the city to the use of the aggrieved person. Such bond must be approved by the city attorney, both as to form, and as the responsibility of the sureties thereon. 
(Ord. No. 10-38, § I, 10-26-10) 
Sec. 12-242. - Posting. 
    It shall be unlawful for any peddler or solicitor to enter upon any private premises when the same is posted with a sign stating "No Peddlers Allowed," "No Solicitation Allowed" or other words to that effect. 
(Ord. No. 10-38, § I, 10-26-10) 
Secs. 12-243-12-250. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - TAXICABS[9] 
Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to license and regulate taxicabs, RSMo 94.110. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 12-251. - Definitions. 
    In this article "taxicab business" means the business of carrying passengers for hire in motor vehicles over irregular routes in the city. 
Sec. 12-252. - Vehicle inspections. 
(a)  All motor vehicles now being used or proposed for use within the city as taxicabs shall be inspected by the chief of police or a deputy assigned by the chief of police, prior to being used as a taxicab, every ninety (90) days, and within fourteen (14) days after each accident requiring an accident report to be filed with the police department. If any motor vehicle is not so inspected or in the event any such motor vehicle is found to be in an unsafe condition upon inspection, the vehicle shall be removed from service as a taxicab. 
(b)  The inspection herein provided for shall be in addition to any inspection provided by the state as a condition to obtaining state license plates. 
(c)  Any person who does not submit his motor vehicles for inspection by the chief of police or his duly appointed deputy, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and in addition shall forfeit his license to operate a taxicab business in the city. 
(Code 1978, § 605.260) 
Secs. 12-253-12-260. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - BUSINESS PERMIT 

Sec. 12-261. - Required. 
(a)  No person shall engage in the taxicab business without a permit from the city council authorizing same.
