(j)  All solid waste and garbage must be drained of liquid substance before it is placed in solid waste containers at residences or dwellings. In the operation of business and industrial establishments, all persons occupying such business or commercial buildings shall place any and all raw garbage in sealed plastic bags, or similar containers, prior to the deposit of such raw garbage in solid waste containers. 
(k)  Every owner, occupant, lessee, or tenant of a house or building used for residence, business, or commercial/industrial purposes is hereby required to maintain solid waste storage areas in a clean, unlittered condition and to ensure that all solid waste generated by the use of such property is contained as required by ordinances of the city. 
(Ord. No. 09-53, § I, 10-13-09) 
Sec. 20-7. - Collection-Generally. 
(a)  The city shall provide for the collection of solid waste in the city; provided, however, that the city may provide the collection service by contracting with a person for the entire city or portion thereof, as deemed to be in the best interests of the city. 
(b)  All solid waste, except bulky items, from premises to which collection services are provided by the city shall be collected; provided, however, that bulky items will be collected weekly if not exceeding reasonable limitations of weight and bulk established by regulations of the director. All solid waste collected shall, upon being loaded into collection equipment, become the property of the collection agency. 
(c)  Containers may be placed at the curbside after 5:00 p.m. the day before the regularly scheduled pickup day but no later than 6:30 a.m. the pickup day. Containers shall be removed from the curb by 7:00 p.m. on the pickup day. The responsible party at each dwelling unit is responsible for maintaining the sanitary condition of solid waste containers as necessary to prevent nuisance by the householder or commercial operator to whom the same belong. 
(d)  Bulky items shall be collected by request to the city's contractor. The director shall establish the procedure for collecting bulky items. 
(e)  Solid waste collectors, employed by the city or a solid waste collection agency operating under contract with the city may enter upon private property for the purpose of collecting solid waste therefrom as required by this chapter. Solid waste collectors shall not enter dwelling units or other residential buildings for the purpose of collecting residential solid waste. Commercial solid waste may be removed from within commercial establishments upon request of the owner. 
(f)  The following collection frequencies shall apply to collections of solid waste within the city: 
(1)  All residential solid waste, other than bulky items, shall be collected once weekly on a regularly scheduled day. 
(2)  All commercial solid waste shall be collected a minimum of once weekly and shall be collected at such lesser intervals as may be fixed by the director upon a determination that such lesser intervals are necessary for the preservation of the health and/or safety of the public. 
(g)  Residential solid waste containers shall be stored upon the residential premises. Commercial solid waste containers shall be stored upon private property unless the owner shall have been granted written permission from the city to use public property for such purposes. The storage site shall be well drained; fully accessible to collection equipment, public health personnel and fire inspection personnel. 
(h)  All collection vehicles shall be maintained in a safe, clean and sanitary condition, and shall be so constructed, maintained and operated as to prevent spillage of solid waste therefrom. The bodies thereof shall be enclosed with only loading hoppers exposed. No solid waste shall be transported in the loading hoppers except during normal collection activities. Bulk rubbish shall be conveyed in tight vehicles, trucks or receptacles so constructed and maintained that none of the material being transported shall spill upon the public rights-of-way. 
(i)  Transportation and disposal of demolition and construction wastes shall be in accordance with sections 20-9 and 20-11 of this chapter. 
(j)  It shall be unlawful for any person to interfere in any manner with solid waste collection equipment, or with authorized solid waste collectors in the lawful performance of their duties as such. 
(k)  Trucks, vehicles and receptacles used to remove, haul or dispose of earth and rock material from grading or excavation activities shall be so constructed and maintained that none of the material being transported spills upon the public rights-of-way. 
(l)  In accordance with the Americans with Disabilities Act and exceptional customers' needs, the contractor shall make reasonable accommodations for collecting solid waste containers of customers with disabilities and exceptional customers' needs. 
(Ord. No. 09-53, § I, 10-13-09) 
Sec. 20-8. - Same-Service charges. 
(a)  There is imposed for the collection and disposal of solid waste, a service charge to be established by ordinance. The service charge for each commercial establishment will be determined by the contractor or city on the basis of quantity and characteristics of material, point of pickup, and time required to collect the solid waste. Commercial establishments at the discretion of the director may haul their own solid waste in vehicles, as provided in subsection (h) of section 20-7, to an authorized disposal site. Any commercial establishment may appeal to the council by written notice to the director in the event any unfair or exorbitant charges are made by the contractor, and the council or a committee thereof will hear the appeal and consider a proper course of action. 
(b)  The service and service charge shall be terminated upon presentation of satisfactory proof to the director that any such dwelling unit or establishment is unoccupied and shall be commenced upon renewed occupancy thereof. 
(c)  The system of services established by the provisions of this chapter hereof is designed as an integral part of the city's program of health and sanitation to be operated as an adjunct to the city's system for providing potable water and the city's system for providing sewerage disposal. The city may enforce collection of such charges by bringing proper legal action against the occupant or any premises which has received such services, to recover any sums due for such services plus a reasonable attorney's fee to be fixed by the court. 
(d)  The service charge is imposed upon the occupant of each dwelling unit receiving service under the provisions of this chapter and billing therefor shall be made to the person contracting for city electric, water and/or sewerage service or for other water service or otherwise providing water service to each such dwelling unit, in which event billing therefor shall be made to the owner. Service charges shall be payable to the department empowered to collect service charges imposed by the city and added to the present utility bill. 
(Ord. No. 09-53, § I, 10-13-09) 
Sec. 20-9. - Disposal. 
(a)  Solid wastes shall be disposed of at a processing facility or disposal area approved by the city and complying with all requirements of the state division of health. The director may classify certain wastes as hazardous wastes which will require special handling and shall be disposed of only in a manner acceptable to the director and which will meet all local, state and federal regulations. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to burn solid waste excepting leaves and yard wastes unless an approved incinerator is provided or unless a variance has been obtained from the appropriate air pollution control agency. Leaves and yard wastes may not be burned except between 7:00 a.m. and 7:00 p.m. 
(Ord. No. 09-53, § I, 10-13-09) 
Sec. 20-10. - License for collectors. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person, other than the city, or its employees, to engage in, pursue, or carry on the business or occupation of collecting, hauling or disposing of garbage in the city without first procuring a license to engage in such business as hereinafter provided from the city. The city shall issue a garbage license which shall entitle the holder thereof to collect, haul and dispose of garbage for any number of customers within the city in accordance with the provisions of this section. The fee for a garbage license shall be one-hundred dollars ($100.00) per year. 
(b)  In this section "garbage" means all rejected matter, whether animal or vegetable, that attended the preparation, cooking, dealing in, handling, or storing of foods, meats, fruits, or vegetables, in all their various forms and the refuse resulting from their use for human consumption. "Garbage" does not include ashes, manure, night soil, chamber lye, the carcasses of dead animals or fowls, rubbish, soap suds, or free liquid of any kind. 
(c)  This section shall not prohibit the actual producers of refuse or trash, or the owners of premises upon which refuse has accumulated, from personally collecting, conveying and disposing of such refuse, provided such producers or owners comply with all governing laws and ordinances. 
(d)  This section shall not prohibit collectors of refuse from outside of the city from hauling such refuse over city streets, provided such collectors comply with all city codes. 
(Ord. No. 09-53, § I, 10-13-09) 
Sec. 20-11. - Permits for collectors, etc. 
(a)  No person shall engage in the business of collecting, transporting, processing or disposing of solid waste within the city without an annual permit therefor from the city. This subsection does not apply to employees of the holder of such a permit. If the city awards a contract for the collection of solid waste, the contractor would be issued a permit. It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of collecting, transporting, processing or disposing of solid waste within the city without a permit from the city, or operate under an expired permit, or after his permit has been suspended or revoked. 
(b)  Permits are not required for the removal, hauling or disposal of earth and rock material from grading or excavation activities. 
(c)  All motor vehicles operating under a permit shall display the number on each side in colors which contrast with that of the vehicle. Such numbers shall be clearly legible. Each permit for processing or disposal facilities shall be prominently displayed at the facility. 
(d)  The contractor shall furnish to city and maintain during the term of the contract, a performance bond acceptable to the city in a penal sum of one hundred eighty thousand dollars ($180,000.00) with good and sufficient surety acceptable to city and conditioned upon contractor performing his duties and obligations provided for in the agreement with him. 
(Ord. No. 09-53, § I, 10-13-09) 
Sec. 20-12. - Prohibited items in landfills. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to place for collection items which have been banned by the State of Missouri for deposit in landfills, within the state, either at the date of the adoption of this section or subsequent to the adoption of this section. These items presently include, but are not limited to, lead acid batteries, waste oil, major appliances, tires, and yard waste. A copy of prohibited items shall be kept in the office of the city clerk and made available to any person requesting such a copy. 
(Ord. No. 09-53, § I, 10-13-09) 
Sec. 20-13. - Yard waste. 
    Yard waste shall not be permitted to be mingled with solid waste. 
(Ord. No. 09-53, § I, 10-13-09) 
Chapter 21 - STREETS AND SIDEWALKS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Street commissioner, § 2-201 et seq.; public possession of alcohol, § 3-3; posting handbills, etc., § 13-132; obstruction of view at street corners and public driveways, sight distance regulations, § 17-1; numbering of buildings, § 17-76 et seq.; traffic, Ch. 23; sales from parked vehicles, § 23-415. 
State Law reference- General municipal authority relative to streets and sidewalks, RSMo 77.520. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 21-1. - References to city engineer. 
    References in this chapter to the "city engineer" are to the city engineer or to such other person as is designated by the council to enforce the provisions of this chapter in which such reference appears. 
Sec. 21-2. - Obstruction of parkway. 
    No person shall erect or maintain any fence, or extend any wire, or place any other obstruction, in any parkway except the following: 
(1)  Brick or masonry structure built around a mailbox for the purpose of supporting a single mailbox and provided that: 
a.  The outside horizontal dimension of any one (1) side or the maximum diameter of such structure does not exceed twenty-six (26) inches. 
b.  Said structure or any part thereof are located behind the existing curb and where no curb exist, behind the back of a curbline as established by the city's engineering department. 
[(2)  Reserved.] 
    All obstructions built in the parkway, including brick or masonry structures built around mailboxes, are subject to being removed or destroyed at any time by the city or by any of the various utilities that are in or placed in the street right-of-way or parkway. Any such removal or reconstruction shall be done at the property owner's expense. 
(Code 1978, § 240.440; Ord. No. 96-24, § 1, 3-26-96) 
Sec. 21-3. - Construction materials in streets. 
    Any person who shall use, or cause to be used, any part of the public square or of any street, avenue or other highway in the city for the piling of material while constructing, removing or repairing or reconstructing any building, and who shall willfully fail, within three (3) days after completing the same, to remove all such material or remnants thereof, so as to leave such street, alley, avenue, square or public highway clear and in as good and safe a condition as found shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1978, § 240.140) 
Sec. 21-4. - Unguarded obstructions. 
    No person shall place or cause to be placed upon any street, avenue, alley, sidewalk, or other public highway, any lumber, lathes, ties, timbers, stone, dirt or other substance, or any building material, so as to constitute an obstruction thereof, and leave the same unguarded at night. 
(Code 1978, § 240.570(F)) 
Sec. 21-5. - Removing danger signals, etc. 
    No person without proper authority shall remove, break, or extinguish any lantern, flare, or other danger signal which has been placed on any street, alley, sidewalk, parking, or other highway, or portion of a highway, for the purpose of guarding against accidents. 
(Code 1978, § 240.570(H)) 
Sec. 21-6. - Open gratings on sidewalks. 
    No person shall leave open, or suffer to be left open, or in an insecure or unsafe condition, on any premises under his ownership or control, any grating or other covering of an area or vault under a sidewalk. 
(Code 1978, § 240.570(G)) 
Sec. 21-7. - Tampering, etc., with streets, sidewalks, etc. 
    No person shall remove any material from any street or sidewalk of the city, or change or alter the lawfully established grade, or change the course of any surface water in any public street, alley, or highway, or remove any part of any sidewalk, or paving in any of the streets, avenues, alleys, or other public highways without the consent of the council. 
(Code 1978, § 240.570(I)) 
Sec. 21-8. - Fires in streets. 
    No person shall burn anything or start a fire upon any paved street within the city. 
(Code 1978, § 240.630(A)) 
Sec. 21-9. - Obstructing sidewalks. 
    No person shall obstruct any public sidewalk in the City of Carthage or any area between any public sidewalk and any street in the City of Carthage by placing, causing or permitting to be placed thereon any object of any nature whatsoever. Provided, however, this provision shall not apply to any area properly marked and dedicated to public parking and further provided that this does not apply to any decorative lighting or any seating for the public, provided that such decorative lighting or seating for the public shall be approved by the city council prior to its placement. This section shall further not apply to sidewalks abutting commercial establishments within the Carthage Courthouse Square Historic District, wherein the commercial establishments may display certain wares and goods upon said sidewalk during daylight hours provided that said merchandise shall be displayed only on that five (5) feet of the sidewalk on the four (4) sides of the outside of the square closest to the mercantile establishment and provided further, that no more than twenty-four (24) inches of sidewalk be used or remaining sidewalks within said Carthage Courthouse Square Historic District. 
    No person shall construct or maintain a downspout in such manner as to cause the water emitted therefrom to flow onto or across any sidewalk located in the City of Carthage. 
(Code 1978, § 240.570(B) Ord. No. 6507, § 1, 7-27-93) 
Sec. 21-10. - Property owners to keep gutters and sidewalks clean. 
    Owners or occupants of buildings shall keep the gutters and sidewalks, in front of their buildings clean and clear of mud, dirt, filth, and other things. 
    No person shall, or allow, by sweeping, raking, mechanically blowing, or by any other means, other than by nature, place or deposit leaves or other discarded material, onto any street, alley or public way. 
    Leaves or other discarded material piled in the street will be presumed to have originated from the adjacent property unless facts and circumstances indicate otherwise. 
    The person residing on or controlling the property which is adjacent to the street, and on the same side of the street, as the discarded material is located in a pile or in such quantity as to indicate it was placed there in violation of this ordinance will be deemed responsible for violating this section unless facts and circumstances indicate otherwise. 
(Code 1978, § 525.840; Ord. No. 6662, § 1, 10-25-94) 
Sec. 21-11. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section I of Ord. No. 98-52, adopted July 28, 1998, repealed § 21-11 in its entirety. Formerly, § 21-11 pertained to the prohibition of roller skating on streets and derived from § 240.630B of the 1978 Code and § 7(20) of Ord. No. 6142, adopted Sept. 13, 1988. 
Sec. 21-12. - Play vehicles. 
    No person shall use any toy bicycle, wagon, toy car or other toy vehicle on any streets or roadway except for crossing a street or roadway. Any parent, guardian or person taking care of a child who knowingly permits any child to violate this section shall be guilty of violating this section. 
(Ord. No. 6324, § 1, 5-14-91) 
Sec. 21-13. - Recreational equipment in streets or rights-of-way. 
    No person shall erect or place either permanently or temporarily any recreational equipment in a street or street right-of-way of the city. This shall include, but not be limited to, such devices as basketball goals, soccer nets, tennis nets and baseball backstops. 
(Ord. No. 6324, § 2, 5-14-91) 
Sec. 21-14. - Skateboarding. 
(a)  No person shall operate a skateboard or similar device upon any street or sidewalk in an area zoned as district D, local business district, or district E, general business district, within the city, nor shall any person operate a skateboard or similar device upon any sidewalk adjacent to nonresidential property within the city unless granted permission by the adjacent property owner. It shall not be a violation of this subsection if the person operates the skateboard upon the city street; as a mode of transportation from a point A to point B, not for recreation, and operates the skateboard in safe and prudent manner. 
(b)  No person shall operate any skateboard or similar device upon any private property or school property unless specifically granted permission by the owner or possessor of such property. In addition to penalties set by the general penalty ordinance of the Carthage Code, any person found in violation of this section may have his or her skateboard impounded for a period of up to thirty (30) days. 
(Ord. No. 6376, § 1, 12-10-91; Ord. No. 6432, § 1, 7-14-92; Ord. No. 6451, § 1, 10-13-92; Ord. No. 16-03, § I, 1-26-2016) 
Cross reference- Traffic, Ch. 23; zoning, Ch. 25; district D, § 25-551 et seq.; district E, § 25-601 et seq. 
Secs. 21-15-21-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - GRADES AND ELEVATIONS 

Sec. 21-26. - Recording. 
(a)  The grades of the streets and alleys of the city shall be established by recording, in a book to be kept for that purpose, the elevation at the intersection of streets and alleys, which book shall also contain a record of acts or ordinances of the council in relation to, or in any way affecting, the established grade of any street or alley. 
(b)  The book in which the record is kept shall be labeled "City Grade Book." The city clerk shall be the custodian thereof, and it shall be his duty to enter thereon all record matter required by this article. The book shall be a public record. 
(c)  All grade elevations shall be recorded in figures designating the whole number of foot, the tenths, hundredths, and thousandths, of the foot which manner of designating the grade elevation of the city shall be used in all returns, certificates and other papers or acts relating to the grade, of any street or alley in the city. 
(d)  In lieu of a city grade book, plans and specifications shall be designed and kept on file by the city engineer. These plans and specifications shall be a public record. 
(Code 1978, §§ 540.010-540.030; Ord. No. 6142, § 7(26), 9-13-88; Ord. No. 6173, § 1, 2-28-89) 
Sec. 21-27. - Elevation of corners. 
    All corners at any intersection of streets embracing the full width of the sidewalk thereof shall bear a uniform elevation, except when otherwise provided, and whenever it shall be deemed expedient not to bring all the corners of any intersection to the same elevation, that the elevation of each corner at such intersection shall be given. 
(Code 1978, § 540.040) 
Sec. 21-28. - Uniformity of grades. 
    All grades shall extend in unbroken uniformity from intersection, to intersection, except when otherwise provided by ordinances. Whenever the grade of any street is broken between intersections, the elevations at such break shall be given, together with the exact distance thereof from one (1) or the other relative intersections. 
(Code 1978, § 540.050) 
Sec. 21-29. - Location of benchmarks. 
    The benchmark bearing the datum of the grade elevation of the city is located at the southwest corner of Third Street and Main Street, and is fixed on the base stone of the west side of the entrance to the Bank of Carthage and designated by a copper plug set in the top of the base stone. 
(Code 1978, § 540.060) 
Sec. 21-30. - Datum elevation. 
    The datum elevation of the city is 152.68 feet, and the bench bearing such elevation, located at the point designated in this article, consists of a Carthage limestone base at the west side of the entrance to the Bank of Carthage; and the point on such base stone marking the exact datum shall be a copper plug set in the top of such stone, and the top of such copper plug shall bear the letters C.G.D. and the character "O." 
(Code 1978, § 540.070) 
Sec. 21-31. - Elevations to be established from benchmark. 
    All elevations of grades shall be established from the benchmark bearing the grade datum of the city, and no other bench shall be used unless it shall have been located permanently and established from the datum benchmark, and its locality and description recorded in the city grade book. 
(Code 1978, § 540.080) 
Sec. 21-32. - Engineer to make returns to council. 
    The city engineer shall make returns to the council of all work ordered to be done by him, certifying to the council of all work ordered to be done by him certifying to the correctness of the same and designating in the return and certificate the benchmark from which he started. After the certificate and return has been passed upon by the council it shall be recorded within the city grade book. 
(Code 1978, § 540.090) 
Secs. 21-33-21-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - STREET IMPROVEMENTS, REPAIRS, ETC. 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 21-51. - Cost estimate. 
(a)  Whenever the council desires to bring to grade any street, avenue, alley, or portion thereof, or to build and construct any bridge, culvert, alley or portion thereof, or to build and construct any bridge, the costs of which is required by law to be paid out of the general revenue fund of the city, except sidewalk and other temporary repairs, the council shall instruct the city engineer to make an estimate of the cost of the proposed improvements; the engineer shall, without delay, make such estimate and submit the same, with proper specifications, to the council. If such estimate is to bring to grade any street, avenue, alley, or other highway, it shall include the grading and filling of all approaches thereto, at intersecting streets and alleys, and the grading and filling of said approaches shall be let with the grading of the proposed street, avenue, alley or other highway. 
(b)  The city engineer shall number consecutively each estimate made and submitted by him to the council and shall keep a record of such estimates in proper order in a book to be provided and kept for that purpose. 
(Code 1978, §§ 525.010, 525.060) 
Sec. 21-52. - Advertisement for bids; specifications; contractor bond. 
(a)  If the estimate of the city engineer under section 21-51 exceeds two thousand dollars ($2,000.00), and the council desires to proceed with the work, it shall direct the city engineer to advertise for bids therefor, stating the manner in which and the place where such advertisement shall be published, and such advertisement shall set for the exact date and time of the meeting of the council at which such bids as may be received shall be opened. If the council decides to accept any bid made, it shall accept the same (provided it does not exceed the estimate of the engineer), and enter into a contract with the successful bidder. The specifications shall be made a part of the contract, and the work to be done under the contract shall be done in accordance with such specifications, within a time to be set forth in the contract, and without any negligence on the part of the contractor resulting in damage to any property or injury to any person. 
(b)  Before any contract as provided in subsection (a) becomes binding upon the city, the contractor shall execute and file with the city clerk a bond, with good and sufficient security, to be approved by the mayor. Such bond shall be conditioned that the contractor will faithfully complete the contract, in accordance with the specifications and within the time fixed in the contract, that he will pay for all labor employed and materials used in the work to be done thereunder, and that he will indemnify and save harmless the city from any and all claims arising from, or as a result of, such work. 
(Code 1978, § 525.020) 
Sec. 21-53. - Improvements less than two thousand dollars. 
    In cases where the estimate of the city engineer under section 21-51 is less than two thousand dollars ($2,000.00), the council may direct the street commissioner to do the work, or to enter into a contract, upon the best terms he can secure, for the execution of the proposed work. In no case shall the contract price exceed the estimate of the city engineer. 
(Code 1978, § 525.030) 
Sec. 21-54. - Emergency improvements. 
    In cases of emergency, where life or limb are endangered, or commerce or travel are impeded, the street commissioner and city engineer shall have authority to make such temporary repairs to streets, avenues, alleys and bridges or erect such barricades as will remove or prevent such danger, and report the same to the council at its next meeting. 
(Code 1978, § 525.040) 
Sec. 21-55. - Supervision of work; reports to council. 
    All work under the contracts entered into as provided for in this division shall be carried on under the supervision of the city engineer or street commissioner, as may be provided by the council. Such person shall personally inspect the work as it progresses and see that the same is done in accordance with the contract and the specifications governing the same. Upon completion thereof, if in the opinion of the city engineer, the terms of the contract have been fully complied with, he shall so report to the city council. If the council receives and approves the report, such approval shall be deemed an acceptance of the work by the council under the contract, and the council shall thereupon provide by ordinance for the payment therefor in the manner provided by law. 
(Code 1978, § 525.050) 
Sec. 21-56. - Contract changes. 
    No change shall be made in any contract or specifications therefor under this division, except with the consent of the contractor, and of the council, as expressed by a majority vote in favor of the change. The street commissioner, city engineer, or any other city official having charge of or superintending any such work, is hereby expressly prohibited from directing, consenting to or permitting any work to be done in any different manner than as provided by the contract therefor. 
(Code 1978, § 525.070) 
Sec. 21-57. - Bonds and contracts to be approved by mayor and council. 
    All bonds and contracts received under the provisions of this division shall be submitted to the mayor and council for approval, and safely kept on file in the office of the city clerk. 
(Code 1978, § 525.080) 
Secs. 21-58-21-66. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - STREET PAVING[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Street improvements generally, RSMo 88.507 et seq. 

Sec. 21-67. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Pave means all kinds of street paving, including macadamizing. 
    Roadway part of any street means all that part of the street between the curblines. 
(Code 1978, § 525.100) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 88.507. 
Sec. 21-68. - Council to order engineer to make estimate. 
    Whenever the city council shall deem it necessary to grade or pave any alley or to grade, pave or gutter the roadway of any street, or any part thereof or connection therewith, including the squares and area formed by the crossing or meeting of streets or other highways, or parts thereof or connections therewith, the cost of which is authorized, or required to be levied as a special assessment upon the lots or pieces of ground abutting upon either side of such street, alley or other highway in proportion to the fronting or abutting feet, the council shall first make an estimate of the costs thereof, and to submit the same to the council, together with the specification of the proposed improvement. 
(Code 1978, § 525.110) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 88.520. 
Sec. 21-69. - Council to adopt estimate. 
    Upon the filing of the estimate and specifications referred to in section 21-68, if the same shall be found satisfactory, the council shall adopt the same by an order of record. 
(Code 1978, § 525.120) 
Sec. 21-70. - Resolution of necessity and protests; bid advertisements. 
(a)  Upon the adoption of the estimate and specifications as provided in this division the council shall, by resolution, declare that it deems such improvement necessary to be made. If the proposed improvement includes the bringing to the established grade any street, alley, or other highway, then the resolution shall include and describe the work of bringing such street, alley, or other highway, square, or area so formed to the established grade. 
(b)  Upon the adoption of the resolution, the council shall cause it to be published, in the newspaper doing the city printing for two (2) consecutive insertions, if a weekly paper, or seven (7) consecutive insertions if a daily paper. If a majority of the resident owners of lands or lots that would be liable for the costs of the improvement, at the date of the passage of the resolution, who own a majority of the front feet abutting on the street, alley, or other highway, or part thereof, proposed to be improved, shall not, within ten (10) days after the date of the last publication, file with the city clerk their protest against such improvement, then the council shall be empowered to proceed to have such improvement made. 
(c)  The city engineer shall be directed to advertise for bids therefor in the newspaper doing the city printing, stating the manner in which the work is required to be done and the time when, and place where, bids will be opened. The advertisement shall be published not less than one (1) week prior to the opening of the bids, and all bids shall be opened and read in the presence of the council in open session. All advertisements for bids shall advise bidders that the payment for the proposed work will be made, in tax bills issued at the contractor's expense, and that the city reserves the right to reject any and all bids. 
(d)  If there are no bids received for the improvement, upon advertisement therefor, or if for any reason all bids shall be rejected, the council may direct the engineer to readvertise for bids, as in the first instance. 
(Code 1978, §§ 525.130, 525.140, 525.170) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 88.520. 
Sec. 21-71. - Awarding of contracts. 
    It shall be the duty of the council, upon the opening of the bids made pursuant to this division to award the contract to the lowest and best bidder, but the right is reserved to the council to reject any and all bids. No contract shall be let or made for a price in excess of the estimate of the engineer, previously filed and adopted by the council. 
(Code 1978, § 525.150) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 88.520. 
Sec. 21-72. - Contractor's bond. 
    The council shall have the power, upon making and entering into a contract for an improvement, to require the contractor doing the work to enter into a bond, in an amount to be designated by the council, conditioned that the improvement, when made, will last for a term of years specified by the contract, and that during such term of years the contractor will keep the improved street or other highway in repair, the contractor shall further be required to give a bond in the amount of the contract, with good and sufficient security, and conditioned that he will faithfully and completely comply with all the conditions of said contract, that he will pay for all materials furnished or used and all labors employed in and upon the work to be done under the contract, and for the faithful performance of all obligations, which bond shall be submitted to the council for approval, and, if approved and accepted, filed with the city clerk. 
(Code 1978, § 525.160) 
State Law reference- Authority to require bond, RSMo 88.520. 
Sec. 21-73. - Supervision of work. 
    All work entered into under contract as provided in this division shall be carried on and done under the supervision of the city engineer and street commissioner. Such officers shall personally inspect the work as it progresses and see that the same is done in accordance with the specifications and contract. Upon completion of the work, it shall be the duty of the contractor to notify the city engineer of the completion, upon which notification the city engineer and street commissioner shall make a final inspection. 
(Code 1978, § 525.180) 
Sec. 21-74. - Apportionment of costs. 
    It shall be the duty of the city engineer, upon the completion of work under this division and after final inspection thereof has been made, if such improvement is found to have been made in accordance with the contract and specifications, to compute the cost thereof and apportion the cost among the tracts of land chargeable therewith, charging each tract of land with its proportionate part of the cost. The city engineer shall make a written report to the council, stating that the improvement has been completed in accordance with the contract, containing a description of each lot or tract of land chargeable with a part of the cost of the improvement, and setting forth the amount with which each lot or tract is to be charged. The report shall be accepted by the council if it is found to be true and satisfactory. 
(Code 1978, § 525.190) 
Sec. 21-75. - Levying of costs. 
    Upon the acceptance of the report of the city engineer under section 21-74, the council shall, by ordinance, levy the cost of the improvement, as evidenced by the contract, as a special assessment upon all the lots and pieces of ground upon either side of and abutting on, such improved street, avenue, alley, or other highway, or part thereof, or connection therewith, in proportion to the front feet; and assess the cost of paving or macadamizing the squares and areas formed by the crossing or meeting of streets or avenues with the improvement against the lots in each block liable by law for such assessment. Each lot and piece of ground shall be charged with its proper share of the amount due, and the mayor and city clerk shall be directed to issue special tax bills for the respective amounts. 
(Code 1978, § 525.200) 
State Law reference- Authority to collect as special assessment, RSMo 88.507, 88.812. 
Sec. 21-76. - Special tax bill-Contents. 
    Each tax bill made under this division shall contain a brief general statement of the facts authorizing its issue, the amount for which it is issued and the name of the contractor to whom it is issued, the rate of interest which it bears, and the date on which such interest commences, and a statement that such tax bill is a special lien against the land described, giving the time such lien commences. 
(Code 1978, § 525.210) 
Sec. 21-77. - Same-Interest; term of lien. 
(a)  Special tax bills under this division shall bear no interest for thirty (30) days after their date, but after the expiration of the thirty (30) days they shall bear interest at the rate of eight (8) percent per annum, unless the council shall, by ordinance, fix a different rate of interest, but no rate fixed by the city shall exceed eight (8) percent per annum. Every tax bill shall be a lien, for a term of five (5) years from and after its date, against the land described therein, unless sooner paid. The lien of tax bills payable in installments, shall not expire until one (1) year after the date of the maturity of the last installment. 
(b)  If any parcel of land is made the subject of more than one (1) special tax bill for curb and guttering and/or paving within a three-year period, the city shall pay interest to the contractor on any unpaid balance for a period of three (3) years from the date of issuance of the second or any subsequent tax bill. 
(Code 1978, § 525.220) 
Sec. 21-78. - Same-Assignment, etc. 
    Special tax bills authorized by this division shall be assignable, and the owner or holder of any such tax bill may enforce the collection thereof by an action in any court of competent jurisdiction; and in all actions thereon, the tax bill shall be prima facie evidence of its own validity, and of the facts authorizing its issue, and that it is a special lien on the land described in it. In any case where it becomes necessary to bring a suit to enforce the lien of any tax bills herein authorized, the lien of such tax bills shall continue until the expiration of the litigation. 
(Code 1978, § 525.260) 
Sec. 21-79. - Same-Records. 
    The city clerk shall keep a record, in a book provided for that purpose, of all tax bills issued by the city which record shall show the date and amount of each tax bill under this division, the rate of interest it bears, a description of the land against which it was issued, the name of the party to whom it was issued, the street or part of street, alley, or other highway improved and the nature of the improvement. When a tax bill has been paid, and is presented to the city clerk, marked, paid, he shall keep on the record the satisfaction of such tax bill. 
(Code 1976, § 525.230) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 88.818. 
Sec. 21-80. - Same-Correction of errors. 
(a)  Any error that may be made in issuing any special tax bill under this division may be corrected by the city clerk who issued it, or his successor in office, either by interlineation or by issuing a new tax bill in lieu of the erroneous one. When a tax bill is corrected by interlineation, the date of the making of such interlineation shall be certified by the clerk on the margin, or on the back of the bills. 
(b)  In action brought on any tax bill, the court shall have the power to correct any error in the amount of the tax bill. In case it may be shown that the work done was not of the standard required by the contract, the court may give judgment for the reasonable value of the work chargeable against the land described in the tax bill. 
(Code 1978, §§ 525.270, 525.280) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 88.814. 
Sec. 21-81. - Payment of costs. 
(a)  The cost of grading, paving, curbing or guttering any street, alley, or other highway, may be paid in ten (10) annual installments, payable respectively in one (1), two (2), three (3), four (4), five (5), six (6), seven (7), eight (8), nine (9) and ten (10) years after the date of the tax bill, each installment to be in an amount equal to one-tenth of the original amount of the tax bill, together with all of the then-accrued interest. 
(b)  In order that the owner of any tract of land chargeable with part of the cost of any improvement may avail himself of the privilege of paying the same in installments, he shall within thirty (30) days after letting of the contract for the improvement notify the city clerk, in writing, that he desires to pay the tax bill to be issued against his property. In such case the special tax bill shall be payable in installments as herein provided, and it shall provide that if any installment is not paid when due, the remaining unpaid installments shall, at the option of the holder of the same, immediately become due and payable provided, the owner of the land against which any installment tax bill is issued shall have the privilege of paying the full amount thereof, with accrued interest to date of payment, on any installment paying date. 
(Code 1978, §§ 525.240, 525.250) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 88.816. 
Sec. 21-82. - Installation of utilities prior to paying. 
    No paving shall be commenced on any street in the city unless all municipal utilities and services are brought to a point inside the curbline. 
(Code 1978, § 525.830) 
Secs. 21-83-21-93. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - MACADAMIZING 

Sec. 21-94. - Generally. 
    Whenever the council shall provide for the macadamizing of the roadway of any street, alley, or other highway, or part thereof, or connection therewith, the same shall, unless otherwise provided by ordinance, be macadamized to the full width thereof, except the parts occupied by, or designated for, sidewalks, curbing and guttering, and the work shall be done in the following manner: 
(1)  The council shall first provide and cause the street, alley or other highway, or part thereof or connection therewith, intended to be macadamized, to be graded to the subgrade line below the grade line as established by ordinance. 
(2)  All earth or other material excavated shall be used, if the city engineer so directs, for the filling or grading of that part of the street upon which the improvement is to be made, and shall be placed so as to make a solid foundation and to prevent the settling of the macadam when placed thereon. 
(3)  All excavated material, except as herein provided, shall be left to the disposition of the contractor. 
(Code 1978, § 525.290) 
Sec. 21-95. - Inclusion of grading and excavating in contract. 
(a)  All grading or excavating necessary for bringing the street, alley or other highway, to the required grade shall be included in the special assessment to be levied, and the tax bill to be issued, for the macadamizing. 
(b)  When the street being improved has a street or other railway track or tracks thereon, the company owning such tracks shall, at its expense, improve that portion of the roadway lying between its rails and not less than twelve (12) inches on each side thereof (or for such distance on each side as may be provided in the contract or franchise, if greater than twelve (12) inches); and the property abutting on the improved street shall be charged only with the expense of improving that portion of the roadway lying between the curbline and the edge of the improvement made by the railway company, as provided herein. 
(Code 1978, § 525.300) 
Sec. 21-96. - Specifications. 
(a)  The macadamizing provided for in this division shall be done in the following manner, unless otherwise ordered by the council: 
(1)  The surface of the roadway indicated upon the plans to be macadamized shall be excavated street, and ten (10) inches below, at the sides of the street, and parallel with the established grade. 
(2)  The cross section thereof shall conform in every respect to the cross section of the macadamized street when completed, as shown by the plans, except at street or alley crossings or intersections, or at points which there exists a difference in level between a railroad track and the curbs, or between opposite curbs, in which case the excavation may be increased or decreased, not exceeding six (6) inches, from the established grade thereof, as the city engineer may direct, in order to ensure the proper drainage of the finished street. 
(3)  The excavation four (4) inches below and parallel with the established grade shall be made on and along those portions of the street where the subgrade falls below the natural surface, and for the full width of the street between the curblines; and at such other places or portions of the street, alley, or other highway, or parts thereof, or connections therewith, as shall be indicated upon the plans for doing the work. 
(4)  The surface of the subgrade shall be dressed to a smooth and even surface, with no large stones remaining thereon. 
(5)  If any place in the subgrade there shall be soft or loosely filled places, the same shall be rammed or rolled until the surface is solid and thoroughly compact. 
(6)  All fills, or embankments shall be composed of such materials and made in such a manner as will insure the greatest possible solidity and compactness. 
(b)  The gravel or tailings used for macadamizing shall be of good, uniform quality, and shall contain not less than seven (7) percent and not more than twenty (20) percent dirt or sand; and no pieces of gravel or tailings shall be used which will not pass through a ring two and one-half (21/2) inches in diameter. 
(Code 1978, § 525.310) 
Sec. 21-97. - Subgrade requirements. 
    Upon the subgrade prepared pursuant to section 21-96 there shall be spread a layer of hand-jigged tailings, mine tailing, or river gravel, as may have been directed by the council, six (6) inches thick in the center of the street, and three (3) inches thick at the sides thereof, which shall be spread evenly and conform to the plans and cross sections of the street on file in the city clerk's office. 
(Code 1978, § 525.320) 
Secs. 21-98-21-110. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - SIDEWALK, CURB AND GUTTER CONSTRUCTION OR REPAIR[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Sections I and II of Ord. No. 99-52, adopted June 22, 1999, amended Art. IV in its entirety, in effect repealing §§ 21-111-21-115 and 21-123-21-143 and reenacting §§ 21-111-21-115, 21-123-21-145, and 21-150-21-155 as herein set out. Former Art. IV pertained to similar subject matter and derived from §§ 525.460, 525.480-525.510, and 525.530-525.710 of the 1979 Code. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 21-111. - Scope. 
    This article applies to the construction and repair of sidewalks, curbs and gutters. 
(Ord. No. 99-52, § II, 6-22-99) 
Sec. 21-112. - Grading and excavation. 
    All grading and excavating necessary in the construction of sidewalks, curbs or gutters, unless the grading of that portion of the roadway has been done previously, may be included in the same contract with the sidewalks, curbs or gutters, as required by law, and the cost thereof, if included in the contract, may be included in the special tax bills issued for the payment of the improvement. 
(Ord. No. 99-52, § II, 6-22-99) 
Sec. 21-113. - Litter removal. 
    The contractor shall, before the work is accepted under this article, remove therefrom all rocks, broken stone, litter or trash of any kind, and leave the meet, parkway, sidewalk, curb, curb stone, gutter, and work in good condition, and ready for use. 
(Ord. No. 99-52, § II, 6-22-99) 
Sec. 21-114. - Acceptance of work. 
(a)  All sidewalks, curbs, gutters, and private driveways, shall be constructed on the true grade, curb and cross section lines of the meets along and upon which they may be ordered, and shall be done under the supervision of the city engineer, the street commissioner, and the committee on streets and alleys. After the work is finished, the city engineer or the street commissioner, shall pass on the sidewalks, curbs, gutters, or private driveways constructed as to the quality of the work done, and acceptance by either of them shall be final. 
(b)  No sidewalk, curb, gutter, or other improvement herein mentioned, which does not meet the specifications herein prescribed, shall be accepted. On sidewalk, curb, or gutter construction, where opposite curbs differ in elevation or vary from the tree grade or where improvements already built do not conform to the established grade, or where necessary for drainage, the engineer may order or allow a variation of up to six (6) inches from the established grade. 
(Ord. No. 99-52, § II, 6-22-99) 
Sec. 21-115. - Private driveways. 
    Private driveways shall be paved back from the curbing in the same manner as the gutters constructed in front of the property to be served by the driveway, rising to the sidewalk. The upper surface of the driveway from thence to the outside street line shall be made to conform to the grade of the sidewalk, and shall be paved with crushed stone, brick, asphalt, or concrete. 
(a)  Any person desiring to construct or reconstruct any driveway shall, before commencing the work, apply to and obtain from the public works director a permit therefor, which permit shall be in writing, and shall specify a time within which said work shall be completed; and the driveway shall be constructed or reconstructed out of the materials, and in accordance with the plans and specifications prescribed by the ordinances of the city for the building of driveways, and constructed under the supervision of the public works director and streets commissioner. 
(b)  Upon obtaining a permit as provided by this section, the person therein authorized to construct or reconstruct a driveway shall present the same to the public works director and streets commissioner, who shall inspect the construction or reconstruction of the driveway when the same is completed, according to the specifications therefor. The public works director and streets commissioner shall not approve any driveway which has not been built in accordance with the plans and specifications prescribed by the ordinances of the city. 
(c)  If an application as submitted to the public works director under the provisions of this section shall be for work acceptable to and in conformity with this section, then the public works director is hereby authorized to issue a permit for such work upon the payment of the applicable fee as established in a schedule adopted by ordinance from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 99-52, § II, 6-22-99; Ord. No. 06-08, § I, 1-24-2006) 
Secs. 21-116-21-122. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - SIDEWALK CONSTRUCTION AND REPAIR[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Sidewalk construction and repair, RSMo 88.863 et seq. 

Sec. 21-123. - Definitions. 
(a)  In this article, the term "approaches" means the extension of sidewalks, at corner lots or tracts, from the property line, each way, to the street curbline, making the connection across the parkway, or intervening space between the corner of the property and the street crossing. 
(b)  In this article, the words "city engineer" and the words "street commissioner" shall mean any person appointed, authorized or employed by the city council to exercise and perform the duties and functions commonly appertaining to such officers. 
(c)  In this article, the words, "right-of-way" shall mean all that area dedicated to the public, by ordinance, for use as a street, thoroughfare, alley, or utility easement. 
(Ord. No. 99-52, § II, 6-22-99) 
Sec. 21-124. - Scope. 
    This division applies to the construction and repair of sidewalks. 
(Ord. No. 99-52, § II, 6-22-99) 
Sec. 21-125. - Construction specifications for sidewalks. 
(a)  Concrete specifications-Sidewalks without driveways. 
(1)  Three thousand five hundred (3,500) psi. 
(2)  Expansion joint every fifty (50) feet. 
(3)  Control joints every five (5) feet. 
(4)  Non-skid surface (i.e., broom finish). 
(5)  Curb ramps for disabled access shall be provided in accordance with the Americans with Disabilities Act. 
(6)  A minimum slump of four (4) inches and a maximum of five (5) inches is recommended. 
(7)  The minimum width shall be as originally constructed or as determined by the city engineer. 
(8)  Minimum depth shall be four (4) inches. 
(b)  Concrete specifications-Sidewalks across driveways; over storm sewers or other openings. 
(1)  Three thousand five hundred (3,500) psi. 
(2)  Expansion joint every five (50) feet. 
(3)  Control joints every five (5) feet. 
(4)  Non-skid surface (i.e., broom finish). 
(5)  Curb ramps for disabled access shall be provided in accordance with the Americans with Disabilities Act. 
(6)  A minimum slump of four (4) inches and a maximum of five (5) inches is recommended. 
(7)  The minimum width shall be as originally constructed or as determined by the city engineer. 
(8)  Minimum depth shall be six (6) inches. 
(9)  Reinforcement as required by the city engineer, such as wire mesh, steel rebar, or steel plating. 
(c)  Specifications for concrete and clay brick pavers. 
(1)  Concrete pavers shall be hydraulically pressed concrete of not less than eight thousand (8,000) psi. 
(2)  A minimum of a three-inch layer of concrete sand shall be used as base material. 
(3)  Clean, coarse, concrete sand shall be used as joint fill between the pavers. 
(4)  Pavers shall be tamped and leveled with a mechanical vibrator until units are firmly bedded. 
(5)  After first vibration, sand shall be added to surface and vibrated into joints. Re-cover joints with additional sand until finn joints are achieved. 
(6)  All pavers shall meet gradient and elevation requirements. 
(7)  All pavers shall meet requirements of the Americans with Disabilities Act. 
(d)  Specifications for sawed limestone, stone slab, or marble slab sidewalks. 
(1)  Stone, limestone, or marble slabs shall only be accepted or approved for sidewalk materials when it is necessary to preserve the historical significance of the abutting property; and when it is necessary to replace existing stone slab sidewalks that have been damaged or destroyed which will not meet any and all applicable city codes. 
(2)  If a stone slab surface exists, and approved for construction or replacement, it must be replaced with stone which will substantially conform in color, texture, and thickness and width to the stone slab surfaces which were removed or immediately adjoined the repaired or replaced public sidewalk (in order to retain the ambiance of the sawed limestone or marble slab sidewalks). If a stone surface has become so smooth that a slick walking surface results, the stone surface must be re-textured, sand blasted, or pressure washed, in order to eliminate any and all existing hazards. 
(e)  Sidewalk width. 
(1)  The minimum width of sidewalks in residential subdivisions shall be four (4) feet, except where otherwise approved, based on the proximity of the sidewalk to the roadway, the volume and speed of traffic, expected number of pedestrians or other safety factors. 
(2)  The minimum width of sidewalks in commercial subdivisions shall be six (6) feet, except where otherwise approved, based on the proximity of the sidewalk to the roadway, the volume and speed of traffic, expected number of pedestrians or other safety factors. 
(Ord. No. 99-52, § II, 6-22-99; Ord. No. 12-44, § II, 10-9-2012) 
Sec. 21-126. - Reconstruction of condemned sidewalks. 
    When any sidewalk which has been, or may hereafter be constructed on any street, avenue, or other public highway in the city, has been condemned by the city engineer, as provided by law, it shall be the duty of the owner of the lot or tract of ground fronting or abutting thereon to construct or reconstruct the sidewalk and the property owner shall be required to grade, fill or park that portion of the street, avenue, or other public highway lying between his property line and the street curbline, and construct the necessary approaches thereto, in the same manner as required by the city engineer and as specified in the Americans with Disabilities Act. 
(Ord. No. 99-52, § II, 6-22-99) 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to condemn sidewalks, RSMo 88.873. 
Sec. 21-127. - Owners to keep in good repair. 
    It shall be the duty of the property owners owning property along and in front of which sidewalks have been, or may hereafter be, constructed, to keep such sidewalks in good repair at all times. In case they fail to do so the sidewalks may be repaired by the city as provided in this division. The property owners shall be subject to the penalty provided by section 21-128, and the cost of the repairs shall be assessed as a special tax against the property abutting thereon, as hereinafter provided. 
(Ord. No. 99-52, § II, 6-22-99) 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to so provide, RSMo 88.877. 
Sec. 21-128. - Penalties for violation by owners. 
    Any person upon whom or which has been served an order of the city engineer to construct or reconstruct any sidewalk, to make necessary repairs to a sidewalk, as hereinbefore provided, who shall fail, neglect or refuse to comply, within the time fixed by the council or in the order, with the requirements of the order, shall on conviction be punished by a fine of not less than five dollars ($5.00) and not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(Ord. No. 99-52, § II, 6-22-99) 
State Law reference- Limitations on penalties, RSMo 88.877. 
Sec. 21-129. - Owners to bear expense. 
    All sidewalks shall be constructed, reconstructed, or repaired at the expense of the owners of lots or tracts of ground fronting or abutting thereon, and in conformity with the ordinances of the city regulating the same. 
(Ord. No. 99-52, § II, 6-22-99) 
Sec. 21-130. - City engineer to order construction; notice to owners. 
    Before proceeding against any property owner for failure, neglect or refusal to construct or reconstruct any sidewalk, under the provisions of this division, or before the city engineer shall proceed to construct or reconstruct the sidewalk, the city engineer shall make a written order, requiring and directing the property owner to construct or reconstruct the sidewalk, stating in order the kind of materials to be used, the width of the sidewalk, the legal description of the property along or abutting on which the sidewalk is to be constructed or reconstructed, the name of the owner thereof, and the time within which such order must be completed with fully, which time shall not be less than thirty (30) days from the date on which the order is served. The city engineer shall immediately serve the notice upon the property owner named in the order by (a) delivering to the owner personally; (b) sending by certified or registered mail addressed to the owner at the last known address with return receipt requested. If the certified or register letter is returned showing that the letter was not delivered, a copy thereof shall be posted in a conspicuous place in or about the area of the sidewalk affected by such notice. Service of such notice in the foregoing manner upon the owner's agent or upon the person responsible for the sidewalk shall constitute service of notice upon the owner. 
(Ord. No. 99-52, § II, 6-22-99) 
Sec. 21-131. - Duties of city engineer. 
    It shall be the duty of the city engineer or his appointed agent to inspect any sidewalk, upon receiving notice that such sidewalk is in need of repair. When the city engineer finds any sidewalk out of repair, it shall be his duty immediately to serve, an order, in writing, upon the owner or owners of the property abutting thereon to proceed to repair the sidewalk; and if the property owner shall fail, neglect or refuse to make the repairs within the time specified in the written order, then the city engineer shall proceed to order such repairs, by competitive bidding, and report the same to the council for assessment. Upon the receipt of the report of the city engineer the cost of the repairs shall be assessed as a special tax upon the lot or tract of ground fronting or abutting on the sidewalk so repaired, and the tax shall be collected as hereinafter provided. In all cases where the city engineer shall find repairs on any sidewalk necessary, and the owner of the property abutting thereon shall be unknown, or a nonresident of the city then the city engineer may proceed by a written order to repair as provided by section 21-130. 
(Ord. No. 99-52, § II, 6-22-99) 
Sec. 21-132. - Council may order construction; special assessment for cost. 
    When in the judgement of the majority of the members of the council, the construction or reconstruction of any sidewalk shall be deemed necessary, or upon the petition of any ten (10) citizens of the city, the council may, by ordinance, order and provide for the construction or reconstruction of any sidewalk, by contract, including in the contract all necessary grading and filling, the removal of any obstruction, the necessary approaches of corner lots or tracts, and the grading or parking of that portion of the street lying between the property line and the street curbline. The council may levy a special assessment against each lot or tract of ground abutting on the street on which the work is done for the cost of the improvements. No such contract shall be let until the plans and specifications for said work have been adopted by ordinance which adoption may be by reference to the general plans and specifications for same. 
(Ord. No. 99-52, § II, 6-22-99) 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to so provide, RSMo 88.883. 
Sec. 21-133. - Engineer to prepare estimate of costs. 
    Upon the passage and approval of an ordinance for the construction or reconstruction, by contract, of any sidewalk in the city, it shall be the duty of the city engineer immediately to prepare and file in the office of the city clerk an estimate of the cost per square yard, of the improvement, including all necessary grading and filling, removal of any obstruction, construction of necessary approaches, and materials to be used. The estimate shall show each lot or tract fronting or abutting upon the sidewalk to be improved, and the estimated cost, per cubic yard, for each such lot or tract. No contract shall be let in which the bid exceeds the estimate of the engineer, by more than ten (10) percent. 
(Ord. No. 99-52, § II, 6-22-99) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 88.887. 
Sec. 21-134. - Advertisement for bids. 
    No contract shall be let for the construction or reconstruction of any sidewalk as provided by this division, until an advertisement for bids for the doing of the work shall have been published in at least two (2) consecutive issues of the daily paper doing the city printing, and the date of the opening of the bids shall be set at least ten (10) days after the date of the first advertisement. 
(Ord. No. 99-52, § II, 6-22-99) 
State Law reference- Advertisement for bids, RSMo 88.887. 
Sec. 21-135. - Contract to be let by ordinance. 
    All bids required by this division shall be opened in the presence of the city engineer, and the council shall let the contract for the work by ordinance, to the lowest and most responsible bidder. In case there are no bids, or that all the bids are rejected, the council may order a re-advertisement for bids. 
(Ord. No. 99-52, § II, 6-22-99) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 88.880. 
Sec. 21-136. - Special assessment for costs. 
    When any sidewalk has been constructed or reconstructed as ordered by the city engineer, as herein provided, the council shall pay all costs of the work out of any fund available for the purpose. Upon the completion of the work, and its acceptance by the city engineer, the council, may by ordinance, levy the cost thereof as a special assessment against each lot or tract of ground fronting or abutting on the sidewalk or other improvement, in the manner hereinafter provided. 
(Ord. No. 99-52, § II, 6-22-99) 
Cross reference- Municipal authority to so provide, RSMo 88.880. 
Sec. 21-137. - Special assessments. 
    The cost of any of the work or improvements provided for by this division that are made and done either by contractor or as required by the city engineer or other proper person acting for the city, shall be levied as a special assessment against the lot, tract or parcel of ground along and in front of which the improvement is made. The cost of the approaches shall be levied as a special assessment against the corner lots which the approaches abut and connect with. The assessment shall be levied by ordinance, in which ordinance shall be set out separately the number and title of the ordinance under authority of which the work will be done, a separate description of each lot, tract or parcel of ground assessed, the name of the owner thereof, the number of front feet therein abutting on the improvement, the separate items of cost of the improvement and the total amount thereof. The assessment ordinance shall further provide for the making out of tax bills by the city engineer, or other proper person therein designated, in evidence of said assessments, payable to the contractor doing the work, and for the delivery of the tax bills in payment for the work, or if the work was done by the city engineer or other person acting for the city, the tax bills shall be made payable to such engineer or other person and for and to the use of the city, and shall be collected the same as other tax bills. 
(Ord. No. 99-52, § II, 6-22-99) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 88.890. 
Sec. 21-138. - Tax bills-Generally. 
    Separate tax bills shall be issued against each lot or tract of ground against which an assessment under this division has been made, and shall state therein the name of the owner of the lot or tract fronting or abutting upon the improvement, the number of the improvement ordinance under which the work was done, the number of the assessment ordinance under which the tax bill is issued, the different items of the improvement, and the total cost thereof. The tax bill shall be made payable to the contractor doing the work, or to the street commissioner, for and to the use of the city, as the case may be. All tax bills issued as herein provided shall be due thirty (30) days after date, and shall bear interest from maturity at a rate not to exceed eight (8) percent per annum. 
(Ord. No. 99-52, § II, 6-22-99) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 88.893. 
Sec. 21-139. - Same-Signature, etc. 
    All tax bills issued under the provisions of this division shall be certified by the city engineer, or other person making the computation of the cost for the city, and shall be signed by the mayor and attested by the city clerk, under the seal of the city. 
(Ord. No. 99-52, § II, 6-22-99) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 88.907. 
Sec. 21-140. - Same-Recording, etc. 
    All tax bills issued under the provisions of this division shall, before delivery, be recorded by the city clerk in a book kept by him for that purpose. It shall be the duty of the clerk to release the tax bills on the margin of the record, upon their presentation by the holder of the assigns thereof and duly marked "paid" or when it is shown by other satisfactory evidence that such tax bills have been paid in full. 
(Ord. No. 99-52, § II, 6-22-99) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 88.910. 
Sec. 21-141. - Liability of real estate for cost of improvements. 
(a)  All real estate except that owned by the United States of America fronting or abutting on any sidewalk which has been constructed, reconstructed, or repaired, shall be liable for the cost of the improvement so made, whether such real estate be owned by an individual, or by a company, church, charitable institution, cemetery association, or by any other institution or association whatsoever, including real estate owned by the state or any state institution or county, township or city; and the tax bills so issued against any and all such property, except that owned by the state, or by any state institution, county, township or city, shall be and constitute a first and prior lien for state, county and city taxes, which lien shall continue for a period of three (3) years from and after the maturity of the tax bills, and until the final determination of any legal proceedings to collect the same. 
(b)  Any real estate owned by the state, or by any state institution, county, township or city, abutting on the improvement shall be liable for the cost of such improvement the same as other property, and an assessment shall be made thereon, and tax bill issued in the same manner as against other property, and tax bill so issued shall constitute a valid claim, but not a lien, against such state, state institution, county, township, or city, and shall bear interest at a rate not exceeding eight (8) percent per annum from maturity until paid. 
(Ord. No. 99-52, § II, 6-22-99) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 88.897, 88.900. 
Sec. 21-142. - Construction permit. 
(a)  Any person desiring to construct or reconstruct any sidewalk before or without being ordered to do so by the city engineer shall, before commencing the work, apply to and obtain from the city engineer a permit therefor, which permit shall be in writing, and shall specify a time within which said work shall be completed; and the sidewalk shall be constructed or reconstructed out of the materials, and in accordance with the plans and specifications prescribed by the ordinances of the city for the building of sidewalks, and constructed under the supervision of the city engineer. 
(b)  Upon obtaining a permit as provided by this section, the person therein authorized to construct or reconstruct a sidewalk shall present the same to the city engineer, with a request for a grade to be given for the work specified in the permit; and it shall be the duty of the city engineer, to set the grade stakes at the established grade for the improvement, and he shall inspect the construction or reconstruction of the sidewalk, and when the same is completed, upon the grade and according to the specifications therefor, the engineer shall report the same to the council for acceptance. The engineer shall not receive any sidewalk which has not been built on the established grade, as given and which has not been built in accordance with the plans and specifications prescribed by the ordinances of the city. In no case shall the city engineer be required to set grade stakes for any sidewalk, unless the same has been ordered by the council, or unless a permit has first been obtained therefor. 
(Ord. No. 99-52, § II, 6-22-99) 
Sec. 21-143. - City engineer may condemn sidewalks. 
    Any sidewalk which the city engineer may deem to be in a dangerous or defective condition, or out of repair, or any sidewalk which is not located on the established grade and line for sidewalks on the street on which the sidewalk is located, or any sidewalk which does not conform to the specifications for sidewalks in the city, as provided by the ordinances of the city, may be condemned by the city engineer and removed, and the sidewalk shall be reconstructed as herein provided. 
(Ord. No. 99-52, § II, 6-22-99) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 88.873. 
Sec. 21-144. - City participation in cost of sidewalk improvements. 
    The purpose of this program is to encourage property owners to replace or install residential and/or commercial sidewalks within the City of Carthage. 
(1)  The city shall reimburse, subject to the availability of funds in the fiscal year construction is completed, a portion of the costs, to the owner of any lot or tract, who shall construct, rebuild, or reconstruct in compliance with this article, a sidewalk lying along and adjacent to his said property. Reimbursement to said owners shall be made as follows: Three dollars ($3.00) per square foot of new sidewalk constructed in accordance with city specifications as defined in section 21-125(a), (b), (c), (d), and (e) provided that all work has been accepted and reimbursement approved by the public works director. Any one (1) owner or owners shall not receive more than three thousand dollars ($3,000.00) reimbursement per fiscal year, except where said owners meet all requirements for reimbursement for additional tracts of land and providing that reimbursement for said additional tracts of land shall not be made until reimbursement has been made during the current fiscal year to all owners entitled to reimbursement under this section as to one (1) tract of land. 
(2)  All construction, reconstruction, rebuilding, or repair of sidewalks less than full width as required in section 21-125, shall not be eligible for reimbursement of funds. 
(3)  All sidewalks constructed by order of the city council as provided in section 21-132, shall not be eligible for reimbursements, unless specifically authorized by a council bill. 
(4)  All sidewalks constructed, repaired, or reconstructed by order of the city engineer in compliance with this article, where a special tax bill has been issued, shall not be eligible for reimbursements, unless said special tax bill has been paid in full within thirty (30) days after date of issuance. 
(5)  The program is not available to property owners where sidewalks are required as a part of the city's sub-division or development standards, i.e., existing or new undeveloped lots. 
(6)  The owner may choose to hire a contractor with a valid city business license or may choose to conduct the work himself or herself. 
(Ord. No. 99-52, § II, 6-22-99; Ord. No. 02-31, § I, 6-4-2002; Ord. No. 16-41, § I, 9-27-2016) 
Sec. 21-145. - Appeals process. 
    Orders issued from the city engineer in compliance with this article may be appealed by the property owner of record to the board of appeals, in accordance with Section PM-111.0 of the BOCA Property Maintenance Code. 
(Ord. No. 99-52, § II, 6-22-99) 
Secs. 21-146-21-149. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - REMOVAL OF STUMPS, TREES, AND TREE ROOTS 

Sec. 21-150. - Scope. 
    This division applies to the removal of stumps, trees, and tree roots, which are located on or within a public right-of-way. 
(Ord. No. 99-52, § II, 6-22-99) 
Sec. 21-151. - Removal included in contract. 
    The removal of stumps, trees, and tree roots, when necessary for proper construction, repair, or maintenance of sidewalks, curbs, curb stones, or gutters, may be included in the same contract with the sidewalks, curbs or gutters, as required by law, and the cost thereof, included in the contract, may be included in the tax bills issued for the payment of the improvement. 
(Ord. No. 99-52, § II, 6-22-99) 
Sec. 21-152. - City engineer may order removal. 
(a)  The city engineer shall have the right to remove or order to be removed, any stump, tree, or tree root, which has caused sufficient damage to any sidewalk, making it unsafe for pedestrian traffic, provided that said stumps, trees, or tree roots are located within the public right-of-way. 
(b)  The city engineer shall have the right to remove or order to be removed, any stump, tree, or tree root, which has caused sufficient damage to any curb, curb stone, or gutter, making it unsafe or inadequate to carry stormwater as necessary, provided that said stumps, trees, or tree roots are located within the public right-of-way. 
(Ord. No. 99-52, § II, 6-22-99) 
Sec. 21-153. - Notice to owners. 
    The city engineer, upon receiving notice of an unsafe condition of any sidewalk, curb, curb stone, or gutter, caused by damage or obstruction from any stump, tree, or tree root, located in the public right-of-way, shall serve a notice, in writing, upon the owner(s) of the property abutting thereon to proceed to remove said stump, tree, or tree root. Said notice shall include the legal description of the abutting property, the name of the owner thereof, and the time within which such order must be completed, which time shall not be less than thirty (30) days from the date on which the order is served. The city engineer shall immediately serve the notice upon the property owner named in the order by (a) delivering to the owner in person; (b) sending by certified or registered mail addressed to the owner at the last known address with return receipt requested. If the certified or registered letter is returned showing that the letter was not delivered, a copy thereof shall be posted in a conspicuous place in or about the area of the sidewalk, curb, or gutter affected by such notice. Service of such notice in the foregoing manner upon the owner's agent or upon the person responsible for the sidewalk, curb, or gutter shall constitute service of notice upon the owner. 
(Ord. No. 99-52, § II, 6-22-99) 
Sec. 21-154. - Removal below surface. 
    All stumps, trees, or tree roots required to be removed under this article, shall be removed so that no part shall project above the surface of the ground, above the top of the sidewalk base material, above or in front of the curb, or above the gutter. 
(Ord. No. 99-52, § II, 6-22-99) 
Sec. 21-155. - Penalties for violations by owners. 
    Any person upon whom or which has been served an order to remove a stump, tree, or tree root, located within a public right-of-way, as herein provided, who shall fail, neglect, or refuse to comply, within the time fixed by the city engineer in the order, with the requirements of the order, shall on conviction be punished by a fine of not less than five dollars ($5.00) and not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(Ord. No. 99-52, § II, 6-22-99) 
Secs. 21-156-21-175. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - EXCAVATIONS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 21-176. - Barricades and markings.
