    Any person making any excavation in any street, sidewalk, or other public way, shall keep the same adequately barricaded and clearly marked at all times. If any excavation be left open overnight, it shall be guarded with adequate barricades and approved kerosene flares in sufficient number to make the excavation seen, shall be placed around the excavation and kept burning all night. Any person failing to observe these precautions while excavating in any street, sidewalk, or other public way shall be liable to the city for any sum it may have to pay for the damage to property or injury to any person resulting from the failure of the person or company adequately to guard and light the excavation made. Such damages may be recovered by the city together with its cost expended in the action by institution of a suit in any court of competent jurisdiction. 
(Code 1978, § 525.810) 
Sec. 21-177. - Restoration of surface. 
(a)  Any person making any excavation in the public square or any street lane, alley, or other highway within the city for any purpose, shall, upon refilling the same, tamp and flush with water the dirt and material placed therein, so that the same will be settled thoroughly, and made firm and solid, and in such condition that the ground will remain in a safe condition for persons and vehicles. 
(b)  Any person who obtains a permit for excavation in any street of the city for residential hookups to the sewer system shall, upon completion of the excavation fill excavation with approved material to within one (1) foot of the original elevation. The remainder of the excavation shall be filled with base rock. All dirt, rock, and other matters which are dug as a result of the original excavation shall be hauled off and shall not be replaced in the excavation. 
(Code 1978, §§ 240.200, 525.830) 
Secs. 21-178-21-187. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 

Sec. 21-188. - Required. 
    Any person making any excavations in any street, sidewalk, alley, or other public way, without obtaining a permit from the city engineer shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1979, § 525.820) 
Sec. 21-189. - Application. 
    Any person, including the water and electric plant, desiring to make an excavation, for any purpose, in any street, sidewalk, alley or other public way in the city shall before starting such excavation, make application to the city for a permit therefor. The application shall state the reason for the excavation the exact location thereof, the length of time required for the making thereof, the length of time the same will exist, and its approximate size. 
(Code 1978, § 525.750) 
Sec. 21-190. - Issuance. 
    The city engineer shall issue an excavation permit if the proposed excavation is for a proper purpose and will be made properly and if the required deposit has been filed with the city. 
(Code 1978, § 525.760) 
Sec. 21-191. - Cash deposit generally. 
(a)  The city engineer, upon receiving an application for a permit to make an excavation in a street, sidewalk, alley, or other public way, shall proceed to the location of such proposed excavation, note the condition of the way, and estimate the amount which would be required to restore the way to its normal condition after the making of the proposed excavation. Upon the making of such an estimate, the city shall present the same to the applicant, and require of the applicant a cash deposit in the amount of the estimate. 
(b)  After the excavation has been made and the street, sidewalk, alley or other public way has been restored to its normal condition, the person holding the permit therefor shall immediately report that fact to the city engineer. Upon the receipt of such report, the city engineer shall inspect same. If the way is restored properly, he shall refund the cash deposit. If, however, work remains to be done, in order properly to restore the way to its normal condition, the city engineer shall specify the work to be done and order the holder of the permit to do the same in the manner designated and within a reasonable time, before the cash deposit will be surrendered. If the holder of the permit, after the expiration of a reasonable time, fails, neglects, or refuses to do the work specified, the city engineer shall cause the same to be done, paying the cost thereof out of the money deposited by the permit holder, and refunding the balance remaining to the holder of the permit, if any balance remains. 
(Code 1978, §§ 525.760, 525.770) 
Sec. 21-192. - Certificate of underground hazard insurance as alternative. 
(a)  Plumbers and drainlayers doing business in the city and all telephone companies, telegraph companies, electric light and power companies, gas companies, and all other persons or companies engaged in any business or line of work necessitating the continuous making of excavations in the public streets, alleys, sidewalks, the other public ways of the city or the removal of any guttering or curbing, shall execute and deliver to the city engineer a certificate of underground hazard insurance to be filed in the city engineer's office. Every effort shall be made by the aforementioned persons and companies to restore all sidewalks, curbs, paving and guttering, and all streets, alleys and other public ways in a careful and efficient manner to be as good and sound a condition as the same were at the time the excavation was made or any material moved therefrom. 
(b)  If any plumbers, drainlayers, telephone companies, telegraph companies, electric light and power companies, gas companies, and all other persons or companies who have been issued an excavation permit fail to restore streets, sidewalks, curbing, guttering or any other public ways to the satisfaction of the street commissioner, the street commissioner shall order the restoration of public ways by the city street department, with the cost of the restoration to be billed to the plumbers, drainlayers, or companies or others listed on the certificate of underground hazard insurance on file in the office of the city engineer. 
(Ord. No. 6175, § I, 2-28-89) 
Cross reference- Carthage Water and Electric requirements relative to construction of water service pipelines, § 6-204. 
Secs. 21-193-21-225. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - POLES AND WIRES 

Sec. 21-226. - Authority to place in streets and alleys. 
    Any telegraph, telephone, or other company doing business in the city or desiring to do business in the city, and using poles to carry wires for the transmission of electric power or current may set its poles, wires, and other fixtures along, across, or under any of the public streets and alleys of the city, subject, however, to the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1978, § 535.010) 
Sec. 21-227. - Use of alleys. 
    Whenever, in the judgement of the council, the use of any alley for the placing of poles is practicable, the poles of the company shall be placed upon and along the alley, instead of along and upon the street parallel thereto. When the poles are set in any alley, they shall be placed as near the side line of such alley as practicable, and in such manner as not to inconvenience the public or the adjoining proprietors or residents. 
(Code 1978, § 535.020) 
Sec. 21-228. - Location on streets. 
    When any poles are erected upon any street of the city, they shall be placed, in all cases where practicable, on the outer edge of the sidewalk and just inside the curbstone, or on the line dividing the buildings, one from the other but in no case shall the poles be placed so as to obstruct the drainage of the street, or injure or damage, in any way, the curbstone or other public or private property. 
(Code 1978, § 535.040) 
Cross reference- Telephone service, § 12-301 et seq. 
Sec. 21-229. - Approval of routes by council. 
    Before any person erects any poles upon any street or alley of the city, he shall submit for approval to the city council the route of the proposed line, stating the name of the street or streets to be used, or, if an alley the name, or description thereof, so that the council may know the alley intended to be used, and, as required by the council, he shall state the location of each pole along the proposed route. When any person presents to the council the route of his proposed line, as provided above, the council shall examine the same, and, if found to be in compliance with the provisions of this article shall immediately issue a permit to the person to erect his line. 
(Code 1978, § 535.050) 
Sec. 21-230. - Excavating, refilling and restoring pavement. 
    All work of excavating, refilling, and restoring pavement in connection with the placement of poles in streets or alleys shall be done under the supervision of the street commissioner, and in all cases the pavement shall be restored as soon as possible to the same condition as it was before, at the expense of the person moving the same. 
(Code 1978, § 535.060) 
Sec. 21-231. - Poles not to lie on street. 
    No person shall, while engaged in erecting poles along or across any street or alley in this city, permit any poles to lie upon any such street or alley for a longer time than necessary, but shall bring the poles upon the streets or alleys only when the workmen are ready to place them in position. 
(Code 1978, § 535.070) 
Secs. 21-232-21-250. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - MOVING OF BUILDINGS 

Sec. 21-251. - Building to comply with other ordinances. 
    No building, shall be moved or relocated unless it can be made, and is made, to comply with the requirements of the ordinances of the city governing the erection of new buildings at the proposed new location. 
(Code 1978, § 545.010) 
Sec. 21-252. - Housemover's license. 
(a)  Every person engaged in the business of housemoving within the city shall obtain from the city a license therefor. No such license shall be granted until the person making application therefor shall have given bond and paid the required fee, as provided by this article. 
(b)  Before any applicant shall be issued a license he shall pay to the city the sum of ten dollars ($10.00) per year, payable annually or semi-annually in advance. 
(Code 1978, §§ 545.050, 545.070) 
Sec. 21-253. - Housemover's bond. 
    The bond to be furnished by a housemover shall be in the penal sum of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) and shall run in the favor of the city for the use and benefit of the city. Any person sustaining personal injury or property damage shall be entitled to sue thereon in his own name. The bond shall be executed by a surety company, shall be subject to the approval of the mayor, and shall be conditioned, among other things that if the license be granted, the licensee will pay any and all damages which may be caused to any person or to any property, either public or private, within the city, when such injury or damage is inflicted by the licensee or his agents, servants, employees, workmen, contractors or subcontractors. Such bond shall also be conditioned that the licensee shall save, indemnify and protect the city from all liability, or any claim against the city arising, either directly or indirectly from the moving of any building by the licensee, his agent, servants, employees, workmen, contractors or subcontractors, and that the licensee will, in all respects, comply with the ordinances of the city in regard to the moving of houses and to the use or obstruction of the streets, sidewalks, highways, and other public places of the city. The form of the bond shall be approved by the city attorney. 
(Code 1978, § 545.060) 
Sec. 21-254. - Permit to move buildings. 
(a)  No person shall move any building or structure along or across any street, or other public way, within the limits of the city, without first having and obtaining from the city engineer a permit therefor. Such permit to be issued in accordance with the provisions of this article. No permit shall be issued to any person who does not have a license as a housemover. 
(b)  All applications for permits to move buildings upon or across the streets, or other public ways, of the city shall be made to the city engineer, and shall state the location of the building proposed to be moved, its greatest length, width, and height, and the principal material of its walls and roof, and shall state definitely the route over which it is to be moved, the length of time required for its removal, and the proposed new location thereof. 
(c)  Before granting any such permit, it shall be the duty of the city to examine the building, the route over which it is to be moved, and the new location. If the nature of the proposed route is such that the building can be moved with safety and in accordance with this article, the permit shall be granted; otherwise the permit shall be denied. 
(d)  Before issuing any permit the city engineer shall, whenever practicable, consult with the person having charge of the maintenance of any electric wires or cables belonging to any public service corporation and suspending over or across any public street or alley, relative to the practicability of the route proposed, and shall have the authority to require any change in such route which he shall deem proper under the attendant circumstances. 
(e)  Before a permit is granted, the applicant shall pay to the city engineer, a fee therefor as follows: 
(1)  For a one-story building not exceeding two hundred eighty-eight (288) square feet in floor area, one dollar ($1.00). 
(2)  For a one-story building exceeding two hundred eighty-eight (288) square feet in floor area, two dollars and fifty cents ($2.50). 
(3)  For any two-story building, three dollars ($3.00). 
No fee shall be charged for a permit for moving a building on unplatted land, or from one (1) location to another within the same half block. 
(Code 1978, §§ 545.020, 545.040) 
Sec. 21-255. - Removal or trimming of trees. 
    No tree on any public way in the city shall be removed, or its branches cut or trimmed, in order to facilitate the moving of any building, except with the consent of the owner of the property on which such tree shall be situated, and under the supervision of the city engineer. 
(Code 1978, § 545.080) 
Sec. 21-256. - Removal of objects other than trees. 
    No telephone, light or power pole, or any fixture or appurtenance thereto, nor any fixture other than a tree, shall be removed, displaced, or otherwise interfered with, in order to facilitate the moving of any building, except with the consent of the owner thereof, and under the supervision of the city engineer. 
(Code 1978, § 545.090) 
Sec. 21-257. - Raising or cutting electric or telephone wires. 
(a)  Whenever, for the purpose of facilitating the moving of any building, it is necessary to raise or cut any telephone or telegraph wire or cable, or any electric wire, or to move any pole bearing any such wire or cable, or any appurtenance thereto, it shall be the duty of the housemover having charge of the moving of the building to give the person having charge of, or owning, the poles, wires, cables, or appurtenances, at least forty-eight (48) hours' notice of the time and place when and where the removal of such pole, or the raising or cutting of such wires or cable will be necessary. If the poles or wires of the fire or police departments, or their alarm systems, are to be interfered with, such notice shall be served upon the chief of the proper department. 
(b)  After the service of the notice the person owning or having control of the poles, wires, cables, or appurtenances, or the chief of the fire or police department as the case may be, shall furnish competent workmen or linemen to remove such poles, or cut or raise such wires or cables. The regular wages of such workmen or linemen, while engaged in such work, shall be paid by the housemover requesting the work. No housemover shall raise, cut or move any pole, wire, cable, or appurtenance, unless the person owning or having the control of the same fails or refuses to do so after the service of the notice, and such housemover shall employ only competent workmen or linemen to do such work. The same shall be done in a careful and workmanlike manner, the poles, wires, cables, and appurtenances. shall promptly be replaced, and any damage thereto promptly repaired at the expense of the housemover. 
(Code 1978, § 545.100) 
Sec. 21-258. - Buildings standing in streets; regulations. 
(a)  No building being moved shall be allowed to remain stationary in any public street or other public way, for a longer period than twenty-four (24) hours, without the written consent of the city engineer. When any building is left in any street at night, at least two (2) lights as are commonly used for guarding street obstructions, shall be posted conspicuously at each end of such building, in such manner as to give warning of the presence of such building to traffic approaching from any direction. All other obstructions left in any portion of the street, or other public way, shall be thoroughly safeguarded by similar lights. All lights so placed shall be in good order, and securely placed in position. No building shall be left standing at night at any street intersection, nor shall any street intersection be obstructed in any manner, and the chief of the fire department and the police chief shall be notified of the exact location of any building left standing in the street at night. 
(b)  When necessary to protect the pavement or sidewalk, planks of sufficient size and thickness, as specified by the city engineer, shall be laid for the wheels of the moving vehicle. 
(c)  The city engineer may require the use of any precautionary measure, if necessary for the protection of persons or property in regard to the moving of a building. 
(Code 1978, § 545.120) 
Sec. 21-259. - Liability for damages. 
    If any housemover, his agents, servants or employees while engaged in moving a building damages or destroys any property, and does not repair, renew, or pay for same, or fails, neglects or refuses to pay the expense of the raising, cutting, or repair of any electric wire or cable, or the removal and replacement of any pole bearing same, or any appurtenance thereto, as required by this article, a written claim, containing a statement of the damages occasioned by the failure, neglect or refusal of such housemover, may be filed with the city engineer, who shall investigate the same. If he finds such claim to be just and reasonable no further permits within the scope of this article shall be issued to such person until he settles the claim in full. 
(Code 1978, § 545.110) 
Sec. 21-260. - Crossing tracks. 
    If it is necessary to move any building over or across any railway or steam railway tracks, the same shall be done in such manner, and at such time, as to interfere as little as possible with the operation of cars or trains thereon. 
(Code 1978, § 545.130) 
Secs. 21-261-21-270. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - TREES[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference- Removal of, § 21-150 et seq. 

Sec. 21-271. - Purpose. 
    It is the purpose of this article to promote and protect the public health, safety, and general welfare of the public by providing for the regulation of the planting, maintenance, and removal of trees, shrubs, and other plants located on public rights-of-way, public easements, public parks, and all property owned by the City of Carthage, Missouri. 
(Ord. No. 99-73, § I, 9-28-99) 
Sec. 21-272. - Definitions. 
    [The following words, terms and phrases, as used in this article, shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them in this section, unless the context clearly indicates otherwise:] 
    Hazard trees shall mean trees with severe structural defects or splits that threaten public safety or property. 
    Landmark tree shall mean any tree listed with the state or national registry or cited in the city's tree registry as being historically significant, by age, species or form. 
    Park trees shall mean trees, shrubs, bushes and all other woody vegetation in public parks. 
    Private community forest shall mean all trees within municipal boundaries but not owned by the city. 
    Public community forest shall mean all street and park trees, and other trees owned by the city as a total resource. 
    Right-of-way shall mean all that area dedicated to the public, by ordinance, for use as a street, thoroughfare, alley, or utility easement. 
    Street trees shall mean trees, shrubs, bushes and all other woody vegetation located on a street or alley right-of-way within the city. 
(Ord. No. 99-73, § I, 9-28-99) 
Sec. 21-273. - Title. 
    This article shall be known and may be cited as the "Carthage Tree Ordinance" of the City of Carthage. 
(Ord. No. 99-73, § I, 9-28-99) 
Sec. 21-274. - Creation of tree board. 
    Said board shall consist of five (5) voting members, at least eighteen (18) years of age, appointed by the mayor with approval of the city council. No more than (1) member of said board serving at any one (1) time shall be a nonresident of the City of Carthage. Said member must be residential, business customer or representative of commercial customers of Carthage Water & Electric Plant (CW & EP). No more than one (1) member of the board can be employed by the same employer. In all cases, such member of the board shall live within five (5) miles of the Carthage city limits. 
(Ord. No. 99-73, § I, 9-28-99; Ord. No. 10-03, § I, 2-23-10) 
Sec. 21-275. - Compensation of board members. 
    Members of the tree board shall serve without compensation. 
(Ord. No. 99-73, § I, 9-28-99) 
Sec. 21-276. - Terms of office. 
    The term of the five (5) persons to be appointed by the mayor shall be three (3) years each, except that the term of two (2) of the members appointed to the first board shall be for only one (1) year and the term of two (2) members of the first board shall be for two (2) years. The mayor may, by and with the consent of the city council, remove any member of the board at any time when, in their judgement, such removal shall be in the best interests of the city. The mayor shall appoint a council member to serve as liaison to the tree board. 
(Ord. No. 99-73, § I, 9-28-99) 
Sec. 21-277. - Vacancies. 
    In the event a vacancy shall occur during the term of any board member due to death, resignation or removal, his successor shall be appointed for the unexpired portion of this term. 
(Ord. No. 99-73, § I, 9-28-99) 
Sec. 21-278. - Board's duties and authority. 
    The tree board shall: 
(1)  Choose its own officers, make its own rules and regulations, keep minutes of its meetings, and act by a vote of a majority of its five (5) members at meetings at which a quorum shall be present. A majority of the board shall constitute a quorum. 
(2)  Develop a management plan for the planting, care, cultivation, pruning and removal of trees, shrubs and plants located on city property. The plan may include provisions designating the species of trees, shrubs and plants to be planted, preserved and removed or replaced. This plan shall be updated on an annual basis and should include details for tree care, replacement, maintenance, removal and disposition of trees. Such plan shall be presented to the city council for approval and upon acceptance and approval by resolution of the council, such plan shall constitute the official comprehensive tree, shrubs and plants plan for the city. 
(3)  The following list constitutes the official tree species for the city. No species other than those included in the following lists may be planted in the right-of-way, public easements, public parks or any property owned by the city without written permission from the tree board. 
Small Trees Large Trees Conifers 
(Large Trees) Pear Ash Upright Juniper Peach Locust Norway Spruce Cherry Linden Blue Spruce Red Bud Red Oak English Holly Dogwood Hawthorne East White Pine Crabapple Tulip Poplar American Holly Golden Rain Tree Pagoda Russian Olive Hackberry River Birch Bald Cypress Cork Ginkgo, male only Black Walnut Red Maple Sugar Maple Pin Oak Shingle Oak White Oak  
(Ord. No. 99-73, § I, 9-28-99) 
Sec. 21-279. - Designation of a city forester. 
    The mayor may, with consent of the city council, designate an individual to serve as city forester and to perform the duties and exercise the authority conferred upon him by city ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 99-73, § I, 9-28-99) 
Sec. 21-280. - Landmark trees. 
    The city forester shall have as one (1) of his duties, the location, selection and identification of any trees which qualify as "landmark trees." 
(Ord. No. 99-73, § I, 9-28-99) 
Sec. 21-281. - Spacing. 
    The spacing of street trees shall be in accordance with city's official list of acceptable street and park trees and no trees may be planted closer to each other than the following: small trees, thirty (30) feet; evergreen trees, thirty (30) feet; and large trees, fifty (50) feet; except in special plantings which have been designed by a landscape architect and approved by the tree board. 
(Ord. No. 99-73, § I, 9-28-99) 
Sec. 21-282. - Distance from curbs and sidewalk. 
    No trees may be planted closer to any curb or sidewalk than the following: small trees, two (2) feet; conifers three (3) feet; and large trees three (3) feet. 
(Ord. No. 99-73, § I, 9-28-99) 
Sec. 21-283. - Distance from street corners and fire hydrants. 
    No street trees shall be planted closer than fifteen (15) feet from any street corner, measured from the point of nearest intersection curbs or curblines. No street trees shall be planted closer than ten (10) feet from any fire hydrant. Trees which overhang sidewalks or walkways shall be pruned not less than eight (8) feet above said sidewalks or walkways. 
(Ord. No. 99-73, § I, 9-28-99) 
Sec. 21-284. - Tree topping. 
    It shall be unlawful as a normal practice for any person, or city department to top any street tree, park tree, or other tree on public property. Topping, rounding off or pollarding is defined as the systematic cutting back of limbs with the tree's crown to such a degree as to remove the normal canopy and disfigure the tree. Trees severely damaged by storms or other causes, or certain trees under utility wires, or trees obstructing alleys or streets, or other obstructions where other pruning practices are impractical may be exempted from this section at the determination of the city forester or tree board. 
(Ord. No. 99-73, § I, 9-28-99) 
Sec. 21-285. - Public tree care. 
    The city shall have the right to plant, prune, maintain, and remove trees, plants, and shrubs within the right-of-way or bounds of all streets, alleys, lanes, squares, and public grounds, as may be necessary to insure the public safety. 
(Ord. No. 99-73, § I, 9-28-99) 
Sec. 21-286. - Utilities. 
    No street trees other than those species listed herein as small trees in the city's official list of acceptable street and park trees may be planted under or within fifteen (15) lateral feet from any overhead utility wire, or over or within five (5) lateral feet from any underground water line, sewer line, transmission line or other utility. 
(Ord. No. 99-73, § I, 9-28-99) 
Sec. 21-287. - Dead or hazardous tree removal. 
    The city shall have the right to cause to be removed any tree located within the public rights-of-way, public easements, public parks, and all property owned by the city that is dead or has been declared a hazard. 
(Ord. No. 99-73, § I, 9-28-99) 
Sec. 21-288. - Enforcement of the article. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to prevent or interfere with the tree board or any of its representatives or agents while engaging in public tree care. 
(Ord. No. 99-73, § I, 9-28-99) 
Sec. 21-289. - Violations. 
    Violation of this article shall be a misdemeanor punishable by a fine of not less than ten dollars ($10.00) and not more than two hundred and fifty dollars ($250.00). If, as a result of the violation of any provision of this article, the injury, mutilation, or death of a tree, shrub or other plant located on city-owned property is caused, the cost of repair or replacement of such tree, shrub, or other plant shall be borne by the party guilty of such violation. 
(Ord. No. 99-73, § I, 9-28-99) 
Chapter 22 - SUBDIVISIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, Ch. 6; planning and development, Ch. 17; zoning, Ch. 25. 
State Law reference- Subdivision regulations, RSMo 89.410 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 22-1. - Definitions. 
    In this chapter "commission" means the planning, zoning and historic preservation commission. 
Cross reference- Planning, zoning and historic preservation commission, § 17-16 et seq. 
Sec. 22-2. - Compliance. 
    All plats for the subdivision of lands within the limits of the city shall be subject to and conform to this chapter before acceptance, filing or approval by the council. 
(Code 1978, § 420.020) 
Sec. 22-3. - Council to approve. 
    Before an addition or subdivision to the city shall be accepted, the city council shall, by ordinance, establish the same and declare it to be a part of the city. 
(Code 1978, § 420.020) 
Sec. 22-4. - Interpretation. 
    Nothing in this chapter binds the city to recognize any addition or subdivision made by any person that does not conform with this chapter, or to grade, macadamize or repair any street, or sidewalk therein. 
(Code 1978, § 420.080) 
Sec. 22-5. - Fee for plats, replats, boundary adjustments and lot splits. 
    There is hereby established a fee in the amount of two hundred dollars ($200.00) for plats, replats, boundary adjustments and lot splits within the city. 
(Ord. No. 05-74, § I, 9-27-2005) 
Secs. 22-6-22-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PLATS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Plat approval, RSMo 89.420-89.440. 

Sec. 22-16. - Required. 
    No addition to the city, and no subdivision within the city, shall be regarded as a plat of the city until the following conditions have been complied with: 
(1)  Two (2) full and complete plats of such addition or subdivision shall be made out, one (1) of which shall be recorded in the office of the recorder of deeds of the county, and the other filed in the office of the city clerk. 
(2)  The plats shall show that all streets and alleys of the city, which, if prolonged in straight lines would occupy any portion of the land in the addition or subdivision, have been laid out the full width and entirely brought through the length and breadth of the addition or subdivision. 
(3)  The plats shall show that all of the streets and the alleys have been dedicated to the public use forever. 
(Code 1978, § 420.010(1)-(3)) 
Sec. 22-17. - Final approval and variances. 
    The council shall be final judge in all cases regarding the application of this article, and may approve variations in specific cases which do not affect the general application or spirit of this article. 
(Code 1978, § 420.060) 
Sec. 22-18. - Advice and assistance. 
    Advice and cooperation in the preparation of plats will be freely given by the office of the city engineer. 
(Code 1978, § 420.060) 
Sec. 22-19. - Preliminary plat. 
(a)  A preliminary plat, in triplicate, of a proposed subdivision shall be submitted to the commission for approval before the preparation of the final plat or plats for record. Such plat must be filed in the office of the commission at least five (5) days prior to the meeting at which approval is asked. This plat shall be drawn to a scale of two hundred (200) feet to one (1) inch, or larger, and shall show, or be accompanied by, the following information: 
(1)  The proposed name of the subdivision, which must not be so similar to that of an existing subdivision as to cause confusion, and names and adjacent subdivisions. 
(2)  The names of the owner and the engineer, surveyor, or landscape architect responsible for the survey and design. 
(3)  The location of boundary lines and their relation to established section lines and fractional section lines. 
(4)  The location and width of existing and proposed streets, roads, lots and alleys, building lines, parks and other features, and similar facts regarding property immediately adjacent thereto; also the location and size of existing sewer and water mains. If there are no adjacent subdivisions, then a map, made on a smaller scale, shall be presented to the commission showing outline and ownership of adjacent properties, location and distance of the nearest subdivision, and how the streets, alleys or highways in the subdivisions offered for record may connect with those in the nearest subdivisions. 
(5)  A survey showing physical features of the property, including location of watercourses, ravines, bridges, culverts, present structures and other features pertinent to subdivision. The outline of wooded areas or the location of important individual trees may be required by the commission. On extensive or broken tracts, the commission may require contours at intervals of two (2) or five (5) feet. All grades shown shall be referred to city datum. The approximate acreage of the property is to be indicated. 
(6)  The approximate grades and gradients of streets. 
(7)  A designation of the proposed uses of land within the subdivisions; that is, the type of residential use, location of business or industrial sites, and sites for churches, schools, parks or other special uses. 
(8)  North point, scale and date. 
(b)  The approval of the preliminary plat by the commission shall not constitute acceptance of the subdivision, but merely an authorization to proceed with the preparation of the final plat. No work shall be done on the subdivision before the final plat is accepted, except with the written approval of the city engineer and the commission. 
(Code 1978, § 420.030) 
Sec. 22-20. - Final plat. 
(a)  After the preliminary plat has been approved by the commission, a final plat in the form of record plat shall be prepared and submitted to the commission for approval by that body and by the city council. Such plat shall be filed in the office of the commission at least five (5) days prior to the meeting at which approval is asked. This plat shall be drawn on tracing cloth in India ink and shall be to a scale of one hundred (100) feet to the inch unless otherwise directed by the commission, and shall show or be accompanied by the following information: 
(1)  The name of the subdivision and adjacent subdivisions, the names of streets (to conform wherever possible to existing street names) and numbers of lots and blocks, in accordance with a systematic arrangement. In case of branching streets, the lines of departure shall be indicated. 
(2)  An accurate boundary survey of the property, with bearings and distances, referenced to section corners, and showing (in dotted lines) the lines of all adjacent lands and the lines of adjacent streets and alleys, with their widths and names. 
(3)  The location of lots, streets, public highways, alleys, parks and other features, with accurate dimensions in feet and decimals of feet, with the length of ratio and of acres of all curves, and with all other information necessary to reproduce the plat on the ground. Dimensions shall be shown from all angle points and points of curve to lot lines. 
(4)  The location of building lines on front and side streets, and the location of utility easements. 
(5)  Profiles of grades for streets, if required by the council or the commission. 
(6)  Certificate of dedication of all streets, public highways, alleys, parks and other land intended for public use, signed by the owner or owners and by all other parties who have a mortgage or lien interest in the property, together with any restrictions which are to apply to lots. 
(7)  An affidavit of ownership, showing fee simple title and encumbrances and liens. 
(8)  A waiver of claim for damages occasioned by the establishment of grades or the alteration of the surface of any portion of the streets and alleys to conform to the grades so established. 
(9)  Certification by a registered civil engineer or surveyor or to the effect that the plan represents a survey made by him and that all the necessary survey monuments are correctly shown thereon. 
(10)  Certificates of approval to be filled out by the commission. 
(11)  North point, scale and date. 
(b)  All figures and letters shown must be plain, distinct, and of sufficient size to be easily read, and must be of sufficient density to make a lasting and permanent record. 
(c)  When more than one (1) sheet is used, a key map, showing the entire subdivision at smaller scale with block numbers and street names, shall be shown on one (1) of the sheets or on a separate sheet of the same size. 
(d)  The city engineer shall place sufficient permanent monuments along the boundaries of the property so that another engineer may retrace his work with accuracy. Iron pins not less than two (2) feet long and seven-eighths inch in diameter shall be placed at block corners, angle points on the streets, and the beginning and end of curves on streets. 
(Code 1978, § 420.040) 
Sec. 22-21. - Exemptions/administrative approval. 
(a)  The following matters are exempted from the full provisions of this article, but must be approved by the mayor and city council. 
(1)  Boundary adjustment plats and deeds, where land taken from one (1) parcel is added to an adjacent parcel, provided that the proposed adjustment does not: 
a.  Create any new lots; 
b.  Render any existing lot substandard in size or shape; 
c.  Render substandard the setbacks to existing development on the affected property; or 
d.  Impair any existing access, easement, or public improvement. 
(2)  A variance of sections and subsection in this chapter may be granted by the board of adjustment to insure conformity to the intent of this section. 
(b)  Lot split plats and deeds, where the division of property results in no more than three (3) tracts or lots or interests, provided that the following conditions are met: 
(1)  All lots or tracts are adjacent to a dedicated and accepted public street. 
(2)  The specifications required by article II and III of this section of these regulations are already in existence and available to serve each lot. 
(3)  Each lot will meet requirements of the city's zoning regulations without the necessity for any variance and no variance has been granted within one (1) previous year. 
(4)  No part of the lot split has been approved as part of a previous lot split within one (1) year prior to the date of submission of the original lot split application. 
(c)  This subsection is intended to implement procedures whereby property owners may split and adjust parcels of land without full compliance of the platting requirements, and with administrative approval. Anyone requesting lot split approval shall submit the following to the public works department: 
(1)  A completed application form. 
(2)  A title search of the parcel proposed to be split, furnished by a recognized title company. Such information shall be presented so that it may be determined if the proposed land split does or does not constitute a subdivision. 
(3)  A lot split survey. The information required for the lot split shall be shown graphically or by note on plans at a standard engineering scale large enough to show all details clearly. The size of the map shall be between eleven (11) by seventeen (17) inches and twenty-four (24) by thirty-six (36) inches and shall contain the following information: 
a.  Name, address, and telephone number of the property owner(s). 
b.  Name, address, and telephone number of the engineer or land surveyor preparing the map, including professional seal and signature. 
c.  Graphic and written scale, north indicator (up or to the right), and date of preparation. 
d.  Legal description of the property. 
e.  The existing zoning classification of the subject site and adjacent properties. 
f.  The property boundaries of the existing site. 
g.  The parcel boundaries of the proposed parcels to be created and the net area (the area exclusive of roadways dedicated to the public in square feet of each parcel). 
h.  The location of existing streets and rights-of-way with all dimensions. 
i.  The locations of existing structures, fences, walls, etc. 
j.  Certificates required for the recording of the survey plat with the Jasper County Recorder's Office. 
k.  Any additional pertinent information as required by the staff, such as copies of current covenants, conditions and restrictions, in the case of land splits in recorded subdivisions. 
(d)  City of Carthage staff, consisting of the city administrator, public works director, street commissioner, city attorney and others that may be assigned, shall review the application and the proposed land split map for completeness and accuracy. When deficiencies are determined, these shall be noted and relayed to the applicant. No decision shall be rendered until the application is determined to be complete. Staff shall present its recommendation to the public works committee for action and recommendation to the city council. Staff in evaluating and making decisions on land split proposals shall consider the following criteria: 
(1)  Consistency of the proposed lot split with the comprehensive plan. 
(2)  Conformity of the proposed lot split to the zoning ordinance. 
(3)  Conformity of the proposed land split to all applicable sections of the subdivision regulations. 
(4)  Conformity of the proposed land split with the city's existing street patterns and details. 
(5)  Lot size and design results from the proposed land split in relation to the site topography. 
(6)  Determination from the title information that a major subdivision is not being created. 
(7)  Other pertinent criteria. 
(Ord. No. 05-71, § I, 9-27-2005) 
Secs. 22-22-22-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - DESIGN STANDARDS 

Sec. 22-51. - Streets. 
(a)  Unless otherwise approved by the commission, provision must be made for the extension of main thoroughfares, as shown on the major street plan of the commission; and 
secondary streets must provide free circulation within the subdivisions. Off-center street intersections will not be approved except in unusual cases. 
(b)  The system of streets designated for the subdivision, except in unusual cases, must connect with streets already dedicated in adjacent subdivisions, and where no adjacent connections are platted, must in general be the reasonable projection of streets in nearest subdivided tracts, and must be continued to the boundaries of the tract subdivided, so that other subdivisions may connect therewith. 
(c)  Except in unusual cases, no dead-end streets will be approved unless such dead-end streets are provided to connect with future streets in adjacent land, but courts or "places" may be permitted where the form or contour of the land makes it difficult to plat with connecting streets. Such courts or "places" shall provide proper access to all lots and shall generally not exceed four hundred (400) feet in length, and a turnaround shall be provided at the closed end, with an outside radius of at least fifty (50) feet. 
(d)  In general, intersecting streets, determining block lengths, shall be provided at such intervals as to serve cross traffic adequately and to meet existing streets or customary subdivision practices in the neighborhood. Where no existing plats control, the blocks shall generally not exceed one thousand (1,000) feet in length, except that in outlining subdivisions a greater length may be permitted where topography or other conditions, in the opinion of the council and commission, justify such lengths. In blocks longer than eight hundred (800) feet, pedestrian ways through the block may be required near the center of the block. Such business use shall generally not exceed six hundred (600) feet. 
(e)  Width of major streets must be approved by the commission or if a major street plan is adopted by the commission such streets shall conform to such plan. A building line safeguarding future widening, may be required by the council or commission in lieu of dedication of the indicated width. Dedication of a half street adjoining unplatted property will be accepted. No reserve strips will be permitted unless by special approval of the council and commission. 
(f)  In districts where apartments or business buildings are apt to be built in the future, or where there is through traffic, minor streets shall be at least sixty (60) feet in width. In districts where detached residences are allowed minor streets shall be at least fifty (50) feet in width. 
(g)  Except in unusual cases, alleys or loading courts shall be provided in business blocks. Alleys are optional in residential districts. Alleys shall have a minimum width of twenty (20) feet. In case of intersecting alleys a cut-off shall be required of at least five (5) feet measured from the point of intersection of the alley lines, the resultant connecting lot line to be at least five (5) feet in length. 
(h)  The streets shall so be laid out as to correspond with the prolongations of existing streets, as far as practicable. 
(Code 1978, §§ 420.010, 420.050(A), (B), (D)-(H)) 
Sec. 22-52. - Lot sizes. 
    The minimum dimensions for residential lots shall be fifty (50) feet in width and generally not less than one hundred twenty (120) feet in depth, unless the council and commission, for special reasons, approve otherwise. In no case, however, shall rectangular or irregularly shaped lots contain less than six thousand (6,000) square feet. Corner lots shall have extra width especially in cases where they back on lots facing on the side streets. 
(Code 1978, § 420.050(I)) 
Sec. 22-53. - Oversize lots. 
    In case a tract is subdivided into larger parcels than normal building lots, such parcels shall be arranged to permit the opening of future streets and logical resubdivision. 
(Code 1978, § 420.050(C)) 
Sec. 22-54. - Lot lines. 
    All rectangular lots and all other lots, so far as practicable, shall have the side lines at right angles to the street on which the lot faces, or radial to curbed street lines. Lots with double frontage are undesirable, and shall be avoided wherever possible. 
(Code 1978, § 420.050(J)) 
Sec. 22-55. - Utility easements. 
    Where alleys are not included in the plat, easements of not less than five (5) feet shall be provided on each side of rear or side lot lines, where required by the council or commission, for public utilities, if necessary for the extension of main water or sewer lines, or similar utilities, easements of greater width may be required along lot lines or across lots. Easements shall connect with established easements in adjoining property. 
(Code 1978, § 420.050(K)) 
Sec. 22-56. - Building lines. 
    Building lines shall be shown on all lots intended for residential use, and may be required on lots intended for business use, and shall provide at least the setback required by the zoning ordinance. 
(Code 1978, § 420.050(L)) 
Sec. 22-57. - Parks, schools, sites and playgrounds. 
    Suitable sites for parks, schools, playgrounds or other public requirements shall be indicated on the preliminary plat, so that it can be determined which of such sites should be indicated on the final plat, and when and in what manner such areas will be acquired by the city. 
(Code 1978, § 420.050(M)) 
Secs. 22-58-22-75. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - REQUIRED IMPROVEMENTS 

Sec. 22-76. - Generally. 
    As a condition to the approval of the final plat the council or the commission shall require minimum improvements which shall include those specified in this article. 
(Code 1978, § 420.070) 
Sec. 22-77. - Staged installation. 
    The subdivider may, at his election, make required improvements on a progressive basis, but in no instance shall a building permit be issued for construction prior to installation and approval of minimum requirements in any block of the subdivision. 
(Code 1978, § 420.070) 
Sec. 22-78. - Bond. 
    The council may accept bond in an amount sufficient to ensure minimum improvements will be installed prior to erection of structures on any block in the subdivision. 
(Code 1978, § 420.070) 
Sec. 22-79. - Streets and alleys. 
(a)  New streets and alleys in the subdivision shall be graded and paved. Specifications for the paving will be furnished by the city street department, public works department or the city's contract engineering firm. 
(b)  Sidewalks shall be required along both sides of all streets, except where the construction of a sidewalk along one (1) side of a cul-de-sac with less than four (4) homes may be allowed to provided that each home has direct access to the sidewalk. Sidewalks may also be required elsewhere where deemed to be in the interest of public safety. 
(c)  Unless otherwise required or permitted, sidewalks shall be placed in the street right-of-way and located approximately one (1) foot from and parallel to the edge of the right-of-way. 
(d)  Where sufficient foot traffic will be realized across proposed streets to merit a crosswalk and/or pedestrian signal, the installation of such signals or striping of the street to provide for the safety of pedestrians may be required. 
(e)  An internalized pedestrian circulation system in the form of paved walking paths or jogging trails may be substituted in whole or part for sidewalks along residential streets with approval from the public works department and the planning and zoning commission. 
(Code 1978, § 420.070(1); Ord. No. 06-64, § I, 9-12-2006; Ord. No. 12-44, § I, 10-9-2012) 
Sec. 22-80. - Curbs and gutters. 
    Curbs and gutters shall be installed in subdivisions. 
(Code 1978, § 420.070(2)) 
Sec. 22-81. - Sewers. 
    A sanitary sewer system shall be installed in a subdivision. 
(Code 1978, § 420.070(3)) 
Sec. 22-82. - City participation in cost of certain improvements. 
(a)  The city shall reimburse, subject to the availability of funds, the developer of a platted subdivision of land for the cost of all concrete curbs and gutters which have been installed along streets which have been constructed in accordance with the City Code. The same would apply to any existing subdivision where the platted street has not yet been graded, and all of the platted lots are owned by the developer. The proposed plans for the expenditure must be submitted to the city for approval prior to construction. 
(b)  The developer is required to construct the sanitary sewers, water mains, electric lines, and street improvements prior to making any reimbursement to the developer for the concrete curbs and gutters. 
(c)  The city shall, subject to the availability of funds, install sanitary sewers, water mains, and electric lines if requested by the developer, and shall assess the cost to each lot. The cost of the improvements shall be payable in ten (10) equal annual installments bearing interest at eight (8) percent per annum. 
(d)  The developer would reimburse the city the amount of the sewer, water, and electric assessment against any lot, whenever the lot is sold, leased, or otherwise conveyed to another party. 
(e)  The developer shall execute a note acceptable to the city, assuring the city that the special assessments would be paid. 
(f)  The city, at its discretion, and where financially feasible, shall extend sanitary sewers and water mains to existing vacant lots under separate ownership within the city and shall allocate the costs to the benefitting properties. The charges against the undeveloped properties would be interest-free, and would be due and payable upon connection to the city utility. Properties already improved with a well or a septic tank shall also be assessed, but shall pay their share of the utility extension, at such time that a permit is issued for connection to the city utility. 
(g)  The city shall be responsible for the construction and the cost of any pumping stations and force mains required within its sanitary sewer systems. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 6162, adopted Jan. 24, 1989, did not specifically amend this Code; hence, inclusion of §§ I-VII as § 22-82 was at the discretion of the editor. 
Sec. 22-83. - Waiver of requirements for new subdivisions. 
    The city council has the right to waive any requirements set forth in Chapter 22, Article IV, of the Carthage Code for new subdivisions annexed into the city providing that such subdivisions are platted in such a manner as to provide lots of a size no smaller than twenty-nine thousand (29,000) square feet. Nothing in this section shall be construed as requiring the city to waive the subdivision regulations but shall be viewed as being permissive only. 
(Ord. No. 6361, § 1, 10-8-91; Ord. No. 6378, §§ 1, 2, 12-10-91) 
Secs. 22-84-22-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - FINANCING MUNICIPAL IMPROVEMENTS[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- The provisions included herein as Art. V, §§ 22-101-22-111, were approved by Res. No. 1164, adopted April 11, 1989, which had provided for their inclusion as Ch. 26; designation as Art. V was at the editor's discretion with the consent of the city. 
Cross reference- City participation in cost of certain improvements, § 22-82. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 22-101. - Introduction. 
    On January 24, 1989, the city council adopted Ordinance No. 6162 which provided for the construction of municipal improvements and the payment thereof, in accordance with policies and procedures to be approved by the city council prior to the ordinance becoming effective. 
(Res. 1164, 4-11-89) 
Sec. 22-102. - Provisions of Ordinance No. 6162. 
    Ordinance No. 6162 provides for the following commitments by the city subject to final approval of each project by the city council: 
(1)  The city will reimburse the developer of a platted subdivision of land for the cost of all concrete curbs and gutters which have been constructed along streets in accordance with the City Code. The same applies to any existing subdivision where the platted street right of way has not been improved, and all of the platted lots are owned by the developer. The proposed expenditure for curb and gutter construction must be submitted to the city for approval and commitment prior to construction. 
(2)  The developer is required to construct the sanitary sewers, water mains, electric lines, and street improvements before the city makes its reimbursement to the developer for the concrete curbs and gutters. 
(3)  The city agrees to finance the installation of sanitary sewers, water mains, and electric lines if requested by the developer, and assess the cost to each lot. Principal and interest payments would be spread over a period of ten (10) years at an interest rate of eight (8) percent. The city reserves the right to limit its participation in any project. 
(4)  The developer will reimburse the city the amounts of the sewer, water, and electric assessments against any lot, whenever the lot is sold, leased or otherwise involves another party. 
(5)  The developer will furnish a form of guarantee, acceptable to the city, assuring the city that the special assessments will be paid. 
(6)  The city, upon request, and at its discretion, will extend sanitary sewers and/or water mains to existing vacant lots under separate ownership within the city, and will allocate the costs to the benefiting properties. Such charges allocated to the undeveloped properties, including interest at the rate of eight (8) percent per annum, would be due and payable upon connection to the utility. Properties already improved with a well and/or septic tank will also be charged in the same manner, and will pay their share of the cost of the utility extension, at such time that a permit is issued for connection to the utility. 
(7)  The city will be responsible for the construction and the cost of any pumping stations and force mains required within its sanitary sewer system. 
(Res. 1164, 4-11-89) 
DIVISION 2. - APPLICABLE PROJECTS 

Sec. 22-103. - Criteria for eligibility. 
    In accordance with Ordinance No. 6162, eligible projects must satisfy the following criteria: 
(1)  Must be a platted subdivision of land, comprised of residential lots. 
(2)  The residential subdivision must be under a single ownership, and for the purpose of encouraging the construction of residences. 
(3)  The residential lots are planned for future sale, and the residences will be privately financed under separate ownership. 
(4)  The residential lots in any project shall be legally subject to special assessments, which can be collected by the city in accordance with state statutes. 
(5)  The utility extensions must be for residential lots or comparable small tracts of land under separate ownership, where the city's special assessment policy is not applicable. 
(6)  Any project involving state or federal funds in the financing thereof is not eligible. Such financial restriction shall not apply to single-family residences under separate private ownership. 
(7)  Projects designed for rental units are not eligible. 
(8)  Only tracts of land that are within the city limits or will be annexed subject to project approval, are eligible for city financial participation. 
(Res. 1164, 4-11-89) 
Sec. 22-104. - Same-City council authority. 
    The city reserves the right to determine the eligibility of any project, the limit of its participation, and the financial capability of the developer to meet future special assessments. 
(Res. 1164, 4-11-89) 
DIVISION 3. - FINANCIAL REQUIREMENTS 

Sec. 22-105. - Owner/developer obligations. 
    The city's intent is to assist the owner/developer of a subdivision of land with the financing of streets and utilities, in an effort to encourage residential development within the city limits. To be eligible for city participation on a project, the developer must; 
(1)  Own the land. 
(2)  Furnish evidence that future special assessments will be paid. 
(3)  Furnish a performance bond, or a letter of credit, or an alternate surety that special assessments will be paid. 
(4)  Furnish references if requested, and information regarding previous projects. 
(Res. 1164, 4-11-89) 
Sec. 22-106. - Method of financing. 
    Due to particular circumstances involving each project, the city reserves the right to select the method of financing which appears to be in the best interest of all parties involved. The time necessary to carry out the financial arrangements, and the city's involved risk are the most important considerations. Therefore the city may consider alternate methods of financing depending upon the scope of the project. 
(Res. 1164, 4-11-89) 
Sec. 22-107. - Financing alternatives. 
(a)  In accordance with Article VI, section 26(d) of the Constitution of Missouri, the city, by vote of two-thirds of the qualified electors thereof voting therein, may become indebted for the purpose of constructing streets, sanitary sewers, storm sewers and water mains. The city may provide that a portion or all of the cost of any such improvements will be levied and assessed on property benefitted by such improvements. The city must collect any special assessments so levied to retire the bonds issued for such improvements. 
(b)  Such bonds would be a general obligation of the city, and would be paid off within a period of twenty (20) years. 
(c)  Any assessment that has been levied against any lot or parcel of land would be due and payable upon its change in ownership. 
(d)  The voters within the city would authorize the sale of a certain dollar volume of bonds, a portion of which would be sold as each benefit district is established by the city council. 
(e)  The city reserves the right to take into consideration its financial risk in determining the feasibility of forming any particular benefit district. Particular attention will be given to other financial arrangements made by the developer which would affect payment of the special assessments to the city. 
(Res. 1164, 4-11-89) 
Sec. 22-108. - Review board. 
(a)  For the purpose of administering this article, a review board shall meet upon call to review all preliminary applications which have been submitted to the city engineer's office. It shall be the responsibility of the review board to solicit whatever information is necessary to determine the eligibility of a particular project. Any project that is deemed feasible by the board, for financial participation by the city, shall be referred to the city council for final approval. Upon passage of a resolution by the city council at a regularly scheduled council meeting, the project would then be advanced through the financing process by the city engineer's office, with the assistance of the city administrator. 
(b)  Any decision rendered by the review board may be appealed to the city council for its consideration. Since the proposed projects involve the commitment of city funds, the council's decision will be final. 
(c)  The review board shall be comprised of the following persons: 
City administrator 
City engineer 
General superintendent CW&EP 
Three (3) persons outside of city government, appointed by the mayor and approved by the city council. The appointed members shall serve three-year terms. Initially one (1) member shall be appointed to serve (2) years, and another one (1) year. 
(Res. 1164, 4-11-89) 
Sec. 22-109. - Utility extensions. 
(a)  Upon a written request from an owner or owners of land, the city will consider financing the extension of utilities to serve designated lots or small tracts of land under separate ownership which front an existing street. 
(b)  Under such plan the city will address each request in the following manner: 
(1)  If a petition for a utility extension bears the names of more than fifty (50) percent of the property owners who own more than fifty (50) percent of the street frontage, all of the properties involved will be assessed for the improvement. 
(2)  If the petition for a utility extension is requested by less than fifty (50) percent of the property owners that would be served by the utility extension, the city, at its discretion, may proceed with the project by formally assessing only those property owners who have requested the utility extension. A special assessment would be levied against each petitioner's property, and such debt would be retired by annual installment payments over a period of years determined by the city upon approval of the project. The annual rate of interest would be eight (8) percent. Those properties which do not desire to participate in the project will not be formally assessed via a special assessment which would appear on the tax rolls. In lieu of that, the city engineer's office will maintain records showing the amount of the special assessment that would have been formally placed against the property via the tax rolls. At such time that an application is submitted for a building permit, or a utility connection, the applicant will be required to pay off in full, all of the assessments which have been held by the city. Such payment shall include an interest payment at the rate of eight (8) percent per annum. It shall be the property owner's responsibility to inform each new owner of the affected property, of the outstanding obligation. The city engineer's office will notify the county recorder's office of the informal assessment against the property at such time that it is made of record in the city engineer's office. 
(c)  As an alternate method of financing utility extensions, the board of public works, at its discretion, may finance utility extensions using reserve funds of the utility. The board shall have the authority to transfer reserve funds between utilities, as a loan. Such loans would be repaid in a manner determined by the general superintendent of Carthage Water and Electric. 
(Res. 1164, 4-11-89) 
DIVISION 4. - EXISTING CITY POLICY 

Sec. 22-110. - Special assessments. 
    At the time of passage of Ordinance No. 6162, the city had certain established policies pertaining to street improvements and extension of utilities. For the ease of future reference such policies are set forth as follows: 
(1)  Street improvements. In locations where individual property owners abut an existing street, and it is their desire to have the city construct the necessary storm water drainage facilities, curb and gutter, and street resurfacing, the owners may initiate pavement improvements by submitting a petition to the city. The petition must contain the signatures of more than fifty (50) percent of the property owners who own more than fifty (50) percent of the street frontage abutting the proposed improvement. 
After having ascertained that the petition is valid, the city will pay seventy-five (75) percent of the cost of the street improvements, and all of the cost of the drainage facilities. The abutting property owners will pay for twenty-five (25) percent of the cost of the street improvements and all of the cost for the curb and gutter. The property owners share of the cost is placed on the tax roll as a special assessment against each parcel of land abutting the improvement. Such assessment is required to be paid off over a period of five (5) years at an interest rate of eight (8) percent per annum. 
(2)  Sanitary sewers. To date the city is composed of eighty-eight (88) separate sewer districts, each of which has been assessed for the cost of the sanitary sewers constructed within each district. However, as alternate the property owners may construct their own sewers without becoming involved in the special assessment process. 
(3)  Water mains. Water main construction is financed similar to sanitary sewers, except that the assessment is established at the rate of ten dollars ($10.00) per foot along the abutting property. 
(Res. 1164, 4-11-89) 
DIVISION 5. - CAPITAL IMPROVEMENT FUND 

Sec. 22-111. - Council to establish fund. 
(a)  The city council shall establish a capital improvement fund for the purpose of administering this article. Upon acceptance of this article, the city council shall place a referendum before the voters in the city for the issuance of $ ____________ of general obligation bonds, to be sold in increment amounts as acceptable projects are approved by the city council. According to Article VI, section 26(d) of the State Constitution, voter authorization for the issuance of the bonds requires a two-thirds majority of the voters. Should the referendum fail during the first ballot, the same issue shall be brought before the voters at a later date, at the city council's discretion. 
(b)  The city clerk shall be responsible for the capital improvement fund, similar to any other city funds. 
(Res. 1164, 4-11-89) 
Chapter 23 - TRAFFIC[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Throwing handbills on sidewalks and streets, etc., § 13-2; handbills on motor vehicles, § 13-1; disabled vehicles, § 15-26 et seq.; sight distance triangles on corner lots, § 17-1; streets and sidewalks, Ch. 21. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 23-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Alley or alleyway means any street with a roadway of less than twenty (20) feet in width. 
    Authorized emergency vehicle means a vehicle publicly owned and operated as an ambulance, or a vehicle publicly owned and operated by the state highway patrol, police or fire department, sheriff or constable or deputy sheriff, traffic officer or any privately owned vehicle operated as an ambulance when responding to emergency calls. 
    Business district means that section of the city bounded on the north by the north line of Central Street, on the east by the east line of Clinton Street, on the south by the south line of Chestnut Street and on the west by the west line of Garrison Avenue. 
    Commercial vehicle means every vehicle designed, maintained, or used primarily for the transportation of property. 
    Controlled-access highway means every highway, street or roadway in respect to which owners or occupants of abutting lands and other persons have no legal right of access to or from the same except at such points only and in such manner as may be determined by the public authority having jurisdiction over the highway, street or roadway. 
    Crosswalk means: 
(1)  That part of a roadway at an intersection included within the connections of the lateral lines of the sidewalks on opposite sides of the highway measured from the curbs, or in the absence of curbs from the edges of the traversable roadway; 
(2)  Any portion of a roadway at an intersection or elsewhere distinctly indicated for pedestrian crossing by lines or other markings on the surface. 
    Curb loading zone means a space adjacent to a curb reserved for the exclusive use of vehicles during the loading or unloading of passengers or materials. 
    Driver or operator means every person who drives or is in actual physical control of a vehicle. 
    Freight curb loading zone means a space adjacent to a curb for the exclusive use of vehicles during the loading or unloading of freight or passengers. 
    Highway means the entire width between the boundary lines of every way publicly maintained when any part thereof is open to the use of the public for purposes of vehicular travel. 
    Intersection means the area embraced within the prolongation or connection of the lateral curb lines, or, if none, then the lateral boundary lines of the roadways of two (2) highways which join one another at, or approximately at, right angles, or the area within which vehicles traveling upon different highways joining at any other angle may come in conflict. Where a highway includes two (2) roadways thirty (30) feet or more apart, then every crossing of each roadway of such divided highway by an intersecting highway shall be regarded as a separate intersection. In the event such intersecting highway also includes two (2) roadways thirty (30) feet or more apart, then every crossing of two (2) roadways of such highway shall be regarded as a separate intersection. 
    Laned roadway means a roadway which is divided into two (2) or more clearly marked lanes for vehicular traffic. 
    Motor vehicle means any self-propelled vehicle not operated exclusively upon tracks, except farm tractors and motorized bicycles. 
    Motorcycle means every motor vehicle having a seat or saddle for the use of the rider and designed to travel on not more than three (3) wheels in contact with the ground, but excluding a tractor. 
    Motorized bicycle means any two-wheeled or three-wheeled device having fully operative pedals capable of propulsion by human power, an automatic transmission and a motor with a cylinder capacity of not more than fifty (50) cubic centimeters, which produces less than two (2) gross brake horsepower, and is capable of propelling the device at a maximum speed of not more than thirty (30) miles per hour on level ground. 
    Official traffic-control devices means all signs, signals, markings and devices not inconsistent with this chapter placed or erected by authority of a public body or official having jurisdiction, for the purpose of regulating, warning or guiding traffic. 
    Owner means any person renting a motor vehicle or having the exclusive use thereof under a lease or otherwise. A person who holds the legal title of a vehicle shall be deemed the owner. 
    Park or parking means the standing of a vehicle, whether occupied or not, otherwise than temporarily for the purpose of and while actually engaged in loading or unloading merchandise or passengers. 
    Passenger curb loading zone means a place adjacent to a curb reserved for the exclusive use of vehicles during the loading or unloading of passengers. 
    Pedestrian means any person afoot. 
    Police officer means every officer of the municipal police department or any officer authorized to direct or regulate traffic or to make arrests for violations of traffic regulations. 
    Private road or driveway means every way or place in private ownership and used for vehicular travel by the owner and those having express or implied permission from the owner, but not by other persons. 
    Public highway means any public street, avenue, alley, parkway, or other place in the city used by the public for driving. 
    Railroad means a carrier of persons or property upon cars, other than streetcars, operated upon stationary rails. 
    Railroad train means a steam engine, electric or other motor, with or without cars coupled thereto, operated upon rails, except streetcars. 
    Residence district means the territory contiguous to and including a highway not comprising a business district when the property on such highway for a distance of three hundred (300) feet or more is in the main improved with residences or residences and buildings in use for business. 
    Right-of-way means the right of one (1) vehicle or pedestrian to proceed in a lawful manner in preference to another vehicle or pedestrian approaching under such circumstances of direction, speed and proximity as to give rise to danger of collision unless one grants precedence to the others. 
    Roadway means that portion of a highway improved, designed or ordinarily used for vehicular travel, exclusive of the berm or shoulder. In the event a highway includes two (2) or more separate roadways the term "roadway" shall refer to any such roadway separately but not to all such roadways collectively. 
    Safety zone means the area or space officially set apart within a roadway for the exclusive use of pedestrians and which is protected or is so marked or indicated by adequate signs as to be plainly visible at all times while set apart as a safety zone. 
    School zone means that district within one (1) block, in any direction, of any public school in the city. 
    Sidewalk means that portion of a street between the curblines, or the lateral lines of a roadway, and the adjacent property lines, intended for use of pedestrians. 
    Stand or standing means the halting of a vehicle, whether occupied or not, otherwise than for the purpose of and while actually engaged in receiving or discharging passengers. 
    State highway means a highway maintained by the state as a part of the state highway system. 
    Stop when required means, complete cessation from movement. 
    Stop or stopping, when prohibited, means any halting even momentarily of a vehicle, whether occupied or not, except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with the directions of a police officer or traffic-control sign or signal. 
    Street or highway means the entire width between the lines of every way publicly maintained when any part thereof is open to the use of the public for purposes of vehicular travel. 
    Through highway means every highway or portion thereof on which vehicular traffic is given preferential right-of-way, and at the entrances to which vehicular traffic from intersecting highways is required by law to yield right-of-way to vehicles on such through highway in obedience to either a stop sign or a yield sign, when such signs are erected as provided in this chapter. 
    Traffic means pedestrians, ridden or herded animals, vehicles, streetcars and other conveyances either singly or together while using any highway for purposes of travel. 
    Traffic-control device means any sign, signal, marking and device not inconsistent with this chapter, placed or erected by authorities of a public body or official having jurisdiction for the purpose of regulating, warning or guiding traffic. 
    Traffic-control signal means any device, whether manually, electrically or mechanically operated, by which traffic is alternately directed to stop and to proceed. 
    Traffic division means the traffic division of the police department of the city, or in the event a traffic division is not established, then the term whenever used herein shall be deemed to refer to the police department of the city. 
    Trailer means every vehicle with or without motive power, designed for carrying property or persons and for being drawn by a motor vehicle. 
    Truck means every motor vehicle designed, used or maintained primarily for the transportation of property. 
    Vehicle means every device in, upon or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon a street, excepting devices moved by human power or used exclusively upon stationary rails or tracks. 
(Code 1978, § 300.010) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 300.010. 
Sec. 23-2. - Obedience to police and fire department officials. 
    No person shall willfully fail to refuse to comply with any lawful order or direction of a police officer or fire department official. 
(Code 1978, § 305.180) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 300.080. 
Sec. 23-3. - Obedience by persons propelling pushcarts or riding animals. 
    Every person propelling any pushcart or riding an animal upon a roadway, and every person driving any animal-drawn vehicle, shall be subject to the provisions of this chapter applicable to the driver of any vehicle, except those provisions of this chapter which by their very nature can have no application. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 300.085. 
Sec. 23-4. - Public employees to obey traffic regulations. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall apply to the driver of any vehicle owned by or used in the service of the United States government, this state, county, or city, and it shall be unlawful for any such driver to violate any of the provisions of this chapter, except as otherwise permitted in this chapter. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 300.095. 
Sec. 23-5. - Authorized emergency vehicles. 
(a)  The driver of an authorized emergency vehicle, when responding to an emergency call or when in the pursuit of an actual or suspected violator of the law or when responding to but not upon returning from a fire alarm, may exercise the privileges set forth in this section, but subject to the conditions herein stated. 
(b)  The driver of an authorized emergency vehicle may: 
(1)  Park or stand, irrespective of the provisions of this chapter; 
(2)  Proceed past a red or stop signal or stop sign, but only after slowing down as may be necessary for safe operation; 
(3)  Exceed the maximum speed limits so, long as he does not endanger life or property; 
(4)  Disregard regulations governing direction of movement or turning in specified directions. 
(c)  The exemptions herein granted to an authorized emergency vehicle shall apply only when the driver of any such vehicle while in motion sounds an audible signal by bell, siren, or exhaust whistle as may be reasonably necessary, and when the vehicle is equipped with at least one (1) lighted lamp displaying a red light visible under normal atmospheric conditions from a distance of five hundred (500) feet to the front of such vehicle.
